column2: HOUSTON, July 17 -- Flying to the moon aboard Apollo 11 today are hundreds of messages and mementos that will not only mark man's first step on another celestial body but also praise the living and honor the dead.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- Assistant Secretary of State Joseph J. Sisco left the Soviet Union today after having failed to make substantial progress in four days of talks with Soviet officials on the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Members of a study team that last month accused Saigon of religious and political suppression criticized the Nixon Administration today for "shoring up the dictatorial regime" of President Nguyen Van Thieu.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A plan for the gradual elimination of cigarette advertising on television and radio has been ratified by directors of the National Association of Broadcasters.

In the advertising skirmishes with the Maverick, Ford's answer to that ubiquitous beetle from West Germany, Volkswagen advises, "Accept no substitutes.'' But the Maverick is no more a substitute for the Volkswagen than apples are for oranges.

In an oblique attack on proposals to build an oil complex in Maine that would utilize imported petroleum at lower prices than currently available, Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel told the National Petroleum Council the other day that the present import quota system for oil had "served well until we began to develop many exceptions."

Television is scheduled to blanket the world on early Monday morning with pictures of the moon landing of Apollo 11 One unanswered question is how many people will see the images. Estimates that became available yesterday put the total potential audience of live or delayed showings near one billion.

UNTIL recently, I would have been as unlikely to notice two books on bringing up children in New York City as I would some similarly promising title -- like a book on raising tropical fish in the East River. I have no children, and I always figured that if I ever did, it would be the end of living in New York for me.
WAPAKONETA, Ohio, July 17 (UPI) -- The Fisher Cheese Company today added a night shift and went into operation seven days a week because of a heavy demand for its "moon cheese."
A new post, that of regional director of stores, has been created by the New York division of R. H. Macy Co., to accommodate expanding sales and profits of the division.

HONOLULU, July 17 (UPI) -- The 39-foot sloop Argonaut was declared the over-all winner of the 25th biennial trans-Pacific yacht race today as Class C boats took all the honors in the 2,225-mile race from Los Angeles to Hawaii.

HOUSTON, July 17 -- Despite grumbling among scientists who felt that the Apollo project was a stunt of little value, the first landing of men on the moon may generate more scientific discoveries than any expedition in history.
" THE best laid schemes o' mice and men gang aft a-gley," wrote Robert Burns many years ago.

Governmental agencies, schools, many private concerns and the New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that they would be closed Monday to observe a National Day of Participation honoring the Apollo 11 moon flight.

A pair of regally bred 2-year-old fillies, the Wheatley Stable's Inheritance and Ogden Phipps's Bright Sun, made things delightful for the favorite players among the 23,558 sweltering fans at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- A Mohawk Indian who lives in Greenwich Village is a leading candidate for the post of Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

WITH the death of Red Rolfe last week, the Yankees lost another link with their storied past. It would be unthinkable, almost sinful, not to offer an appraisal of one who came closer than most to being the beau ideal of the Yankees. He had all the finer qualities, both as ballplayer and as man.
The Instrument Systems Corporation announced yesterday it had acquired four companies for stock valued at about $11.3-million.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday visited a Negro church in the Ocean Hill section of Brooklyn where members of the Eastern Baptist Association were holding their 48th annual session.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Senate Finance Committee, in what may prove an empty gesture, voted 9 to 8 today to report to the Senate without change the bill passed by the House extending the 10 per cent income tax surcharge.
Preparations are being made for President Nixon to speak to Neil A. Armstrong and Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. early Monday morning as they walk on the moon. The event would be nationally televised.
The state announced yesterday that it would lease 1.8 million square feet of office space on 45 floors of the World Trade Center, now under construction in lower Manhattan.

HOUSTON, Friday, July 18 -- The moonbound Apollo 11, its systems sound and its aim true, was coasting far past the halfway point of its 240,000-mile outward journey early today amid rising expectations of success for the first lunar-landing attempt by men.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, July 17 -- Fighting flared once again along the El Salvador-Honduras border this afternoon after peace missions to the Central American countries had obtained cease-fire agreements.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Ford Foundation announced yesterday a joint contribution of $3.6-million to underwrite the cost of a new Sunday night series combining elements of theatrical entertainment and public affairs discussions in a courtroom setting.

BRISTOL, England, July 17 -- Britain and South Africa were tied, 1-1, today in the Davis Cup European Zone finals as four anti-South African protesters were forcibly carried off center court and Bob Hewitt, the Springbok No. 1, staged some temperamental tantrums of his own as he defeated Graham Stilwell.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Latin-American diplomats said today that the United States had urged the Council of the Organization of American States to keep a plea by Honduras for urgent military aid on its agenda as an apparent psychological deterrent against further military moves by El Salvador.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The opposition took the initiative in the debate on the antiballistic missile issue by calling the Senate into an unusual closed session today to consider secret information that was described as critical of the Administration's proposed Safeguard system.
A pledge to press for a road around the Battery as a substitute for the abandoned Lower Manhattan Expressway was given yesterday on behalf of Percy E. Sutton, the Manhattan Borough President.
One of the lessons of the present spectacular voyage to the moon is that the American mind and the American political system seem to need great challenges and clear goals to work at their best.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- An advisory committee to Congress called today for a mandatory system of comprehensive health insurance for all Americans.

BRUSSELS, July 17 -- Economic ministers of the six Common Market countries acted today to strengthen financial cooperation, and, in effect, bring Europe a step closer toward the ultimate goal of a common currency.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The House Judiciary Committee voted down two key sections of President Nixon's voting rights program today and then approved a five-year extension of the present law.

We note The Times's call (editorial July 9) for preservation and development of Jamaica Bay as a municipal park, national recreation area or national seashore. If viewed independently, these goals are most laudatory.

A coordinating body of all branches of Judaism denounced yesterday what it described as "calls to violence and vigilantism emanating from various quarters including a small and unrepresentative segment of the Jewish community."
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 17 -- A Voyage to the Moon will be the theme on July 26 when the Monmouth Turf Charity Ball and Carnival is held at the Monmouth Park Race Track here.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Five medical scientists told a Senate committee today that certain seasonings in baby foods were potentially harmful and nutritionally unnecessary.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell to a 22-month low for the period ended July 15, the exchange said yesterday.
Porter McKeever, director of information of the United States Mission to the United Nations from 1947 to 1952, has been elected president of the United Nations Association of the U.S.A.

President Kaunda has stepped out of character with an attack on Zambia's High Court. Irked by the quashing of prison sentences against two Portuguese soldiers for a border incursion, Dr. Kaunda asked caustically whether the court was "defending the interests of the people or foreign interests."

A man was killed and at least 150 people were prostrated by stifling heat last night during a massive subway tie-up that left thousands of riders trapped in the Lexington Avenue IRT tunnels between 77th and 125th Streets.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 18 -The Newport Folk Festival spread out all over the 15 acres of sun-drenched Festival Field this afternoon to become a folk music bazaar.
The American Stock Exchange has issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by major shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The following changes were included:
HOUSTON, July 18 -- The two men who will be the first to tread the moon, early on Monday may find that walking is not the best way to get around. The answer may be a "kangaroo hop."
LONDON The climax of H. G. Wells's film "Things to Come" was the dispatch of a youth and a girl to the moon. He placed the moonlanding in 2055 A.D. In his scenario (1935) he wrote:

The Nassau County Executive, Eugene H. Nickerson, called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to halt any action on the pending rate increase being sought by the New York Telephone Company "until normal service has been established."

It will be 4:17 P.M., Eastern daylight time, when the astronauts Neil A. Armstrong and Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. begin their 22-hour stay on the moon, and many of their countrymen will be getting ready for supper.
DOES saving money on clothes make you go into stitches of triumphant mirth? Well, B. H. Wragge can now provide the Stitches.
DACCA, Pakistan, July 12 -- The military Government's recent economic measures favoring impoverished East Pakistan over the better developed West have created no enthusiasm here in East Pakistan.
Of the three Presidents who have occupied the White House since the initiation of Project Apollo, President Nixon has had least responsibility for that massive program.

The Communications Satellite Corporation reported yesterday a rise in second-quarter earnings to $1,976,000, or 20 cents a chare, from $1, 976,000, or 20 cents a share from $1,506,000, or 15 cents, the year before. Revenues advanced to $11,546,000 from $7,314,000.

HASTINGS -- ON HUDSON, N. Y., July 18 -- George (Sandy) Dillon, the defending champion, and Joe Kryla, the 1958 victor, advanced today to the quarterfinal round of the 50th annual Westchester Golf Association's amateur championship at St. Andrew's Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The painful, as distinct from the popular, nature of tax reform is beginning to sink in to members of Congress.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 18 -- Two operators of drive-in theaters have filed a suit in Federal Court challenging the constitutionality of a 1907 obscenity law invoked by state authorities in the seizure of six films on July 9.
Ernie Banks, who conceivably could become the first black manager in the majors, turned down a chance to manage this winter because he doesn't want to spend an four extra months away from his family.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 18 -- Entrepreneurs here have found that turning off Niagara Falls is not bad for business.

LONDON, July 18 -- Nothing so illuminatingly reveals the pristine innocence of critics more than the childlike pleasure we take in being proved right. Perhaps it is because we are so frequently proved wrong.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Following is the text of a message on population sent to Congress today by President Nixon:

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 18 -- Dennis Furjanic, a rookie defensive end, was lucky enough to get past the first hard contact drill of the Giants' training camp yesterday and then he got hit by what has become the great leveler during this first week of training -- the heat.
CHARLESTON, S. C., July 18 -- A 113-day strike at Charleston County Hospital ended today.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., July 18 -- Arnold Palmer said it was the hottest day on which he ever played golf as opening-round leaders in the $150,000 Philadelphia Golf Classic, wilted today and Tommy Jacobs set the 36-hole pace at 139 after a second round of 70.
ESTORIL, Portugal, July 18 -- Don Juan of Bourbon stepped aside today but not down.
The stock market turned in a chilly performance yesterday as the rest of the city sweltered.

Members of a private study team that recently spent seventeen days investigating political conditions in South Vietnam report that they found "a climate of political and religious suppression" incompatible with "representative or stable government." The team included Representative John Conyers Jr., Democrat of Michigan; John deJ. Pemberton, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union, and representatives of leading religious groups.
At 5 A.M. yesterday, Charles F. Luce, the chairman and chief executive officer of Consolidated Edison, was awakened in his Bronxville home by a telephone call.

HOUSTON, July 18 -- Observers of the Soviet space program said today that the present period of good feeling between American and Russian spacemen had led to a ceasefire in the cold war overtones of the space race.

LEE, Mass., July 18 -- The fourth weeks program at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival was not officially designated a Norman Walker festival but could easily have been mistaken for one. Mr. Walker presented three of the four works on the program, two of which were premieres.
SUMMIT, N. J., July 18 -Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood won her fifth Women's New Jersey Golf Association 54-hole stroke-play championship today with a total of 248 at the Canoe Brook Country Club.
Stocks in London closed a dull week yesterday with a slight quickening of pace.

LUCCA, Italy, July 18 -- State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican candidate for Mayor of New York, says he is in this old, walled Tuscan city to rest from the primary, but he may have picked up some votes yesterday.
LOME, Togo -- Until World War I, when it was split between France and Britain under a League of Nations mandate, this West African nation was a German colony -- the model colony of the Second Reich.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- In one of the biggest upsets of the outdoor track and field season, Juris Luzins, a William and Mary student, beat Ralph Doubell, the Olympic champion, and Byron Dyce in the 800-meter run tonight.
Wide-open politicking for high church office is the newest trend in religion.
New issues were caught in the general stock-market downdraft this week although a fairly sizable group of companies managed to sell their shares publicly for the first time.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -Donna Mudrinich, who will not be 2 years old until September, has inspired an invention.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The White House announced today that President Nixon plans to talk with the Apollo 11 astronauts as they explore the moon. The conversation is to be televised nationally.

President Nixon's goal of making birth control information available to all American women drew a warning yesterday from a Roman Catholic spokesman. He said that such a program would put too much pressure on the poor.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Dr. John H. Knowles said today that "positive steps" must be taken to ease the burden of the elderly, who were beset by inadequate income, inflation and the rising cost of medical services.

" I AM weary," said Fearless Football Fan, "of retirements and restaurants, agents and arguments. Now that the training camps are going, give me news of players playing. I want the hue of heroes and the physiology of phenoms, rather than the breadth of bonuses."
Northwest Industries, Inc., amended its exchange offer yesterday for any or all of the common stock of the B. F. Goodrich Company.

A globe-trotting stakes campaigner, Nodouble of the Verna Lea Farm, will attempt to carry the top weight of 127 pounds, as well as the burden of favoritism, in the $109,000 Brooklyn Handicap at Aqueduct today.
There has been much - talk as to what the first words of the astronauts might be when, as, and if they land upon the moon.
National Airlines won President Nixon's approval yesterday as the United States-flag carrier on a new nonstop route between Miami and London. It promptly announced a start of daily service on Jan. 1.
BRUSSELS, July 18 -- The Common Market's executive commission predicted today a slowdown in world economic growth next year.

The Administration won a hollow victory when it pushed its surtax bill through the Senate Finance Committee by a one-vote margin. No action can be taken on the floor of the Senate so long as Majority Leader Mike Mansfield is steadfast in his resolve to couple the surtax with meaningful tax reforms.

BERLIN -- No other city in the Western world contributes so much public money to the arts as does West Berlin. To an American accustomed to the litany of financial distress intoned by cultural institutions across the land, it comes as a staggering statistic that West Berlin subsidizes its opera, orchestras, theaters, museums, painters. sculptors and writers with $25-million a year.
Each day a mother walks down to the foot of Isham Street near Manhattan's northern tip and into Inwood Hill Park to make sure that the emergency police phone there is still operating.

MADRID, July 18 -- It is widely asumed here that Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon will take the oath of acceptance as successor to the Spanish throne next Wednesday, the day after Generalissimo Francisco Franco announces the restoration of the monarchy in Spain before an extraordinary session of the Cortes (Parliament).

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the welded track where a Seaboard Coast Line passenger train derailed near here June 28 was inadequately supported by ballast.

MOSCOW, July 18 -- The Soviet Union strongly hinted today that the unmanned Luna 15 spacecraft would do no more than remain in moon orbit and not try to land, gather rock samples and return to earth, as predicted by some observers.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Personal income rose $5.9-billion in June, spurred by a $4.1-billion increase in wages and salaries, the Commerce Department reported today.

CUYAHOGA FALLS, Ohio, July 18 -- The six-week summer series of the Blossom Music Center started on July 10 with two guest conductors officiating at the three concerts. Last night a more potent figure took over.
Buffy Sainte-Marie, the beautiful Cree Indian folk singer, bends a song as if it were tanned leather.
The Olympiakos soccer team of Greece defeated Portuguesa of Brazil 2-1, last night in the second game of the Greek-American soccer tournament before 4,500 spectators at Randalls Island.

Juan B. Martin, Argentina's new Foreign Minister, urged here yesterday that the Nixon Administration abolish restrictions on some of Latin America's key exports before it considered plans to grant the area preferential treatment.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Medical specialists testified today that there was no significant health problem posed by the use of monosodium glutamate in seasoning baby foods.

Hundreds of Long Island Rail Road passengers, seeking a weekend of escape from the heat-drenched city, found themselves sweltering in Pennsylvania Station at the height of the rush hour last evening when a signal failure touched off a series of delays.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 18 -- In a hotel suite featuring a burgundy rug, a blond hostess, pink phones and businessmen with blue badges, the contractors who have contributed to the moon-landing program wait nervously for the finale of the $24-billion drama.
BERKELEY, Calif., July 18 -- A professor who specializes in psychedelic anthropology said today that he had bought The Berkeley Barb for $200,000 and intended to run it.
The Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday that it would discipline air-traffic controllers whose "sick strike" snarled air travel last month.
A 65-year-old Bowery pawnbroker who refused to hand over his money was shot and killed yesterday by one of two gunmen, who were accompanied by a woman.
Steel companies, bell and jewelry makers, coffin and machinery companies and meat packers were all involved in yesterday's merger activity.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 18 -- Controller Mario A. Procaccino criticized Mayor Lindsay today for what he called "a paternalistic, discredited approach'' to welfare recipients.

HOUSTON, Saturday, July 19 -- The Apollo II astronauts closed in on the moon early today on the third day of their historic landing attempt. Yesterday the Soviet Union gave assurance that its unmanned lunar-orbiting spaceship would not intersect the Apollo's trajectory.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- The Government filed suits today against four restaurants, a skating rink and a golf club in five Southern states, accusing all six of discriminating against Negroes.

J. Victor Herd, chairman and chief executive officer of the Continental Insurance Company, which owns 34 per cent of the common stock of Diners' Club, Inc., said yesterday that his company had no plans to acquire the rest.
The Port of New York Authority has withdrawn its opposition to the merger plans of the Norfolk Western and Chesapeake Ohio Railways.
IT is one of the virtues of partisan biography at its best -- and Mr. Fleming's is a splendid example of the kind -- that some of the author's own passion rubs off on the reader.

As one who believes that our involvement in virtually a civil war in Vietnam is in the wrong place, at the wrong time, and in the wrong war, I am convinced that the time has come for immediate action to end the war.
CAN a young man from Lima, Peru, a pretty blonde from Oregon and a Brooklyn boy find happiness together?
WASHINGTON, July 18 -Franklyn C. Nofziger, former press secretary to Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, has been appointed a White House assistant.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz is conducting an inquiry into the curtailment of interest payments to 12,500 tenants of Parkchester, the Bronx apartment complex.
IF there a such a thing as a friendly proxy war in the corporate world, it is under way right now at the Bulova Watch Company.

" Put it this way, you're a prisoner in your own home," the chairman of the New Jersey Avenue Community Association said, looking out on the hot street where a Brooklyn State Senator and a Negro block leader were stabbed Thursday night.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -President Nixon proposed today a substantial expansion of the Government's birth control programs and the establishment of a commission to study the implications of continued population growth in the United States.

Prof. Henry Steele Commager's argument [Topics July 5] that the American Revolution of 1775-76 was "positive and constructive" while the current youth revolt is "negative and destructive" is nothing short of sheer arrogance.

It was with great dismay that I read the terms of the new rent control law. Under the previous agreement, one of the sharpest inequities was that no protection was offered to the tenant who, during the time covered by the agreement, entered into a new lease.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -There is a growing belief in Congress that President Nixon's antiballistic missile program will be approved by perhaps a half-dozen votes in the Senate.

WASHINGTON -- The turn of a potter's wheel has taken Nancy Sweezy from running a handicraft shop in Cambridge, Mass., to what is called the "dark corner" of Moore County, N. C. Nancy Sweezy said she was perfectly happy running Country Roads, a handicraft shop in Cambridge, catering to the Harvard clientele. But one day in March, 1968, she and her daughter, Lybess, stopped at the Jugtown Pottery in the North Carolina piedmont.
Most of the assumptions in Rabbi Levi Olan's presidential message to the Central Conference of American Rabbis (Times, June 17) require serious challenge.

BRISTOL, England, July 18 -- The only demonstration inside the Bristol Lawn Tennis Club Grounds today was a characteristic ball-slugging and racquet-throwing display by Bob Hewitt of South Africa as he and Frew McMillan were upset in doubles by Mark Cox and Peter Curtis, 6-4, 3-6, 4-6, 6-4, 9-7 and Britain took a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup European Zone finals.
Consolidated Edison said yesterday that continued public opposition to proposals for new electric power plants was undermining its efforts to meet the annually increasing demands.

A Penn Central Company spokesman said yesterday that it was cheaper to commute to New York City on the New Haven Railroad than to drive in and park. The comment followed criticism earlier this week to the effect that the New Haven's commutation fares were excessive.
MONTREAL, July 18 - The New York Mets had their first international incident tonight, a minor border skirmish between Ron Brand of the Montreal Expos and Cleon Jones during the Mets' 5-2 victory.
A $75,000 libel award to Senator Barry M. Goldwater was upheld unanimously yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals here.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- George Douglas Hofe Jr., 39 years old, of South Orange, N.J., was named today as director of the Department of the Interior's Bureau of Outdoor Recreation.

Joe Namath agreed yesterday to sell his one-half interest in the Lexington Avenue restaurant, Bachelors III. The 26-year-old quarterback of the New York Jets will resume his football career tomorrow evening when he reports to the team's training camp at Hofstra University.
Following are highlights of the remainder of the Apollo 11 flight plan. The timetable is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern daylight.

A top official of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., denied last night that the mutual fund management company was negotiating to hire Hamer H. Budge, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission since February.

MANILA, July 18 (AP) -- The United States-Australian naval board investigating the collision of the American destroyer Frank E. Evans and the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne ended its inquiry today and sent a secret report to the two navies.

THE crew of Apollo 11 caught the television industry by surprise late yesterday afternoon in converting what was to be a test audition of life within the capsule into a full-fledged color TV show of surpassing technical quality.

CINCINNATI, July 18 (AP) -- Allan Stone of Australia upset Arthur Ashe, the United States No. 1 tennis player, today in quarter-finals of the $17,000 Western open tennis championships. Stone, ranked No. 7 in his country, scored a 3-6, 7-5, 7-5 victory.
THE Litchfield Historical Society has concentrated on furniture made in the county before 1840 for its current exhibition.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 19 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that South Vietnamese armed forces would not be able to replace all the United States combat troops in Vietnam by the end of 1970.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -President Nixon, appealing to officials and relief agencies involved in the Nigerian civil war, has urged a resumption of food and other shipments to secessionist Biafra.

The threat of a major power failure forced Consolidated Edison and other major power producers in large sections of the Northeast to appeal to customers yesterday to make do with as little electricity as possible.
When Mayor Lindsay dropped plans for two of New York's most controversial expressways this week it was both a political act and a sign of the times.

SAN SALVADOR, July 18 -El Salvador accepted a four-point peace plan tonight to end her undeclared war with Honduras. A report received in San Salvador said that Honduras had accepted several hours earlier.
Silver futures prices rose 80 cents to $1.10 an ounce yesterday as 730 contracts changed hands.

NEW DELHI, July 18 -- The leaders of the governing Congress party failed again tonight in their efforts to reconcile Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and her ousted Deputy Prime Minister, Morarji R. Desai.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -Artillery shells and bombs loaded with lethal nerve gas have been shipped to major United States military bases overseas on a worldwide basis for years, knowledgeable sources said today.

If Mayor Lindsay's decision to abandon plans for the Lower Manhattan Expressway results in an exodus from the city of many manufacturing and warehousing enterprises, as the Regional Plan Association gloomily forecasts, and the loss of large numbers of skilled and semi-skilled jobs, New York City will have paid a high price for his bid for votes.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association reduced today the amount of its stock that must be purchased and held by institutions servicing mortgages for Fanny May.
The two-day rally on the American Stock Exchange ended abruptly yesterday as prices fell in the lightest trading volume of the year.
A heavy volune of new financing was announced yesterday throughout the credit markets.

NAHA, Okinawa, July 18 -- The presence of a chemical unit within the United States Army's Second Logistical Command here has been a matter of knowledge among a few Okinawans and the accident that reportedly occurred last week apparently confirmed its existence.

Gilberto Gerena-Valentin, whose dismissal as a director of the city's Commission on. Human Rights touched off angry protests and demonstrations, was admitted to Trafalgar Hospital early yesterday to recover from a hunger strike.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 -- A leading Biafran official proposed today that the United States act to increase relief airlifts to Biafra and obtain guarantees from Nigeria that there will be no attacks on the Uli airfield.

A Swiss team tournament begins this afternoon at the New York Hilton under the auspices of the Greater New York Bridge Association. Play begins at 1:30 P.M., and all teams continue in the event until the final session tomorrow night.

CHRISTIANSTED, Virgin Islands, July 18 (AP) -- Thor Heyerdahl abandoned his battered reed boat Ra 600 miles short of his goal tonight after sharks chased away six of his crewmen as they tried to repair the craft.

Coach Weeb Ewbank's announcement that Joe Namath had finally settled his differences with Pete Rozelle, the commissioner of professional football, brought forth a collective sigh of relief from his New York Jet teammates last night at their Hofstra University training camp in Hempstead, L. I.

Fritz Peterson confesses that every once in a while he has difficulty maintaining his concentration on the mound. Last night was not one of those times, for he pitched a six hitter as the New York Yankees defeated the Washington Senators, 5-0.
TO Dr. Mstislav Vsevolodovich Keldysh, the slender, soft - spoken, silver haired leader of the Soviet scientific establishment, space is not an arena for the continuation of international hostility.

MIAMI, July 18 (AP) -- John Fairfax was 90 miles south of Miami today paddling easily toward what friends said will be a landing tomorrow at Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a six- month journey across the Atlantic.
A member of the Prospect Park Advisory Board charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had forced her to resign because she had criticized the Mayor.
TOKYO, Saturday July 19 -- The report that the United States has been stocking deadly nerve gas on Okinawa has let loose a storm of protest in Japan and the Ryukyu Islands.
ONSTAGE nudity seems to be rapidly replacing the weather as a conversation topic. And like the weather (and like much of the nudity), although talk is plentiful, action -- so far -- has been minimal.

JUST as every automobile requires periodic maintenance (engine tune-ups, lubrication, etc.) so too does every power mower, yard tractor, hedge trimmer, snow thrower and similar piece of power-driven outdoor equipment require the same kind of regular preventive maintenance.

The responses to the question whether nudity should be displayed onstage miss the point altogether -- as, indeed, does the question. The one point on which all those who have offered an opinion on nudity in the theater are in agreement is that the nudity, whether desirable or not, is a step toward naturalness and sincerity.

The Transit Authority said yesterday that passengers who ignored warnings and walked through subway tunnels helped prolong the subway tie-up Friday night in which one man died and more than 150 persons were prostrated by heat.
MOSCOW, July 19 -- The Soviet Union announced tonight that the orbit of its unmanned lunar spacecraft, Luna 15, had been changed. No reason was given for instituting the new, higher orbit.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 19 (UPI) -- Insubordination surged from off the pace today to capture the 30th running of the $159,350 Hollywood Park Juvenile Championship, first major test for 2-year-olds.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- Francis P. Beattie, sailing Galure, won the Grundoon Trophy on Long Island Sound today in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual day-race for Luders-16 Class sloops.

CARMEL, N. Y., July 19 -- Ch. Arriba's Prima Donna, a 3-year-old boxer owned by Dr. and Mrs. P. J. Pagano of Pelham Manor, N. Y., and Dr. Theodore S. Fickes of Marblehead, Mass., was named best in show at the 18th annual Putnam Kennel Club's 1,225-dog fixture on the Kent School grounds today. It was the fawn boxer's 18th top award. On the way, she registered her 26th group victory.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. -- This historic hamlet of 17,000 souls is now in the full swing of its 1969 summer, with the New York City Ballet in residence at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center through next Sunday and the Philadelphia Symphony taking over for the major part of August.

LINCOLN, Neb., July 19 -The University of Nebraska has presented an honorary doctoral degree to Theodore C. Sorensen despite ccriticism of the former special counsel to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson.

Vince Lombardi is for sale. You can buy a significant part of pro football's most famous coach -- 5 hours 12 minutes worth -- for 43,052. Lombardi comes in cans, 12 of them. Each can contains a reel of 16 millimeter color film running 26 minutes and narrated by himself. That comes to $254.33 a lesson.

Twenty-five years ago, the United Nations Monetary and Financial Conference at Bretton Woods, N. H., agreed to establish the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The two institutions have played a vital role in the monetary and financial developments of this generation. White it was recognized that the World Bank was essential for postwar reconstruction and development, as the primary concern at Bretton Woods was the monetaryfund.

VIENNA. THE calendar of change governing the museums of Europe is so different from the headlong pace at which their American counterparts are adapting themselves to what is, in effect, a new and larger public as well as a new chapter of art history, that one feels, at times, that the European institutions are almost a different order of phenomena altogether.

SOME of the top officials directing day-to-day preparations for Apollo lunar flights became seriously worried 18 months ago about the dizzying complex of computer programs for the rockets, the spacecraft and the ground-support network.

SAN SALVADOR, July 22 -El Salvador demanded today that the Organization of American States set up a war-crimes court to try Honduran leaders for genocide as one of five conditions for withdrawing her troops from occupied areas of Honduras.
Wheat and corn prices moved lower yesterday and oats, rye and soybeans were irregular on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The city asked the State Health and Insurance Departments yesterday to delay action on a request by the Blue Cross for hospitalization insurance increases averaging 49.5 per cent until a plan was developed to make the Blue Cross a force in controlling spiraling hospital costs.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan Democrat of Arkansas, proposed stiff penalties today for college rioters.

HONG KONG, July 22 -- For Burgess Meredith, the decision of the United States to ease trade restrictions with Communist China came as a pleasant surprise. Yesterday he was told that he would not be able to take back to New York some art objects he admired.
HOUSTON, July 22 -- As the three Apollo astronauts sped toward home this afternoon, Mission Control read to them a detailed summary of the day's news on the earth.
A DECLARER who finds that the partnership assets are considerably more than he is likely to need for his contract sometimes falls into the trap of overconfidence.

CHICAGO, July 22 -- Seventeen Negroes were arrested today after they took over the office of Thomas J. Murray, president of the Chicago Building Trades Council, in downtown Chicago in support of demands for more Negro workers and foremen in building trades unions.

MADRID, July 22 -- When Generalissimo Francisco Franco told Juan Carlos last week that he was to be his successor, the Prince sent a painful twopage, hand-written letter to his father, Don Juan of Bourbon.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The public will get its first chance to welcome the Apollo 11 astronauts back to the earth next month when they make a hectic, one-day tour from coast to coast, the White House announced today.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday following six days of declines.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 22 -- President Tito received former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey today for private talks that lasted more than an hour. The meeting took place at the secluded Adriatic Island of Brioni, President Tito's summer residence. Mr. Humphrey was accompanied by his wife.

ROME, July 22 -- There are so many trousers and long skirts whizzing through the Rome couture collections for winter that legs in nylon stockings look almost indecent. Pants, worn with a short dress, and the mid-calf length coat or skirt have come out by the bushels in the Italian shows, which end this week.

" Magnificent desolation," one of the astronauts observed Sunday night as he stood on the moon's surface and surveyed its bleak landscape. The description was accurate as millions of television viewers saw for themselves. So far as the four human eyes there at the time or their accompanying camera lens could perceive, the moon is a dead planet, quiet after the unimaginable convulsions that eons ago left the tortured, pockmarked, rockstrewn mass that exists today.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The tobacco industry, yielding to pressure from the Senate and two Federal regulatory agencies, promised today to end all cigarette advertising on television and radio by September, 1970.
ROME, July 22 -- Pope Paul VI will meet the heads of state of at least seven African countries on his three-day visit to Uganda from July 31 to Aug. 2, it was announced today.
Plans for courses and departments of urban and ethnic studies at five colleges were approved yesterday by the Board of Higher Education.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (UPI) -- The Pearl S. Buck Foundation, Inc., announced today that the Nobel-Prize winning author had been elected foundation president to replace Theodore F. Harris, who resigned because of "unpleasant publicity."
Olympiakos of Greece was held to a scoreless tie by the New York Greek-Americans at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island last night, but won the summer soccer tournament organized by the New Yorkers.
" Probably the best account man that ever lived and the most dynamic marketing guy," was what one well known creative man said of James Edwin Doyle.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively agreed today on three more tax changes that would increase the taxes paid by certain businesses -- including one that would have its major impact on the big oil companies with international operations.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- Both of yesterday's Lightning Class division winners finished second today as 305 boats sailed in Larchmont's second Junior Day in this 71st race week on Long Island Sound.
The Overseas Press Club has been granted a "very brief extension" of eviction proceedings by its landlord, it was made known yesterday.
ALGIERS, July 22 -- The passionately anti-Israeli young Arabs of Algiers cheered new heroes today: members of the American Black Panther party.

PRAGUE, July 22 -- The Communist party newspaper Rude Pravo today urged Dr. Alexander Dubcek and other prominent liberal Communists to practice self-criticism of their role in the events that led to the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia 11 months ago.
Senator Kennedy has spoken of the landing of a man on the moon as marking a point at which it would be appropriate to reorient our national priorities so as to deal with "earthly" problems.

BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., July 22 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells took the first-round lead with 9 points today in the Garden State Women's Golf Association 54-hole round-robin tournament at the Somerset Hills Country Club.
MOSCOW, July 22 (AP) -Pravda has carried an account of Senator Edward M. Kennedy's automobile mishap -- but omitted any mention of the death of his passenger, Marry Jo Kopechne.

TRENTON, July 22 -- The State Commission of Investigation resumed its inquiry into organized crime in New Jersey today backed by a strong affirmation of its legality by a United States Circuit Court of Appeals.
The Ford Foundation announced a series of grants yesterday to help American public schools study and possibly adapt features of a recent British primary school reform.
The Penn Central was barred yesterday from imposing a new fare structure Aug. 1 on 14,000 commuters -- most from Westchester County -- on the New York portion of its New Haven division.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- George Romney, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said today that a solution to the nation's housing shortage should have top domestic priority once the Vietnam war was settled and inflation was halted.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Senate backers of the antiballistic missile system declared today, that a nation that can send a man to the moon can build a missile capable of shooting down enemy missiles.
HOUSTON, July 22 -- Twelve men are in absolute quarantine here because of something that probably does not exist.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 (AP) -- The enemy pressed harassing attacks against allied positions today, but there was no major break in the month-long lull on the battlefields.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Nixon ordered expenditure reductions of $3.5-billion today to offset increases of that amount now expected as a result of several factors, including actions and inactions by Congress.

MADRID, July 22 -- Prince Juan Carlos of Bourbon was designated today as the future chief of the Spanish state in succession to Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who is 76 years old and has ruled since 1939.
The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its member firms experienced a stringent profits squeeze in 1968 as a result of sharply rising costs.

Earnings results issued yesterday for the second quarter and first half showed that, of 27 major industrial companies, only seven had lower profits than in the year-earlier periods. Three of these showed minor declines for both the three and six months, one was off sharply and the other three were down only moderately for the second quarter.
BUFFALO, July 22 -- A 2-yearold girl was missing and feared kidnapped today from a carriage on the sidewalk near the Kleinhans Music Hall, where the Buffalo Philharmonic performs.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Nixon, observing that the Interstate Commerce Commission lacks leadership and continuity, advanced a plan today that he said would promote more efficient operation by the agency.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Gen. Earle G. Wheeler returned from Vietnam today with a report on the war for President Nixon. It was secret, but there were indications that the military would be willing to accept further reductions in United States troop strength in Vietnam.

Representative Shirley A. Chisholm of Brooklyn, the Democratic national committee-woman from New York State, endorsed Mayor Lindsay for re-election yesterday and challenged her party to do something about it.

Construction of the Second Avenue subway, a high priority goal of transit planners for forty years, could well begin in 1969. But once again indefinite delay is threatened by a squabble over the exact route it should follow. This must not be allowed to occur, and the Board of Estimate should approve tomorrow the direct route south to Broad and Water Streets.

Revenues of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., topped the $1-billion level for the first time in the company's history during the 12 months ended June 30, according to the first-half report released yesterday.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 22 -- Police Chief Dominick J. Arena has received stacks of telegrams and a steady stream of telephone calls concerning his investigation of the automobile accident last weekend in which Senator Edward M. Kennedy suffered minor injuries and a 28-year-old secretary was killed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam (UPI) July 22 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said in a speech made public today that it would be at least two years before national elections could be set up to include the Vietcong.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 22 -- President Suharto, noting that Indonesia still depended on the United States for defense and development assistance, expressed concern today that the Americans might turn their backs on Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Robert Montgomery, the former actor and producer, described network television programing as "mass mediocrity" today and urged the complete separation of program production from distribution.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Following is the text of a message on the Interstate Commerce Commission sent to Congress today by President Nixon, including the text of his plan for reorganizing the commission:
" Shipbuilding for the Seventies," a 26-minute color motion picture produced for the Shipbuilders Council of America was given its local preview yesterday.
MADRID, July 22 -- Following are excerpts, in unofficial translation, from the speech on succession delivered today by Generalissimo Francisco Franco before the Cortes:

PLYMOUTH, Pa., July 22 -- Mary Jo Kopechne, whose life and death were intertwined with the Kennedy family, was buried here today on a high green hillside above the slag heaps of this mined-out anthracite town. She would have been been 29 years old next Saturday.

LONDON, July 22 (AP) -- The British Government has agreed to exchange two Americans convicted of spying for the Soviet Union for at least three prisoners jailed by the Russians, a well-informed British source said tonight.

A 538-apartment low-cost public housing development in the Baychester section of the Bronx was dedicated yesterday with city officials urging the Federal Government to allocate more money for housing.
" Oh, my aching back," moaned Dr. Leon A. Star yesterday. Was he hurt? Not really. He didn't know that his unheralded 2-year-old colt, Rippy Glitters, had been entered in the first race at Aqueduct.

MOSCOW, July 22 -- The Soviet Union today virtually ignored Luna 15, its unmanned spacecraft that held the world in suspense for more than a week before apparently crashing into the moon's surface yesterday.

HARTFORD, July 22 -- The Connecticut Legislature today issued a stinging declaration of independence from Gov. John N. Dempsey, completing a twoday special session in which it passed eight bills that the Governor had vetoed.

MORICHES, L. I., July 22 -- Steve Scopinich, already assured of the title, closed with a flourish today by taking the final event of the nine-race round-robin series for the Gulden Trophy, emblematic of the junior sailing championship of the Great South Bay.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 22 (UPI) -- Mrs. Anna Chan Chennault, widow of Lieut. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault, described as an "insult" today a published report that she had tried to delay the Vietnam peace talks in Paris to help the Nixon campaign.

HOUSTON, Wednesday, July 23 -- The moon explorers of Apollo 11 gathered speed early today as the pull of the earth's gravity drew them closer and closer to home after their historic walk on another world.
The sun, which was expected to roar like a lion throughout this year of lunar exploration, has remained as quiet as a lamb during the Apollo 11 mission.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 22 -- Allen Jacobs, a fullback hopeful with the New York Giants, fractured his left elbow and dislocated his left wrist at this morning's workout. He will be lost for the season.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 22 -- The 17th-century Mulford Farm, facing the Village Green here, will be the scene of a one-day fair on Friday. The annual event, sponsored by the Ladies Village Improvement Society, an organization of 500 members, founded in 1895, raises funds for educational and civic projects, including the care of the stately elms and the many greens flanking Main Street.

BLUE POINT, L. I., July 22 -- Edwin M. Schwenk, the Suffolk County Republican chairman, called on Governor Rockefeller today to remove Dr. William J. Ronan as head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 22 -- The former faculty adviser to a student magazine that printed a sketch of two people engaged in sexual intercourse on its cover was found guilty today by the New Rochelle Board of Education of conduct unbecoming a teacher.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- President Nixon moved Glenn W. Sutton up today from vice chairman to chairman of the United States Tariff Commission.
The Student Non-Violent Coordinating Committee dropped the "non-violent" from its title yesterday and announced that H. Rap Brown had been renamed chairman of the organization.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Overseas Development Council announced yesterday the appointments of Harold Boardman as senior fellow for conferences and seminars and Dr. Harald B. Malmgren as senior fellow for economic policy.

An ambitious pop rock festival is going west 30 miles in the hope of finding a warmer reception than the one received in Orange County's Wallkill, where the climate of opposition led to the search for another site in the state.
The trustee, faculty and student committees that have been searching for a new president for Columbia University for a year have settled on the man they want for the job.

BRUSSELS, July 22 -- The six members of the European Common Market accepted today a French proposal to hold a meeting of heads of government before the end of the year to discuss the admission of Britain and other issues before the market.

The Wall Street Journal on July 18 published evidence of a recent leak of nerve gas stored on Okinawa with injury to U.S. servicemen and raised questions about possible previous accidents with injury to Okinawan children.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 22 -- Pete Bisconti and Frank Simon worked perfectly as a team, particularly on the par-3 holes, to win the 39th annual British Victory bestball tournament with a one-under-par 34, 35 -- 69 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The United States has accepted in principle a Russian proposal for opening a Soviet consulate in San Francisco and an American consulate in Leningrad.

THE Horn Hardart chain of automats, restaurants and cafeterias, which in recent years has been trying to build rapport with a new generation or two of customers through a breezy advertising campaign, lost contact with its shareholders last April but apparently made good yesterday.

FARRAGUT STATE PARK, Idaho, July 22 -- The Seventh National Boy Scout Jamboree ended here tonight with the presentation of a new "action program" calling for increased emphasis in scouting on racial problems, conservation, the menace of narcotics and decision-making by youngsters.
HOUSTON, July 22 -- A fleet of spaceships loaded to the thrusters with moon rocks could not begin to satisfy the demands for the lunar materials being brought back by the Apollo 11 astronauts.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, July 22 (Reuters) -- The Norwegian explorer Thor Heyerdahl led his six-man crew ashore today and asserted that his abandoned papyrus reed boat, the Ra, had proved its point before it became waterlogged in storms.

Three teen-aged girls were arrested last night after they were found in a Queens apartment with two rifles and 500 rounds of ammunition.
" The Front Page" is slated to have another run on Broadway in the fall.
Having spent a little over a year at Doyle Dane Bernbach, Metrecal, the weight-control drink, will be switched on Oct. 8 to Young Rubicam. The billings are said to be around $4-million.

A lone member of the City Planning Commission yesterday defeated a proposal by its chairman to approve a $3.6-million increase in construction costs of two slum-area swimming pools without prior notification of either the commission or the public.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- Clark R. Mollenhoff, Pulitzer prize-winning investigative reporter for Cowles Publications, was appointed today to be a deputy counsel to President Nixon.
The independent Petroleum Trade Employes Union ended its weekold strike against Texaco here and on Long Island last night.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Professional baseball reached the peak of its centennial celebration tonight in a good old-fashioned American way -- the 40th All-Star Game was rained out.
NEW CITY, N. Y., July 22 -- A grand jury has charged that there have been organized prostitution, illegal use of narcotics and numerous instances of escape at Rockland State Hospital.

This year, it is a Republican. Last year, it was the politicians who had to be convinced that a tax increase made sense.

William C. Durkee has been elected president and chief executive of the Royal Crown Cola Company, Columbus, Ga. He succeeds William E. Uzzell who becomes chairman of the board and chief executive of Royal Crown Cola International, Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The All-Star Game scheduled for tonight at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium was rained out. The pregame party, held in five sodden tents, was rained on and rained in, but was not rained out.

A formal order was signed in Federal District Court here yesterday, directing the court-appointed trustee of R. Hoe Co., maker of printing presses and saws, to concentrate upon delivery of new presses to five newspaper publishers, a magazine concern and three can companies who have agreed to prepay a total of $2,447,788.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 22 -- The police, aided by the National Guard, rigidly enforced tonight a curfew on the Negro community to prevent further rioting.

Rashad Mourad, the Permanent Observer of the League of Arab States to the U.N., is absolutely right in stating in his July 17 letter that "The ceasefire must be constructed as a temporary arrangement which should last . . . until peace is achieved, and no longer."

World War II was fought with outstanding generalship by our American Administration. However, statesmanship was a minus quality. The war destroyed Nazi Germany, Fascist Italy, Imperial Japan, but left Communist Russia more powerful than ever.

CARLISLE, Pa., July 22 -- "Shannon," shouted Vincent Lombardi, the noted football coach and bogeyman. "Shannon!" The shout might have been heard in nearby Harrisburg or far away Green Bay. Bob Shannon, a rookie receiver candidate of the Washington Redskins, had just goofed.

Borough President Percy E. Sutton of Manhattan said yesterday that he had enough support in the Board of Estimate to defeat the downtown route of the Second Avenue Subway that has been proposed by the Transit Authority.

NEW CITY, N. Y., July 22 -- State Supreme Court Justice Joseph F. Hawkins today directed Rockland County to adopt a 19-member county legislative form of government to comply with the mandate that counties reapportion in keeping with the rule of one man, one vote.
The Norfolk Western Railway and the Southern Railway, two of the nation's wealthiest carriers, reported sharply higher earnings yesterday for both the second quarter and the first half.
Short-term interest rates climbed to record levels yesterday, influenced by the Federal Reserve's continued tight grip on credit conditions.

Telephone revenues, manufacturing sales and consolidated net income of the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation rose to new highs for the second quarter and first half, Leslie H. Warner, president, reported yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 22 (AP) -- The Jersey City Police Department was ordered today to show why it should not be enjoined from "harassing" a Black Panther chapter.

A 48-year-old taxicab driver was shot in the shoulder yesterday during an attempted holdup in Brooklyn when he stepped on the gas and drove to a police station instead of following the gunman's orders.

PARIS -- From the threshold of a wholly new and awe-inspiring age it is hard to contemplate what vistas lie ahead of us. With a matter-of-fact approach that transcends poetry, NASA has already laid out further space exploration programs.
Hopes that the successful progress of the Apollo 11 moon mission would arrest the decline in the stock market were dashed yesterday as prices took another sharp break.

NEW DELHI, July 22 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi appeared today to have turned back the threat to her Government from the bosses of her ruling Congress party, at least for the time being, and to have emerged with a stronger hand over the direction of national policy.

The Pentagon can -- and should -- act quickly to fulfill its promise to remove chemical warfare munitions from Okinawa. But it will take months, if not years, of delicate diplomacy to remove the poisoning effect on United States-Japanese relations of the disclosure that these deadly agents have been secretly stored at the controversial American base in the Ryukyus.

INDIANAPOLIS (UPI) -- Cliff Richey, hot off his victory in the Western tournament, withstood a challenge from Rich Russell of Jamaica to win his first-round match, 6-1, 5-7, 6-3, at the $25,000 national clay-court tennis championships today at the Woodstock Club.

YONKERS, July 22 -- If, as has often been stressed, one of the greatest Rambling risks is betting on 2-year-old filly trotters, few among the 19,807 fans at Yonkers Raceway tonight heeded the warning.
Following are the highlights of President Nixon's itinerary for his round-the-world trip (times are local, with New York time in parentheses):

TROY, N. Y., July 22 -- A former City Manager of Troy told the State Commission of Investigation today that this city was bankrupted by political leaders who designed "fairy tale" budgets and then had to be bailed out by the State Legislatures.
THE MAKING OF THE PRESIDENT 1968. By Theodore H. White. 459 pages. Atheneum. $10.
MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., July 22 (AP) -- Diavolo, skippered by Peter Stern of Chicago, today was declared the over-all winner of the 45th Port Huron-to-Mackinac Island yacht race.
LONDON, July 22 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation declined today to reply to Israeli charges that its overseas radio service was presenting "Egyptian fiction" as "straight news."

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 22 -The police arrested about 75 demonstrators at the State Capitol today as they demanded action by Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie on problems in Cairo, Ill. About 30 women, including 17 men, were among those arrested.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Denny McLain, the American League's starting pitcher, learned how to be a Secret Service agent while tonight's All-Star game was rained out, then said he was flying home to Detroit for a dental appointment.
TOKYO, Wednesday, July 23 -- A wave of relief swept across Japan and Okinawa in the wake of the Pentagon's announcement that the United States would withdraw chemical warfare weapons from Okinawa.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- A sailor who publishes an antiwar newsletter learned today that he had been trailed for four months by as many as 25 naval intelligence agents.
Resorts International, Inc., a company with a big stake in gambling in the Bahamas, has embarked on an acquisition program directed toward expansion into other areas of the world.
Yesterday's merger and acquisition activity was dominated by the motion picture industry, led by a tender offer for 17 per cent of the stock of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc.

Oil industry earnings continued to be mixed yesterday. The Gulf Oil Corporation and the Cities Service Company reported increased earnings, but the Sun Oil Company and the Getty Company were less profitable than they were last year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- In his final fling before the break in the schedule for the 40th All-Star Game, the 23-year-old Reggie Jackson of the Oakland Athletics hammered out his 37th home run of the season. It put him four games ahead of the pace that Roger Maris set in his 61-homer year and an astounding 23 games ahead of Babe Ruth's pace in his 60-homer year.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Department of Defense acknowledged today for the first time that the United States had shipped lethal nerve-gas munitions to American forces overseas. It said it was removing all such munitions from Okinawa.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Seven Airlines were granted Federal authority today to fly to Hawaii from 35 cities on the mainland, in apparently the final chapter of the stormy trans-Pacific route case whose roots extend back a decade to the Eisenhower Administration.

AKRON, Ohio, July 23 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, Al Geiberger and Jay Hebert share a fondness for the Firestone Country Club. They've won six of the nine tournaments held at the 7,180-yard, par-70 layout since 1960.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday lower net income for the first six months, despite higher operating revenues. Operating revenues were $72,811,000 against $69,709,000 a year earlier. Net income slipped to $8,024,000, or $1.51 a share, from the $8,459,000, or $1.59, reported for the 1968 half.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Before a virtually empty Senate chamber, the bipartisan opposition today opened its floor battle to block deployment of the Administration's proposed Safeguard missile defense system.

DETROIT, July 23 -- The General Motors Corporation reported today that second-quarter profits dropped 17 per cent to $448.8-million, or $1.56 a common share, from $540.7-million, for $1.88 a share, a year before.
HOUSTON, July 23 -- An agent of the country's top corps of medical detectives has been assigned here to learn the cause of every illness that occurs, during the next three weeks, among 700 people.
W. W. Norton Co., Inc., a privately owned quality publishing house, is preparing to sell its juvenile department.

LONDON, July 23 -- One of the sad aspects of Soviet ballet is the lack of opportunity it offers Soviet dancers to have their own roles created for them. The whole machine of Soviet ballet possibly produces surely, but certainly produces slowly.

LISBON, July 23 -- Premier Marcello Caetano's Government today dismissed Dr. Adriano Moreira, the principal rival within the leadership, from his post as director of the Higher Institute of Social Sciences and Overseas Policy.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A defense lawyer cautioned the Navy today that it was making a political martyr out of a young seaman who has been publishing an antiwar newsletter.

ROY OSTER, the Houston expert, formerly from New York, captured second place in the recent Great Plains Open in Lubbock, Tex. He scored 5-1, with four victories and two draws, including a last-round split point with Grandmaster Arthur Bisguier of Hartsdale, N. Y., the winner of the event with 5 1/2-1/2.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 23 (UPI) -- A 36-year-old Puerto Rican teaching professional pulled an upset today by beating fifth-seeded Bob Lutz of Los Angeles in the third round of the $25,000 national clay-court tennis championships.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- The Chicago Board of Education announced today a plan to ease faculty segregation.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -State Department officials conceded today a delay in putting into effect new passport regulations relaxing restrictions on travel to Communist China.

THE gloomy announcements each month that consumer prices in the New York area have risen again should be released by someone other than Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Steady showers, a sloppy track and a sparse opposing field proved acceptable to the Calumet Farm's Royal Exchange in the $26,850 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Denny McLain was the envy of every working man in America today. He arrived for work late and left early.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- The Government sued three American companies and two British ones today, charging them with conspiring to monopolize the sales of the British drug Iron Dextran.

NEW DELHI, July 23 (Reuters) -- A Government Minister told Parliament today that a letter in which a representative of the Douglas Aircraft Company allegedly offered big bribes to an Indian airlines official was passed to the Government "with the compliments of the Boeing Company."

PRAGUE, July 23 (Reuters) -- Dr. Eugen Loebl, one of the chief victims of the Stalinist trial of Rudolf Slansky, former Secretary General of the Czechoslovak Communist party, in 1952 and the author of a best-selling book about it, has been stripped of his Communist party membership, it was announced today.
Representative James J. Delaney said yesterday that he had been informed that overpayments of more than $60-million a year had been made to welfare families in New York City.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 (AP) -- The United States took another step in reducing its combat commitment in South Vietnam today by handing over a fire-support base in the Mekong Delta to the South Vietnamese Army's Seventh Division.

TROY, N. Y., July 23 -- Joseph Casey, Republican party chairman of Rensselaer County, who has been the central figure in the State Investigation Commission's hearings here, said today that he agreed that the city had been run by "political fiat" and that he had been the power behind the scenes.
TEL AVIV. July 23 -- A bomb exploded at a bus stop on a busy thoroughfare here this morning, killing one Israeli and wounding another.

HOUSTON, Thursday, July 24 -- The Apollo 11 spaceship sped toward the earth today for the splashdown that will end its epic moon-landing voyage.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Consumer prices rose substantially again in June and have gone up 3.2% in the first half of this year, the Labor Department reported today.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 23 -- Once upon a time there were four young men named Paul, John, George and Ringo who played rock music and became so popular they escaped from the beer houses of Liverpool and Berlin. They were called the Beatles.
The City Relocation Commissioner announced yesterday that he would resign tomorrow from his $25,000-a-year post to run on the Liberal party ticket for Councilman at Large in the Bronx.

Departing from its stated goal of not increasing the amount of pollutant fuel it burns inside the city limits, Consolidated Edison announced plans yesterday for a substantial expansion of its oil-powered generating station in Astoria, Queens.

Jensen, July 14] whether U.S. abstention from U.N. resolutions deploring Israeli action in Jerusalem is "due to complete insensitivity to Arab rights in Jerusalem. . . ." Somehow that doesn't sound like the explanation -- not in view of the special sensitivity we showed in maintaining diplomatic relations with Arab nations who refused to honor American passports equally.

The direction was down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. All contracts moved lower. Wheat was off 1 3/8 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel, corn dipped 1 to 1 5/8 cents, oats fell 1/8 to 5/8, rye was down 1/8 to 3/4 and soybeans fell 1/2 to 1 1/2.
WESTPORT, Conn. -- An out-size kitchen in a converted barn here has been the scene of a weekly cook-in since Mrs. John Capsis received a pasta machine from her husband last Christmas.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, rained into a starting assignment as first-ball tosser at the All-Star Game, turned it into a double-header today by throwing out two first balls -- one to each catcher, Johnny Bench of the National League and Bill Freehan of the American.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 -- The leading American military officials here believe that the current lull in battlefield activity is likely to continue through August and possibly into September.

ATLANTA, July 23 -- The Georgia Board of Education told the Justice Department today that its letter telling the board to begin regulating school desegregation in the state was confusing, and asked for a clarification.
Mayor Lindsay appointed Gerald R. Coleman, a Liberal party official and a union executive, to the City Planning Commission yesterday, thereby gaining immediate control of the agency.
CAIRO, July 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser declared tonight that the United Arab Republic was passing to "the stage of liberation" in the conflict with Israel.

BALTIMORE, July 23 (UPI) -- Jerry Wolman has put up a $500,000 check in his bid to regain control of the Philadelphia Eagles, but it probably will be several months before he will know whether the N ational Football League team is his again.

The three giant oil companies that have begun developing the Arctic Slope of Alaska said yesterday they would study the possibility of building a large-diameter pipeline to send Alaskan crude oil from Puget Sound to the East Coast by way of Chicago.

Those who have been mourning the death of baseball must have been shocked by the glittering scene in Washington a few nights ago. In a sumptuous setting that resembled anything but a wake, the nation's leaders joined the fabled names of the sport in celebrating 100 years of professional baseball. Is baseball dead? Has professional football taken over as the national pastime? The prestigious gathering in the capital would dispute both points.
The First Hanover Corporation, its president and three other defendants were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of violating the Federal Reserve Board's margin requirements.
PARIS, July 23 -- The Saint Gobain Company and the Ponta-Mousson Company announced today they were negotiating one of the biggest industrial mergers in French history.

The National Association for Puerto Rican Civil Rights said yesterday that it would investigate the reported suicide in a police station this week by a Puerto Rican youth.

President Nixon has made the startling prediction that thirty years from now "we on this earth will have visited new worlds where there will be a form of life." Exobiologists, scientists who have been preparing to study extraterrestrial life forms but have so far been unable to find any, will wonder on what data this prediction was based.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Clifford L. Alexander Jr., who resigned last April as chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, has accepted a partnership with the Washington law firm of Arnold Porter.

A pushing incident involving three young women on a crowded subway train in Queens yesterday morning ended with one of them stabbing the other two with a letter opener when the train reached Manhattan, the police said.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- President Nixon's pladge last fall to strive for an all-volunteer military establishment and other factors associated with the Vietnam war caused the Army to miss its enlistments goal by 9,000 men in the last fiscal year, Army Recruiting Command officers report.

PRAGUE, July 23 -- The East German leadership is disgruntled over Soviet insistence on early European security talks involving West Germany, according to reliable information reaching here from Warsaw.

HARTFORD, July 23 -- A Civil War relic in the rotunda of the State Capitol Building has been declared potentially dangerous because it contains three cannonballs and several other projectiles, which, though fired over a century ago, might still explode.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Mason Williams, chief writer for the now-canceled Smothers Brothers television show, presented a one-man variety hour of his own today as the final witness at a two-day hearing by the Federal Communications Commission on proposals to limit network control over prime-time TV programing.
LONDON, July 23 -- The Salvation Army today chose Commissioner Erik Wickberg, a Swede, as its general to succeed Frederick Coutts, who will retire in September at the age of 70.

Sidney J. Weinberg, whose financial acumen earned him the sobriquet "Mr. Wall Street," died at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center last evening after a short illness. He was 77 years old.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell broadly yesterday, pushing the indexes to new lows for the year. The main reason for the decline was seen in Tuesday's drop on Wall Street.

The showdown between Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and Morarji R. This political crisis, which was aggravated by Mrs. Gandhi's abrupt decision to nationalize India's banks, is perilous but not necessarily bad for India.
