WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate Securities subcommittee will hold a one-day hearing next Wednesday on the circumstances surrounding the job offer recently received by Hamer H. Budge, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, from the group of mutual funds managed by Investors Diversified Services.

GENEVA, July 2 A spokes-[ man for Investors Overseas[ Services said today that he had[ no information "at the present[ time" about plans to add former] Vice President Humphrey and] Arthur J. Goldberg, formerl United States representative to the United Nations, to the I.O.S. board of direcors.

WASHINGTON, July. 24 -Senate Democrats agreed today on a new legislative strategy in an effort to force a vote on tax reform before considering the Administration's bill extending the 10 ,per cent tax surcharge.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that he would not seek re-election to the Senate from Minnesota next year on any ticket or run for the Senate from any other state.
A suit brought by three New York City Assemblymen challenging the constitutionality of the state's current $6.9-billion budget was argued in Supreme Court yesterday.
HOUSTON, July 24 -- It took only a change in two numbers on board the Apollo 11 spacecraft to translate its landing point more than 200 miles across the Pacific Ocean.
"Are they down yet?" an elderly- brokerage-house runner asked another in a Wall Street elevator shortly after 1 P.M. yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A constitutional amendment that would substitute direct popular election for the Electoral College as a Presidential selection system was cleared today by the House Rules Committee.

A spokesman for McDonnell Co., the brokerage house, said yesterday that the firm had sold one of its three memberships on the New York Stock Exchange, had laid off 70 of its employes and had raised new capital in the last week.
A new round of price increases began yesterday for fabricated copper products, affecting such major items as water and refrigeration tubing.

FOR the television viewer, the perfect splashdown of Apollo 11 added one more viewing experience. Because of the heavy cloud cover in the predawn Pacific area, there was no chance to see the descent of the spacecraft, as there had been with Apollo 10; one had to rely on the radio reports from those on the scene.

HOUSTON, July 24 (AP) -From launching to splashdown the great adventure lasted 195 hours 17 minutes 49 seconds. Nowhere did the clock tick louder than in the homes of Neil A. Armstrong, Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. and Lieut. Col. Michael Collins.

Turtle Bay Gardens, an oasis of 20 New York backyards of cool greenery, splashing fountains and summer flowers, will open its gates on Aug. 5 for the annual Turtle Bay Association Summer Garden Festival.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- Neither the United States nor the Soviet Union feels that the Middle East is on the brink of a major explosion, United States sources said today.
Music will be presented in a seagoing atmosphere by the South Street Seaport Museum this summer at the South Street Pier.

PARIS -- Apollo's most immediate terrestrial spin-off was the renewal of faith in the United States by Europeans and the renewal of self-confidence by the Americans themselves. The long, bedraggled drift into aimlessness would seem dramatically to have been reversed.

ALGIERS, July 23 -- Stokely Carmichael, former prime minister of the Black Panther party, said today that he had met privately here with Eldridge Cleaver, the party's minister of information. But Carmichael said he "doubted" that he would rejoin the extremist group.
Denny McLain has been grounded, but Mickey Lolich is still flying high.
PARIS, July 24 -- When guns chatter on the banks of the Suez and planes go down trailing smoke, note is taken with antiseptic objectivity in a score of modest offices around Paris.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -Mayor Lindsay and 10 members of the New York State Congressional delegation today urged Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee to rescind the relocation of 687 of 1,026 jobs at the Naval Applied Science Laboratory in the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.
Several American newspapers called in editorials yesterday or more complete disclosure of the events surrounding Senator Edward M. Kennedy's accident on Chappaquiddick Island over the weekend.
PRAGUE, July 24 -- The Communist party conceded today that politically motivated unrest among workers in Ostrava, the mining and steel center near the Czechoslovak-Polish frontier, was serious.

Higher prices and strong demand for copper lifted secondquarter earnings, the Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday. Net income was put at $38,179,000, or $1.15 a share, up from $35,967.000, or $1.08 a share, a year earlier.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 24 -- Some of the New York Giants might have been surprised this morning when Allie Sherman held a 40-play scrimmage, only two days before the first "intrasquad" scrimmage on Saturday afternoon.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 24 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy decided today to appear in Dukes County Court tomorrow morning to answer charges that he left the scene of an accident last Saturday in which a 28-year-old Washington secretary, Mary Jo Kopechne, was killed.

Trans World Airlines took a paperwork lead over Pan American World Airways yesterday in their race to be first to operate commercial flights to the moon. It announced that it had filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board an application for authority to fly "persons, property and mail between points within the United States and points on the moon."
Tax-reform proposals in Congress hit the tax-exempt bond market with a hard jolt yesterday.

NEW DELHI, July 24 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi has renewed a proposal to set up a joint India-Pakistan body to examine all aspects of normalization and improvement of relations between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -There is a widely held belief among Democratic leaders that unless Senator Edward M. Kennedy answers all questions about the fatal accident in which he was involved last weekend, he will raise ineradicable doubts about his qualifications for the Presidency.

HOUSTON, July 24 -- When the helicopter carrying the Apollo 11 astronauts touched down on the deck of the U.S.S. Hornet today, the men of Mission Control here stood up at their consoles, cheered, waved small American flags and talked of flying men to Mars.

"The courageous astronauts Armstrong, Aldrin and Collins are again on our planet," said the enthusiastic announcer in a rarely used "flash" on the Moscow radio last night. "We congratulate you on your return to earth, courageous astronauts."
RANGOON, Burma, July 21 -Peking-backed Communist insurgents in Burma have shifted their main sphere of activity from central and lower Burma to areas bordering Communist China in the north.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 24 -- While many Americans were on a vicarious space trip into the future, a nostalgic audience at the Chautauqua Institution reveled last night in a journey backward in time, back to the operetta days of yore, when hearts beat in three-quarter time and all stouthearted men pined for a girl like Jeanette MacDonald.
HOUSTON, July 24 (Reuters) -- The spirits of the astronauts soared as they neared the end of their epic flight today.
Consumers searching for villains responsible for the high cost of beef these days might well point their fingers at the people around them as well as cattlemen out West.
Following are highlights of President Nixon's itinerary for the next two days of his round-the-world trip (times are local, with New York time in parentheses):

New York City's taxicab situation is worse today than it has ever been since cabs first came into general use sixty years ago. This miserable state of affairs, causing untold inconvenience and discomfort to the riding public, is the direct result of the ability of special interests to block a sound program of reform.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- The adult helmsmen of Larchmont race week resumed today where they left off last Sunday and fared only a little better than their juniors had yesterday, when the under-18-yearolds ended their part of the antique sailing fixture in frustration. Now it was the turn of the senior skippers to draw a blank except for one class, the Ensign.
Chiefs of medical services at Lincoln Hospital charged yesterday that $1.8-million spent in the last 12 months to improve the Bronx institution had "solved not one problem."

ON a child, it's adorable but then what isn't? Usually hatless Jacqueline Onassis was seen wearing one last November. Fashion magazine editors have been wild about it for a year or more, and their enthusiasm knows no bounds for fall.
The stock market mustered a small rally in early trading yesterday, then slipped back into its losing ways and closed with a modest decline.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 24 -- A 22-year-old East Hills man, who had reported the burglary of his parents' $50,000 home yesterday was arrested by detectives after they allegedly found a half-pound of marijuana and other narcotics in his room during an investigation.

A special City Council committee, completing a ninemonth investigation, declared yesterday that the authority of the Human Resources Administration was "so fragmented that truly effective operation is virtually impossible."

George Lindsay, 49, eldest brother of Mayor Lindsay, has been active in African affairs for many years, although this is the first time he has represented a client in South Africa, associates said yesterday.

Eddie Belmonte made the whole thing look easy again yesterday at Aqueduct. The Puerto Rican jockey with the mod-haircut contributed another of his multiple victory exhitions, his successes including a 10-length triumph in the feature race.

Presidential junkets abroad have always had a mysterious alchemy, a mixture of risks and opportunities, of headlines and serious diplomacy. Incidents are always possible; concern over riots kept Dwight Eisenhower out of Japan and Lyndon Johnson out of Europe. But riots are less of a danger than the summit conference on the run which is the chief business of a Presidential voyage.

SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, July 25 -- President Chung Hee Park, in a surprise move, said today that he would resign if the constitutional revision being pushed by his supporters to allow him to be elected to a third term was voted down in a national referendum.
The Morgenthaus, Robert M. and his sister, Mrs. Joan Morgenthau Hirshhorn, have a soft spot for the Coast Guard.
American colleges and universities last year received record contributions totaling $1.57billion from alumni, friends, foundations, business and industry.

HONG KONG, July 24 (AP) -A Minneapolis yachtsman said today that he and his wife, released yesterday after eight days in Communist Chinese captivity, might have to change their plans to sail their converted lifeboat back to the United States.
With pealing bells, popping champagne corks, cheers, prayers and firecrackers, a jubilant nation celebrated the safe return yesterday af the Apollo 11 astronauts.
Most grain futures moved lower in active trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

David Cohen, chairman of the John s Bargain Stores Corporation, said yesterday his company had approached the brokerage firm of Sprayregen Co., Inc., to discuss the acquisition by John's of all of Sprayregen's stock.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz suggested four types of consumer-protective legislation yesterday to eliminate business practices "intended to put the poor and disadvantaged in a status of near serfdom to their creditors."

Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur Goldberg said yesterday that he planned, on behalf of a client, to sue S. I. Newhouse, one of the nation's leading newspaper publishers, charging him with restraining competition and monopolizing the dissemination of news.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The tobacco industry's offer to end all broadcast advertising of cigarettes by September, 1970 has delayed a new Government report on the hazards of smoking. The report is being kept at the White House while officials reassess the Administration position.
Four hundred disadvantaged youngsters left here this week for free summer vacations in Friendly Town communities on Cape Cod.

McGEHEE, Ark., July 23 -In McGehee, perhaps the most interesting consequence of the moon shot is not that the nations of the world were drawn momentarily closer together but that McGehee and New York were.

FILETTO DI CAMARDA, Italy, July 23 -- A parish priest and a Communist politician are locked in battle in this tiny hill town over the memory of 17 men killed here 25 years ago and over the reputation of the German captain who passed on the order for their execution.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino, the Democratic candidate for Mayor, told party leaders yesterday that he was opposed to reprisals against Democrats who support Mayor Lindsay.

PARIS, July 24 -- The 10 richest nations reached a monetary compromise today, virtually assuring implementation by September of the first internationally managed reserve unit to share with gold and the dollar the job of lubricating world trade.

State Senator John J. Marchi, Republican-Conservative candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that law and order were "two civilizing concepts" and that he would not permit political foes to make them "code words for racism."
MALMOE, Sweden, July 24 (AP) -- John Carlos, the Olympic medalist from San Jose, Calif., won the 100 and 200 meter dashes today as Americans dominated an international track and field meet here.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

VIENNA, July 24 (AP) -- A United States team participating in the second international wheelchair games won 28 gold, 30 silver and 17 bronze medals, putting it in first place, ahead of Austria and Poland.
JERUSALEM, July 24 -- Israeli and Egyptian forces battled for eight hours with aircraft and artillery along the Suez Canal today. The fighting was the heaviest since the sixday war of June, 1967.

TOULON, France, July 24 (AP) -- The Norwegian tanker Silja collided early today with a French passenger-cargo ship in the Mediterranean, off Toulon. She exploded and sank within a minute. Two bodies were recovered, and 18 persons were listed as missing and probably dead.

Following is a transcript of President Nixon's greetings to and conversation with the astronauts aboard the Hornet and the prayer offered by the ship's chaplain, Lieut. Comdr. John A. Piirto, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -There was no visible progress today in a dispute between the Federal Aviation Administration and several thousand air traffic controllers who have threatened to shut down the nation's air transport system.
YONKERS, July 24 -- A 52night middle meeting ended tonight at Yonkers Raceway with 25,109 fans wagering $2,808,218 on the 10-race program, including the daily double and four exactas.
Muddy Waters deserves his reputation as one of the great Chicago blues musicians.

The post-All-Star portion of the season began on a protracted and discouraging note for the New York Mets last night, as they lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3, in 12 innings at Shea Stadium before a crowd of 30,934.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -Informed observers here are looking toward a surge of diplomatic activity aiming at a conference of Arab leaders to plan joint confrontation with Israel.

Perhaps the most important result of Apollo 11's lunar landing has been to make us proud of America, as embodied in the persons of our astronauts Armstrong, Aldrin and Collins. There is therefore a widespread and natural feeling that we should do something to honor these men and recognize their efforts.

Following is a transcript of President Nixon's greetings to and conversation with the astronauts aboard the Hornet and the prayer offered by the ship's chaplain, Lieut. Comdr. John A. Piirto, as recorded by The New York Times:

WASHINGTON, July 24 -There was no visible progress today in a dispute between the Federal Aviation Administration and several thousand air traffic controllers who have threatened to shut down the nation's air transport system.
YONKERS, July 24 -- A 52night middle meeting ended tonight at Yonkers Raceway with 25,109 fans wagering $2,808,218 on the 10-race program, including the daily double and four exactas.
Muddy Waters deserves his reputation as one of the great Chicago blues musicians.

The post-All-Star portion of the season began on a protracted and discouraging note for the New York Mets last night, as they lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3, in 12 innings at Shea Stadium before a crowd of 30,934.

BONN, July 24 -- A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church in Munich indicated today that the Most Rev. Matthias Defregger, Auxiliary Bishop of Munich, would remain in seclusion for an indefinite period until the publicity surrounding his part in wartime executions in Italy died down.

COMPLAINT Department. The New York regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission has been hearing a lot of complaints lately from investors who think they have been victimized by unscrupulous Wall Streeters.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -Treasury-bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- A provision that could sharply curb Federal efforts to desegregate public schools was approved today by the House Appropriations Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel today announced the signing of a $225,000 contract for a study of damage being done to coral reefs in the tropical Pacific Ocean by the Crown of Thorns starfish.
GENEVA, July 24 -- Mrs. Alva Myrdal of Sweden today urged the disarmament conference to adopt a compromise version of the Soviet proposal for the complete demilitarization of the ocean floor.

Mrs. Edith Spizer did not have to be told by the Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday that prices were rising precipitously in New York. She could tell from the prices she was paying for food, medical care, cleaning, baby-sitting and just about everything else she buys.

LONDON, July 24 -- If anyone still has any doubt that Harold Pinter is the most important playwright of our time he should go to the Aldwych Theater in London -- any travel agent will provide the airline schedules, and any superior travel agent will have in hand the current repertory of the Royal Shakespeare Company in London -- and see the new Pinter double-bill of "Landscape" and "Silence."
The "Automatic" Sprinkler Corporation of America and Mid-Con, Inc., announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge Mid-Con into "Automatic" Sprinkler.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 25 -- Walter Fink, Commodore of the Midget Ocean Racing Club, who lives in Manhasset, L.I., took a boat named Kalkum (which translates to Turkey in Norwegian) that was so new that she never had been in competition until now. and became the only three-time winner of Larchmont Race Week today.

Consolidated Edison's decision to enlarge its Astoria plant violates an earlier pledge not to build any more fossil-fired electrical generating plants in the metropolitan area. Nevertheless it is the best available solution to the insatiable demands of the city for more and more power, which came so close to exhausting the utility's capacity last week.

MANILA, Saturday, July 26 -- President Nixon declared yesterday that the United States would not be enticed into future wars like the one in Vietnam and would redesign and reduce its military commitments throughout non-Communist Asia.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., July 25 -- Mrs. Sue Maxwell Berning of Lake Tahoe, Nev., took a stroke lead after the second round of the 15th annual Ladies Professional Golf Association 72-hole championship was completed today.
JERUSALEM, July 25 -- Israeli jets attacked Egyptian artillery positions along the Suez Canal today for the fourth time this week.
LONDON, July 25 -- Gerald Brooke said tonight that he had unwittingly smuggled into the Soviet Union material that had more to do with espionage than with anti-Soviet propaganda.

LONDON, July 25 -- Communist China has sent a commercial counselor to join its mission in London, and the Bank of China has begun quoting forward-exchange rates for Communist Chinese currency against sterling in an apparent effort to encourage British-Chinese trade.

LONDON, July 25 -- Do you recall the days when those J. Arthur Rank films were dismissed in America as being too English and too incomprehensible for American audiences? This phase seems over. The English accent, with all its regional diversities from Oxonian to Liverpudlian, now seems clear from sea to shining sea.
MANILA (UPI) -- Preparing for weekend guests presents difficulties for any hostess, but consider the problems facing the First Lady of the Philippines.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 25 -- Bill Mathis, a 30-year-old running back who intended to retire from pro football but not if "it leaves the team short," will rejoin the New York Jets next Wednesday.

BONN, July 25 -- The West German Government will probably ask the United States and other allies for an explanation of safeguards in connection with any chemical weapons stored here, the Government spokesman said today.
As a former director of the National Park Service, familiar with the Mineral King area of California for 54 years, I believe it important to clarify several points in your recent editorials.
AGANA, Guam, July 25 (UPI) -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon joined her husband on this Pacific outpost today for her initial taste of travel abroad as First Lady.
PARIS, July 25 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier of Laos, today rejected as "completely false" North Vietnam's charge that his country had been invaded by 12,000 United States troops.

ROWAYTON, Conn. -- Ask two youngsters at the Windward School which of its myriad activities they prefer and an argument is likely to ensue. Some opt for the scuba diving, others for the water-skiing and still more favor sailing. An occasional scientific type stands up for the marine biology and oceanography courses, and almost everyone agrees that lifesaving instruction, while necessary, is a bit of a drag.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y. -- The housewife who goes out of her mind waiting for the new sofa to be delivered should sympathize with Bernice J. Banks. She has the same problem -- but multiplied by 50 in a normal year.

Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, yesterday rejected the proposal of a special City Council committee that a panel of business, civic and public officials take over policy-making for the city's manpower agency.

Restlessness after a forced early retirement, plus determination that turned a mountain mule-track into a road, have made Alfred Rodriquez, a former General Dynamics executive, one of Mexico's newest silver-mining tycoons.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 25 -- Side by side, they stood there in silence. Punting practice was about to begin. Curley Johnson, the incumbent, was wearing his helmet, his usually mischievous face grim behind the gray protective bar. Steve O'Neal, a rookie from Texas A. and M. whom the New York Jets had drafted in the 13th round, appeared even more slender than he is. He had not put on shoulder pads.
Slumping stock prices exacted a heavy toll this week from the new-issue market, where shares of companies going public are underwritten and traded.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 25 -- An Island Park, L. I., publisher, one of five men indicted yesterday for the kidnapping and ransoming of a Long Island plastics executive two years ago, surrendered today to the Suffolk County District Attorney.

Seven airlines that were awarded new trans-Pacific air routes this week were gearing up yesterday to fly the new routes, but there was widespread uncertainty among airline executives over just how big a plum the lines had won.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation and its subsidiaries reported gains yesterday in operating revenues and net income for the three-month and 12-month periods ended June 30. The report placed June-quarter operating revenues at $137,401,980, against $129,918,637 a year earlier.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 25 -- A 51-year-old Larchmont commuter who refused to show his $1.01 ticket on a New Haven train pleaded not guilty today to a charge of theft of services and won the right to a jury trial.
Prices continued to drift in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

ALGIERS, July 25 -- The mood was grim today at the Black Panther party's unofficial Algiers headquarters after statements by the party's former Prime Minister, Stokely Carmichael, indicating that his differences with his other leaders were unresolved.

BONN, July 25 -- The Most Rev. Matthias Defregger, Auxiliary Bishop of Munich, who has been in seclusion since the disclosure of his part in wartime executions in Italy, has been discovered in an Austrian village, where he told a German reporter, "My nerves are shattered."

The International New Thought Alliance ended a week-long annual congress here yesterday. Its 2,000 delegates more than ever convinced, they said, that if the mind of man remains open to spiritual ideas, his power becomes limitless.
Fifty-two private, nonsectarian colleges were declared eligible yesterday for state aid without conditions. A state official said it was the first time in the nation that such grants had been made.

CLEVELAND, July 25 -- A 10-year-old dispute between the nation's railroads and unions over the elimination of firemen on diesel locomotive crews has again failed to be resolved; Charles Luna, president of the United Transportation Union, announced today.
ALBANY, July 25 (AP) -- New York's mental hygiene commissioner charged today that a grand jury report on illegal drug use and prostitution at Rockland State Hospital had distorted "the true picture."

INDIANAPOLIS, July 25 (AP) -- The top-seeded singles players in the National clay-court tennis championships, Arthur Ashe and Nancy Richey, dropped their first sets today and then rallied to score quarter-final round victories at the Woodstock Club.
ALBANY, July 25 -- The appointment of a new warden of Sing Sing Prison in Ossining, was announced today by the State Commission of Correction.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 25 (AP) -- Following is a stenographic transcript of the District Court proceedings today at which Senator Edward M. Kennedy pleaded guilty to a charge of leaving the scene of an auto accident in which a young secretary was killed:
To many of the 31,165 fans who attended the penultimate program of the Aqueduct meeting yesterday, the greatest excitement occurred in the running of the first two races.

WHITE PLAINS, July 25 -- Automobile accidents involving teen-aged drivers have increased sharply in the affluent New York suburban area during the last few years, alarming policemen, parents and often the young drivers themselves.

The young Cuban who fled to Spain in the wheel pod of a jet airliner last June 4, amazing doctors by surviving temperatures of 40 degrees below zero during the long flight, arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday as a regular passenger.
In your July 12 editorial "The Shoe That Doesn't Fit" you comment on my letter (published in an adjoining column) which was in turn aroused by your original editorial of July 2.
Governor Rockefeller is seriously considering asking for the dismissal of Frank Aikman Jr., the president of the embattled Long Island Rail Road.

The Aetna Life and Casualty Company reported yesterday that its premium income in the first half this year increased 12 per cent to $1.4-billion from a year before and net investment income climbed 9 per cent to $195-million.
MOSCOW, July 25 -- The Soviet Union disclosed figures tonight indicating that its economy had picked up momentum in recent months but was still lagging behind its planned annual growth rate.

The two men who Senator Edward M. Kennedy said last night had aided him during the night of Mary Jo Kopechne's death, before the police were notified the next day, are both lawyers and close political associates of the Senator.

It would seem a little late in the season to have a dinner dance in New York what with almost everybody out of town, but the Fresh Air Fund went ahead with its Evening of Elegance at the 79th Street Boat Basin last night, and nearly 200 guests showed up.
A package marked "live frogs and lizards" was ripped open accidentally in the General Post Office yesterday, and 50 snakes wriggled onto the floor.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 25 -- The family of a 20-year-old Negro soldier who was killed in Vietnam filed a suit in Federal Court today demanding that a whites-only private cemetery provide a burial spot for the youth.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., july 25 -- Traffic will be heavy on all roads leading to Fairfield University tomorrow but there will probably be better collisions on the football field.
SAN DIEGO, July 25 (AP) -- Elvin Hayes is getting a nice raise and he's buying a nice $86,000 house in fashionable La Jolla.
The Mets recaptured some of that midsummer magic last night when they scored three runs with two out in the eighth inning and defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 4-3.
Transit Authority detectives seized $10,000 worth of counterfeit tokens yesterday, about the same amount that they said was now being dropped into subway turnstiles in the city every week.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 -- A debate within the Brazilian Army over the responsibility of military officers for the Government they dominate has come to light obliquely here.
ONE of the phenomena of the bear market of 1969 is the strange absence of selling triggered by margin calls, an important factor in many past periods of plunging prices.

AKRON, Ohio, July 25 -- Jack Nicklaus set a scoring record today with a second consecutive 66 in the $125,000 American Golf Classic. The 29-year-old Ohioan completed the best two-round span he has played this year and shattered the tournament mark by two strokes with a 36-hole aggregate of 132.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Edward Moore Kennedy made his test oratorical flight during the Easter holiday in 1962. The Kennedy family had decided that he should run for the Senate seat formerly held by his brother.

The Seaboard Coast Line Railroad's management said yesterday it finally was realizing some of the economic benefits of the merger of the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard Air Line railroads on July 1, 1967.

S. Michael Nadel [letter July 14] criticizes Mayor Lindsay's "preoccupation with his image and so-called principle" and, in the process, implies that New York City is not governable by a man of principle. If that is true, the sad state of affairs is attributable to several decades of cronyism, nepotism, and special-interest strangle-holds within the city government, not to the deficiencies of the present administration.

WHITE PLAINS, July 25 -- Bill Furey, a versatile 17-year- old athlete, did not let the fact that he was playing the strong favorite disturb him today. He took a big lead early and defeated Don Jarvis, 2 and 1, for the Metropolitan junior golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Nixon Administration's bill to establish a commission on population growth was introduced in the Senate today by Senators Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, and John L. McClellan, Democrat of Arkansas.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senate colleagues of Edward M. Kennedy who could be reached for comment tonight expressed the hope that the Senator would not resign his Senate seat.
PARIS, July 25 -- As the monetary system moves into the era of Special Drawing Rights, three Swiss banks have fallen out over the risks of carrying large inventories of South African gold.
GSTAAD, Switzerland, July 25 (Reuters) -- Lea Pericoli of Italy upset Mrs. Billie Jean King of Long Beach, Calif. 6-3, 6-3, today in the quarter-finals of the Swiss open tennis championships.
CAIRO, July 25 -- The United Arab Republic Military Command reported that antiaircraft gunners had shot down three Israeli planes today during attacks on Egyptian positions along the Suez Canal.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 25 -- The governing Democratic Republican party, prompted by President Chung Hee Park's public endorsement and call for early action, began drafting a bill today for constitutional revision to allow him to seek a third term in 1971.

The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday began disciplining air traffic controllers who participated in a "sick strike" last month, but there was no sign when -- or if -- members of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization would fulfill their vow to resign en masse over the disciplinary action.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange took a sharp beating yesterday as the !ist declined for the fifth consecutive session.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Government filed suits today against restaurants in North and South Carolina, contending they refused to serve Negroes.

IN the introduction to this work, Lovat Dickson suggests that his study of H. G. Wells is a kind of holding action between the disproportioned "Experiment in Autobiography" and the full-scale life that Gordon N. Ray, the biographer of Thackeray, is preparing from the bulky archives at the University of Illinois.
The stock market took a key test yesterday and failed.

CPC International, Inc., formerly the Corn Products Company, introduced a new infant-feeding formula yesterday, called Duryea, for sale in developing countries. Test marketing began simultaneously in Cali, Colombia, by Maizena, S.A., a local affiliate.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 25 (Reuters) -- The United States has lost more than 5,500 aircraft in Vietnam since 1961 worth at least $3-bilion, the American military command said today.

MANILA, Saturday, July 26 -- In a burst of undiplomatic candor Foreign Minister Carlos P. Romulo has said of President Nixon's visit to Manila: "We know he is only coming because the Apollo 11 splashdown was in this area and if he did not come there would be a hue and cry."
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Mayor Lindsay urged a Senate subcommittee today to liberalize the major cost limitations proposed by the Nixon Administration for Federally assisted housing.

The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it was raising prices, effective Monday, for its line of underground distribution power cables. The rise is 8 per cent. Alcoa's aluminum conductor products division introduced its underground distribution cable in May.

ALGIERS, July 25 -- American economic ties to Algeria, a counterweight to the vast Soviet presence here, were strengthened this week with the announcement of plans to export large quantities of Algerian natural gas to the United States.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., July 25 (AP) -- Three men were being held in Hunterdon County Jail today in connection with the rape and torture of a 19-year-old girl in a motel in nearby Bridgewater Township.

"Think about sex -- and smile," the Mighty Sparrow urged the members of his orchestra last night at Madison Square Garden where he took part in "Calypso Spectacular." This appeared to be the Sparrow's approach to his songs although one got this more from an interpretation of his gestures than from the lyrics of his songs because the abysmal acoustics and amplification of the Garden made most of his words unintelligible.

ROME, July 25 -- The Italian Premier - designate, Mariano Rumor, reached tonight what appeared to be a dead end in his efforts to form a center-left governing alliance between his Christian Democratic party and two warring Socialist factions.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The average wage and benefit settlement negotiated by organized labor in the first half of this year provided increases of slightly more than 7 per cent, the Labor Department reported today.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Dr. Francis L. Land resigned as chief of Medicaid today, an apparent early victim of the Administration's pledge to reform the program of health care for the poor.
Grain futures moved sharply lower yesterday in a finale to a week that saw little resistance to selling pressure.

READING, Pa., July 25 -- Pete Retzlaff's first major move as general manager of the Philadelphia Eagles was to trade the best offensive tackle in football, Bob Brown, to the Los Angeles Rams. DETROIT, July 25 (AP) -- The annual shutdown for model changeover reduced automobile production this week to 56,516 units, the trade publication Automotive News reported today.

GENEVA, July 25 -- C. Clyde Ferguson Jr., President Nixon's special representative for Nigeria and Biafra relief, conferred today with representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross, the World Council of Churches, and the United Nations Children's Fund about the possibility of resuming relief shipments to Biafra.

BERLIN, July 25 -- The East German Communists stressed today their interest in a European security conference, maintaining that Walter Ulbricht, the party leader, demanded no prerequisites or special conditions for such talks.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The opposition to the proposed Safeguard antiballistic missile system, on the defensive for the last week, believes it is about to recapture the initiative by picking up the vote of Thomas J. McIntyre, one of the uncommitted Senators.

ABOARD U.S.S. HORNET, in the Pacific, July 25 -- The Apollo 11 astronauts have passed their preliminary medical examinations and are relaxing in a quarantine trailer aboard this carrier. The three-man crew of the lunar mission will arrive in Pearl Harbor tomorrow for a plane ride to Houston.

LONDON, July 25 -- The British government has announced a plan to limit casino-style gambling clubs to 31 cities and towns of England, Scotland and Wales. It was received today with a mixture of criticism and praise.
Columbia University announced yesterday the election of five trustees, including two Negroes, the first of their race to serve on the board of the 215-year-old university.

TRENTON, July 25 (AP) -- Two top administrators at Trenton State College have been demoted because of their role in a faculty demand that Dr. Robert Heussier be removed as president of the college.
MOSCOW, July 25 -- The Soviet authorities, faced with a constantly increasing number of older people, are planning new housing complexes for aging citizens who are able to pay rent.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House Ways and Means Committee disclosed today the tentative adoption of additional changes in the tax law that would close tax-escape routes used mainly by the wealthy.

HOUSTON, July 25 -- James W. Williams, the former chairman of the Westec Corporation who is under sentence of 15 years in a Federal prison for conspiracy and mail fraud, has been indicted by a grand jury here for stock fraud.

All of our repertory companies, even the most conservative, are in a sense experimental; and one of the most promising of these experiments in repertory is being conducted by the American Conservatory Theater, which is now finishing up its third season as San Francisco's resident company.

MADRID -- In naming Prince Juan Carlos de Borbon y Borbon last week his successor as Chief of State, Generalissimo Francisco Franco ended one of the oldest political guessing games in Spain: After Franco, what? But, at the same time he launched a new one: After Franco how?

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- A Chicago physician. convicted of evading his Federal income taxes, was ordered yesterday to pay $565,000 in taxes, penalties and interest, and to spend half his work time for six months working in a public institution without charge.

To the Editor: The recent passage of the so-called "truth-in-lending law" has been hailed by some as a milestone in the protection of America's victimized consumers. Unfortunately, the law is being diverted from its intended purposes.
To the Editor: It seems to me that the cost of health services could be dramatically reduced by tax exemptions.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 26 -- Despite many weeks of heated debate in Washington over the Administration's antiballistic missile program, a majority of Americans (58 per cent) are either unaware of the program or have not made up their minds about it, according to the Gallup Poll.

WASHINGTON -- Twenty-four Army men on Okinawa, who recently got a whiff of deadly nerve gas while refurbishing a weapon, recovered and were back on the job within six hours. But the effect of the potentially tragic incident on the American body politic clearly will be much longer-lasting, giving impetus to a basic reappraisal of the nation's entire chemical - biological weapons policy.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Witnesses at Congressional hearings this week on airport and airways improvement agreed that improvements were urgently needed but differed on funding arrangements.

FLORENCE, Italy -- Because of the disastrous flood that swept through Florence in November, 1966, tourists, if they want to see both the city's newest ancient sights and all the long-familiar ones, must spend more time here now than in the past.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Organization of American States sought a face-saving formula today to compel the withdrawal of El Salvador's occupation troops from Honduras and preserve the integrity of the hemisphere organization.

NEW DELHI -- When Prime Minister Indira Gandhi went before the Indian Parliament last Monday to explain her nationalization of the country's 14 largest private banks, executed in a sudden stroke two days earlier, she was loudly applauded not only by her own ruling Congress party but by the leftists in Parliament as well.

WASHINGTON -- To the astonishment of skeptics, a tax reform bill that would meet almost anybody's definition of "meaningful" is emerging from the House Ways and Means Committee.

They contend it will save 20,000 of them double fares they now pay daily to take buses to the subway. That is indeed a gain, but it is a gain at the expense of vastly greater numbers of Brooklyn, Bronx and upper Manhattan residents.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Six years ago yesterday, Ivan Allen Jr., a businessman who had been elected Mayor of Atlanta in 1961, appeared before the Senate Commerce Committee to testify on the public accommodations section of President Kennedy's civil rights bill.

It shared the evening at the Wollman Rink with Carlos Montoya, the flamenco guitarist.

AKRON, Ohio July 27 -- Ray Floyd jogged down the fairways between shots today as though he were working out with the Chicago Cubs, which he often does when he's off the golf tour. But today he hurried to score a 65 for a tournament record 72-hole aggregate of 268 and won the American Golf Classic by four strokes.

The use of checking accounts at the nation's banks increased sharply during June, the Federal Reserve Board reported over the weekend. The Penn Central company named Charles A. Goodwin to coordinate commuter service on its Hudson, Harlem and New Haven-divisions with the title of director of suburban service. The post is a new one.

PORTLAND, Me., July 27 -- The physical assets of the bankrupt Cushman Baking Company and its subsidiary, the Cushman Bakery, have been ordered sold to the International Fastener Research Corporation of Los Angeles. ROME, July 27 -- A committee of international and Italian experts has called on Italy to produce an over-all plan before the end of next year to save the city of Venice.
