MARYVILLE, Tenn., July 27 (AP) -- Richard Petty of Randleman, N. C., won his second stock-car race in 18 hours today, driving a 1969 Ford to victory in the Smoky 200.
PITTSBURGH, July 27 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente hit four straight singles today, driving in one run, and he scored twice as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the San Diego Padres, 4-1.

LONDON, July 27 -- John A. Cumber, acting commissioner in Anguilla since April, when he took over from Anthony Lee, is leaving the islands for personal reasons, the Foreign Office announced here on Friday.

JAKARTA, July 27 (UPI) -President Nixon said today that he would send pieces of the moon to the world's chiefs of state after the lunar rocks collected by the Apollo 11 astronauts had been studied scientifically.

John Laino (letter July 1) states that legalized abortion would deprive people of the opportunity of raising and learning about children. In the first place, legalized abortion would in no way deter those who are mentally and emotionally capable of loving and understanding children.
Even his closest friends call Inspector Arthur B. Hill a "street hoodlum who went straight." But they say it with affection and with admiration.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., July 27 -- A United States Marine Corps corporal died today from injuries received last Sunday night in a racial fight at Camp Lejeune, a Marine base in southeastern North Carolina.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 27 -- "I think that it's 10 years too late, but better late than never," says Joseph Fersh, chairman of the Sullivan County National Bank.

Leonard Sillman has ended his search for a theater to house his forthcoming production of "The American Hamburger League," the new comedy by Norman Kline. The New Theater at 154 East 54th Street will receive the play on Sept. 16.
BALTIMORE, July 27 (UPI) -- Frank Robinson smashed two home runs and Boog Powell and Jim Hardin one apiece as the Baltimore Orioles buried the Chicago White Sox, 17-0, today.
The credit markets, suffering under the twin burdens of a restrictive Federal Reserve policy and Congressional proposals to reform taxes, are moving into a decisive week.

ATHENS, July 27 -- All movies shown at film festivals in Greece now must be compatible with the religious beliefs and traditions of the Greek people, as well as with "public order and national security."

Having disdained hot dogs and having scrounged for soup bones from her butcher for a week, Mrs. Jonathan B. Bingham told yesterday how she barely managed to stay within a welfare-level food budget of 66 cents a day for each person.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., a large investment-banking house, yesterday announced major executive appointments. Ernest B. Kelly Jr., president and chief executive officer, said the changes reflected in part the recent retirement of Walter L. Darfler as chairman.

Axel Axelsson Johnson of Stockholm is interested in potato farming in Brazil and fast freighters all over the world. The 58-year-old head of an industrial dynasty that owns the Johnson Line and 25 other companies is involved in all forms of transportation, even horses.

FOR the last year, Walter Lincoln Schlager Jr. has been struggling to find enough time out from his job of keeping the city's subways and buses running to unpack his HO-gauge model railroad at his new Manhasset, L. I., home.

State Senator A. Frederick Meyerson, who was stabbed in the back 11 days ago when he tried to aid a policeman under attack, expressed praise for the police yesterday at a ceremony marking the extension of the fourth platoon to West Brooklyn.
The Police Department yesterday continued its investigation into the theft of $500,000 worth of gems and settings from the Jewelry Unlimited Manufacturing Company, 64 West 36th Street.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 28 -- The Coast Guard said today that patches of oil had washed ashore at beaches in New Jersey resort communities from Barnegat to Ocean City and as far south as Wildwood.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 -- After five months devoted mostly to his favorite pastimes of mah-jongg and cockfighting, Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky was back in the headlines last week.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 27 -- If a prize were to be awarded for the most productive major dance company in the world, there could be little doubt of the winner. It would be the Netherlands Dance Theater, which, year in year out, maintains the awesome average of nine new ballets a year.
The American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes won a representation election yesterday among the 6,920 employes in New York State's security services.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A Government report described today new evidence that cigarette smoking was bad for the heart, the lungs, the mouth and the unborn babies of expectant mothers who smoke.

BY THIS time Gene Sarazen should be quite expert at accepting trophies, plaques and awards of various descriptions. The stocky little guy in the anachronistic plus-fours has been a towering figure in his sport over the better part of the last half century and at golfdom's elaborate Cancer Fund dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria tonight he will be paid tribute for his long and meritorious service to the game. He rates it.

New York Telephone Company officials said yesterday that despite a massive expansion program and the recruitment of a 1,500-man rescue force, there was no immediate relief in sight from the troubles that have been plaguing telephone service here.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 28 -The New York Jets traded Jeff Richardson, an offensive lineman, to the Cincinnati Bengals today for an undisclosed 1970 draft choice, believed to be the No. 5 selection.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 28 -- Multicolored beach umbrellas were as plentiful as oldtime great baseball players today as Roy Campanella, Stan Musial, Waite Hoyt and Stanley Coveleski were inducted into the Hall of Fame.

Tax and price increases have made recent collective bargaining advances "a treadmill to nowhere" for factory workers in the metropolitan area suburbs, according to a labor union study made public yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the best way to make sure the United States was not the victim of chemical or biological weapons was to maintain its own such weapons as a deterrent.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 28 -- A hawker waiting for the Pony Express to arrive from Penn Station today smiled in anticipation of how many tout sheets he would sell to "the New York bettors who are always the best, the biggest spenders in the country."
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Treasury bill rates at today's $2.7-billion auction of three-month and six-month securities declined from last week's levels, the Government reported late today.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 28 -- Everybody on the Giant defensive platoon has a new system to learn this year but nobody must learn it faster or better than Henry Davis. He's the man in the middle.

A Queens couple that has asked the State Supreme Court to restore to its custody a little girl it wants to adopt has no right to make such a request, it was argued yesterday by attorneys for the New York Foundling Hospital.

SEATTLE, July 28 -- Nixon Administration officials today pledged increased financial aid to the states and appealed for a strong stand by Western Governors against any institutional cutoff of Federal aid as a penalty for college campus violence.

Suffolk County, which is gradually modernizing its governmental machinery to keep pace with its explosive growth in population, has been urged by its Charter Revision Commission to abolish the "two-hat" evil. This is the system, common to many counties throughout the state, under which local mayors or supervisors combine executive and legislative functions.

The nation's airlines are seeking to work out an agreement to cut down voluntarily their flights at New York, Chicago and Washington if air traffic controllers walk off their jobs in large numbers. However, industry sources said yesterday, agreement on the plan is lagging because of the opposition from some airlines.

CHICAGO, July 28 (UPI) -Leo Durocher, the Chicago Cubs' manager, is expected to meet tomorrow with the club's owner, Philip K. Wrigley, to discuss his weekend trip to Eagle River, Wis., which left the team without a manager in the midst of its drive for a pennant.
ROME, July 28 -- A member of the papacy's elite corps of Swiss Guards deserted over three months ago and has disappeared without a trace, officials in Vatican City confirmed today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 28 (AP) -- A commercial communications satellite that had been missing in space for more than two days was found today in the wrong orbit.
SOME housewives are reluctant to cook the fish their husbands bring home.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 28 -- A special session of the Legislature was urged by the Democratic chairman of seven counties today to restore cuts made in state aid to school districts.
Alfred M. Lerner, the 37-year-old president of the First Hanover Corporation, a brokerage-firm member of the New York and American Stock Exchanges, was indicted yester day on fraud charges.

Frank Loesser, the composerlyricist who gave the Broadway stage "Guys and Dolls," "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," and "Where's Charley?," died of lung cancer yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital He was 59 years old.

A pilot program in which a single judge will take a case from inception to completion will begin Oct. 1 in Federal Court in the Southern District of New York, Chief Judge Sidney Sugarman announced yesterday.

Following are highlights of President Nixon's itinerary for today and tomorrow on his round-the-world trip, with a summary of the subsequent days' activities (times are local, with New York time in parentheses):
ACCRA, Ghana, July 22 -- In little more than a month, on Aug. 29, Ghana will elect a Parliament.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey issued a statement today in which he urged Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts not to resign from the Senate, "where he has served so ably."
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 28 (Reuters) -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, said today France had assured him that she would help maintain the neutrality of Laos.

An appropriation bill, providing funds for the Departments of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare for the current fiscal year, scheduled for consideration by the House of Representatives on July 29, contains a section which clearly imperils the freedom of higher education and should be removed.
JERUSALEM, July 28 -- Israeli jet fighters resumed their attacks on Egyptian positions along the Suez Canal today. It was the sixth raid since Israel's air arm was given a new role eight days ago.
PARIS, July 28 -- The United States applied today for six world records in manned flight to the moon.

The Pepsi-Cola Company and the civil rights group known as Operation Breadbasket have signed an agreement that the leaders of Operation Breadbasket said would bring more than $8-million into the black community here within the next year.
Because of the many choices it left to man, who all the way through made the wrong ones, the Titanic disaster of 1912 is the most completely clean-cut Greek tragedy of our modern times.
Earnings of the Boeing Company in the second quarter plunged to $8,373,000, or 38 cents a share, from $23,105,000 or $1.07 a share, in the 1968 period. T. A. Wilson, president, reported yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 28 -- Johnny Famechon of Australia retained a share of the world featherweight boxing championship tonight with a narrow victory over Masahiko (Fighting) Harada of Japan in 15 rounds.
Federal agents have arrested a New Jersey hairdresser on charges of smuggling from France large quantities of heroin hidden in hollow fiberglass ski poles.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28 -- The composer sat in a small cluttered sound room here this weekend, smiling broadly and listening to a playback of the song he had just recorded.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., July 28 -- The commanding officer of the Second Marine Division said today that there were "indications" but "no tangible evidence" that Negro marines involved in a racial flare-up here a week ago were members of the Black Panther party.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 -- Secretary General Thant made known today that he "has no intention of resigning and is planning to serve the remainder of his term," which runs to the end of 1971.
CAIRO, July 28 -- Premier Abubakr Awadallah of the Sudan charged here today that the United States was striving to "sabotage" his Government.
Heavy rains, fierce winds and floods beset portions of the Northeast yesterday, and Weather Bureau forecasters held out little hope for a swift end to the poor weather.
You should be commended for your July 23 editorial "Closing the Depletion Loophole."
BONN, July 28 -- West Germany and Yugoslavia signed two far-reaching cultural exchange agreements today providing for more East-West contacts than Bonn has with any other Communist country.
ECL Industries, Inc., and the Chicago Musical Instrument Company announced yesterday that they had agreed on financial terms to combine their businesses.
Thomas Eboli, the 59-year-old reputed heir to the Mafia's richest racket empire, was listed in serious condition yesterday, suffering from his third apparent heart attack this year.

NEW HAVEN, July 28 -- Elinor Kaine, a football writer, obtained a court injunction today to force her admission into the Yale Bowl press box to cover the exhibition game between the New York Jets and the New York Giants on Aug. 17.
The International Business Machines Corporation finally will take its long-awaited big step into the small computer field.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 28 -- Following are statements made by President Nixon shortly after his arrival in Bangkok today. The first is an excerpt from extemporaneous remarks made by the President as he accepted a key to the city. The second is the text of a statement prepared by the traveling White House on the flight to Thailand and distributed here in the President's name.
LIMA, Peru, July 28 (AP) -- President Juan Velasco Alvarado denied tonight that he would declare Peru a Socialist country, but he reiterated that his was a "revolutionary" regime.

The special City Council committee that studied the Human Resources Administration was accused by four of its members yesterday of having failed to investigate welfare abuses that allegedly cost $300million to $400-million a year.

HOUSTON, July 28 -- Neil E. Armstrong and Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. today suggested one disadvantage of the ease of movement they experienced in the moon's low-gravity environment. It could promote muscular laziness.

A bench warrant for the arrest of James H. Meredith was issued by a Bronx Criminal Court judge yesterday, the second day on which the civil rights activist had failed to appear for sentencing in a housing case.

JERUSALEM, July 28 -- Priceless treasures carried to the Holy Land by Armenian pilgrims for the last thousand years and now on display to the public for the first time are attracting huge crowds in Jerusalem.
NOW that the Big Board has given a green light to public stock offerings by the exchange's member firms, a flood of brokerage-house new issues will hit the market. Or will it?

The Dodge index of nationwide construction contract value in June declined 14 per cent from the record 210 established in May, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
HONG KONG, July 28 -- Peking launched a strong attack against President Nixon today, denouncing his visit to Asia as a "trip for conducting aggressive activities."
TOKYO, July 28 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers arrived here tonight to head the American delegation in the annual cabinet-level talks with members of the Japanese Government.

ATHENS, July 28 -- The car of the United States Army attache and seven other American-owned autos were damaged by bombs in the Athens area early today in an anti-American sabotage drive believed to be waged by opponents of Greece's army-backed regime.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today that a sufficient number of countries had ratified the new plan for Special Drawing Rights, or "paper gold," to put the idea legally into effect.

BERLIN, West Germany, July 28 -- The three Western allies have ruled out the use of West Berlin as a haven for West German Army deserters, but they have intervened in favor of German draft dodgers who also sought refuge in the Western outpost, officials said today.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Following are excerpts from the statement on firearms and violence issued today by the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence:
HOUSTON, July 28 -- A dozen geologists gave the first broad interpretation of the moon's surface composition today, saying it was a good deal different from that of earth, but not "unearthly."

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Treasury collected $2.2billion more than it thought it would in personal income taxes alone in the fiscal year just ended and wound up with a surplus of $3.1-billion in the budget.

THE only policemen I ever got to know personally were the heroic troops of Chicago during the 1968 Democratic Convention. Until then, my idea of policemen was strictly literary: a jumble of Simenon and Nicholas Freeling, of the urbane and the grotesque who would appear periodically to roil the waters of reflection in an Eric Ambler thriller.

Registration for half-fare transit passes will continue on a year-round basis to make them available to some 200,000 older citizens here who have not yet registered, as well as to the 8,000 residents who turn 65 each month.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Tuesday, July 29 -- President Nixon, apparently eager to diminish the fears of an apprehensive Asian ally, said yesterday that the "United States will stand proudly with Thailand against those who might threaten it from abroad or from within."

KAMPALA, Uganda, July 28 -- More than 40 Roman Catholic bishops and archbishops -- including all seven African cardinals -- gathered today in this verdant East African hill town for the church's first pan-African conference.
WHEN a woman chooses a book on child rearing, she is not so much looking for guidance as for justification for her opinions, according to a sociologist at the University of Pennsylvania.

Two men accused of holding up two garages belonging to Mister Softee and of crippling 39 of the ice cream company's trucks pleaded innocent in Bronx Supreme Court yesterday to a five-count indictment handed up by a Bronx County grand jury.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 27 -- "There will be no color bar in South African tennis," Alf Chalmers, the president of the South African Lawn Tennis Association, said today. "And that means in the selection of South African players for the Davis Cup squad and in foreign teams participating in matches in this country."
The first tentative signs of a drop in the cost of short-term borrowing are starting to appear in the money markets.

One cost which Tom Wicker did not include in his discussion [July 20] of the Vermont Yankee nuclear plant at Vernon is the high emotional cost that many Vermont residents continue to pay for an educated fear that neither industry nor taxpayers can or will "redeem our environment from our technology," the fear that thermal and nuclear contamination will destroy yet another beauty spot in a rapidly deteriorating American landscape.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -The Federal Government has watched without interference while many people sickened and some died in an extended series of drug tests and blood plasma projects.

Never judge a book by its cover, runs the adage. It is an adage whose current aptness has been illustrated by "Flashman: From the Flashman Papers 1839-42," recently published by the World Publishing Company.
A delegation of American aviation leaders was en route last night to the Soviet Union to inspect its 1,550-mile-an-hour TU-144 supersonic airliner.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 (Reuters) -- Huynh Van Trong, a top adviser to President Nguyen Van Thieu, has been questioned by the police about reports that he had unauthorized contacts with the National Liberation Front -- the Vietcong -- a Government spokesman said today.
MOSCOW, July 28 -- A Soviet conservation official said today that the spread of water pollution had been halted in the Soviet Union.
The Long Island Rail Road changed presidents yesterday in the face of rising complaints from commuters and politicians about its laggard service.
A dictionary should be an embarrassment of riches, not a richness of embarrassments, but nowadays it is a little of both.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Air Force is insisting on major revisions in a contract with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for the controversial C-5A jet transport plane.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 28 (AP) -- Letters by the thousands poured into Hyannis Port today. With them could lie the political future of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

DR. KALMAN APFEL and Murray Schnee of New York, Emmett Pollenz of East Meadow, L. I., and Abe Schoenfeld of Hicksville, L. I., captured the Open Team Championship that concluded the Greater New York Bridge Association's Brooklyn Championships at the New York Hilton Sunday.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 -- Copper deposits in the territory of New Guinea will be developed under a complex $246.4-million "venture banking" agreement signed today.
The Alcan cable division of the Alcan Aluminum Corporation announced yesterday price increases for bare aluminum conductors and for aluminum underground distribution power cables.

In the biggest account switch in at least a year, Miles Laboratories has moved Alka-Seltzer which bills $18- million to $20-million a year, from Jack Tinker Partners (one of the Interpublic Group of Companies) to Doyle Dane Bernbach.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The "leading indicators" of business activity in the second quarter continued to signal further growth in the economy rather than a slowing down, the Department of Commerce disclosed today.
ALBANY, July 28 -- Boys may let their hair grow long, and girls may wear slacks to school under a ruling today by the Acting State Education Commissioner.
Maria Callas, the opera star, currently making her first movie in a nonsinging part. She is playing the title role in an Italian production of "Medea."
SEATTLE, July 28 -- Western Governors were divided today over the political future of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

BOSTON, July 28 -- The Boston Globe, in a copyrighted article appearing in tomorrow's editions, reports that 84 per cent of those voters polled in Massachusetts approve of the conduct of Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
Mayor Lindsay was endorsed yesterday by a Brooklyn Democratic Assemblyman who said that he had first offered to endorse Controller Mario A. Procaccino, the Democratic mayoral candidate.
LONDON, July 28 -- The reports from Johannesburg that there would be no color bar in South Africa's Davis Cup tennis were welcomed cautiously by British tennis circles today.
PASADENA, Calif., July 28 (AP) -- Mariner 6 snapped its first pictures of Mars tonight. Flight controllers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory said the camera seemed to be working well.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -If the nation is to transcend its history of domestic violence, the Federal Government and the states must act to confiscate 90 per cent of the estimated total of 24 million handguns owned by private citizens, the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence declared today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 An international agreement signed today set in motion the preliminary steps that may make it possible for the first time to communicate regularly and predictably from one Latin-American country to another.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- A Harvard psychiatrist proposed today that a national policy be established to end what he called the virtual peonage of farm labor migrants, including Government income subsidies, so they could settle down and not be constantly moving.
MONTREAL, July 28 (UPI) -- Tommy Aaron scored his first professional golf tournament victory today when he beat Sam Snead by two strokes in an 18-hole playoff of the Canadian open.

MUNICH, West Germany July 28 (AP -- A spokesman for the Munich archdiocese announced today that the West German auxiliary bishop who passed on an order to shoot Italian hostages when he was a German Army captain in World War II is expected to appear at a news conference here this week.
PARIS, July 28 -- The world can stop holding its breath. There are lots of long skirts in the maxi-ish new Yves Saint Laurent collection today, but he still gives his fans a big choice.

The Parks Department announced yesterday that, granted fair weather, it would have its spray trucks out today in the Sheepshead Bay area of Brooklyn, where a heavy infestation of hairy caterpillars has caused rashes on children and adults.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A House subcommittee charged today that the North Koreans' capture of the intelligence ship Pueblo and their shooting down of an EC-121 reconnaissance plane showed that the United States' ability to react to national emergencies was imperiled by "serious deficiencies" in the military command structure.
Stock prices continued in a headlong plunge yesterday as the market registered its broadest decline of the year.
CAIRO, July 28 -- A sudden increase in births has sharpened concern over population pressures and a lagging birth-control program in the United Arab Republic.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 28 -- President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, who rules Pakistan under martial law, promised today that he would restore democracy. In keeping with that commitment, he loosened restrictions on political activity and named a commissioner to take on the task of preparing for national elections.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to slip yesterday, as indexes reached new lows for the year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28 -- An out-of-court settlement was reached today in the trial of 34 Ohio State University students indicted by a Franklin County grand jury following a rake-over of the university administration building in April of 1968.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Congress, which has fretted all year about the conduct of college students, has been overrun this summer with college students fretting about the conduct of Congress.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 28 -- A steady drizzle today kept the attendance down to 14,924 for the opening day's activities of the annual Saratoga meeting. But the mud track was exactly to the liking of George D. Widener's Pontifex in the $29,000 Flash Stakes, the event that served as the feature on the program.
A second company of "Oh! Calcutta!", the Off Broadway hit, will begin an indefinite run at the On Broadway Theater in San Francisco on Sept. 23.

American Brands, Inc., formerly the American Tobacco Company, reported yesterday higher sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30, reflecting its diversification into non-tobacco fields, such as food and distilled beverages.

YPSILANTI, Mich., July 28 (AP) -- Eastern Michigan University announced today that 540 girls housed for the summer session in dormitories would now be required to sign out and sign in. Heretofore only freshmen women had a curfew.

The Penn Central Company reported yesterday that consolidated net income fell to $21,850,000, or 91 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30. Its railroad company operations showed a loss of $8,225,000 in the quarter.

Between 40 and 60 per cent of the high-rise office buildings going up in New York City have some of their structural steel shipped from abroad. The percentage may drop in the next few months, but the drop will be only temporary.
Abraham D. Beame said yesterday that he would run for election as City Controller on his own record rather than on that of his running mate, Mario A. Procaccino, the Democratic candidate for Mayor.

WESTHAMPTON, L. I., July: 28 -- The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual race week championship regatta got under way today under the threat of squalls. While the foul weather failed to materialize, the threats did have an adverse effect on the size of the fleet, with only 122 assorted craft taking the starting guns.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- The head of one of the largest industrial enterprises in Leningrad has complained that the emphasis in Soviet society on getting a higher education has made it extremely difficult to lure young people into blue-collar work.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey said today he was giving "serious consideration" to running next year for the Senate seat that Eugene J. McCarthy had announced he would leave vacant.

One baffling aspect of the tragic Arab-Israel clash is the complete absence of a dissenting voice within the Arab world. It is incredible that no report emanates of any group, even a tiny handful, disavowing Arab leadership and its implacable hostility to the existence of the State of Israel.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 28 -- Up in the laundry room on the 13th floor of the Tower C dormitory at Hofstra University today, Leo Accardo, the New York Jets' barber, was finishing a haircut on Dave Herman while his next customer, Joe Namath, slouched nearby in green cotton bellbottom pants.
Wheat futures declined as much as 6 cents a bushel yesterday, one of the sharpest drops in recent memory. Each month set new life-of-contract lows.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 28 -- The only development today in the events involving Senator Kennedy's fatal automobile accident was the information that the Senator's cousin, Joseph F. Gargan, rented a 1969 white Valiant automobile on Friday, July 18.

MADRID, July 28 -- Prince Javier of Bourbon, leader of Spain's disinherited Carlists, who lives in Austria, today issued a resounding denunciation of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's decision to name Prince Juan Carlos as heir to the throne.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to impose a heavier tax than it had previously considered on charitable foundations, which are now tax-exempt.
Excavation was begun yesterday to prepare the foundations for a 23-story office building that will be erected in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn, adjoining the Civic Center.
GREENPORT, L. I. -- The National Cash Register Company would be happy to buy back a refurbished, workable, circa 1900 cash register with ornate brass grillwork and carrying a name plate "Preston's."

SOUTH ORANGE, N, J., July 28 -- The 43d annual Eastern grass-court tennis championships started today with a limited number of matches on indoor courts because of intermittent heavy showers. For the first time the event is putting up a $20,000 purse.

PRAGUE, July 28 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party announced today a purge in the district committee of central Prague, accusing the committee's leaders of "rightist opportunism" and "unhealthy involvement'' in liberal causes.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The executive director of the National Urban League criticized the Nixon Administration today for not "moving forward" on domestic issues.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Two leading processors of baby foods today disputed statements that seasonings in their products are potentially harmful to infants.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A dispute over some secret Pentagon reports, described as critical of the Administration's Safeguard system, blocked attempts today to bring the Senate to a vote on the antiballistic missile issue.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 28 -Roy White, who had to attend a weekend Army Reserve meeting in New York, is scheduled to rejoin the Yankees for tomorrow's opening game of a three-game series against the Oakland Athletics, and Tom Shopay may have to wait a while to fatten his .125 batting average.

In a letter published July 21 J. Hermann questioned the use of the term "qualified" as applied to beginning office workers, stenographers and typists who were unable to pass current tests containing reading comprehension and vocabulary questions.
The American Stock Exchange took its worst beating in three years yesterday as the list declined sharply in heavier trading.
CHICAGO, July 28 (UPI) -Billy Williams drove in Don Kessinger with two out in the 10th inning and gave the Chicago Cubs a 4-3 victory over Juan Marichal and the San Francisco Giants today.
" We Reach the Moon," a 416-page account of America's efforts to reach the lunar surface, was published by Bantam Books and The New York Times yesterday, 76 hours after the splashdown of Apollo 11.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 28 (AP) -- United States troops backed by tanks and helicopters smashed through hedgerows and bunkers near Saigon today and fought the enemy in one of the heaviest clashes since the battlefield lull began six weeks ago.

The captain of the tanker that struck and sunk a fishing party boat off Long Branch, N. J., on July 13 denied a charge yesterday that his vessel made no effort to pick up the 47 survivors for more than two hours after the accident, in which a fisherman was reported missing.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 29 -- A three-judge Federal court decision yesterday held that Indiana's legislative districts were unconstitutional because of discrimination against racial minorities in urban areas.
LAGOS, Nigeria, July 29 (AP) -- Nigeria's Official radio rejected today a Biafran proposal that a truce in the two-year civil war be declared in honor of Pope Paul's visit to Africa.
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 29 -- When Paul Cardinal Zoungrana spoke to his fellow Roman Catholic bishops from all over Africa yesterday, he displayed his usual distaste for platitudes.

IT seems unlikely that Sam Posey could thrive in a world free of care. He is way ahead in the competition for this year's Sisyphus Cup, with most of his exercises in futility concentrated in the Continental series (not all -- last month at Le Mans his co-driver wiped out a good Ferrari).

Help-wanted advertising in June fell for the third consecutive month, the National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday. The index last month came to 209 per cent of the 1957-1959 average, 8 points below May, although still 20 points above the June, 1968, level.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 29 -- Midget, who once won five championships in the space of one week, captured her second title in 48 hours today when she won the small pony hunter crown at the Orange County horse show.

Eight supplemental airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to make charter flights available to "millions" more Americans by amending its regulations. The request was expected to draw opposition from the scheduled airlines.
LISBON, July 29 -- Portuguese Roman Catholics expect the visit of Pope Paul VI to Africa this week to focus attention on the problems of the church in Portuguese Africa.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Two large Middle Western railroads urged the Interstate Commerce Commission today to approve their merger into a 22,000-mile rail complex.

Reflecting the highest sales of any quarter or half year in its history, earnings of Borden, Inc., advanced over the year-earlier periods, Augustine R. Marusi, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 29 -- Reggie Jackson, the major league's home run leader, hit his 40th homer of the season tonight to lead the Oakland Athletics to a 6-5 victory over the New York Yankees in the first game of a three-game series.
Our magnificent achievements in space should not permit us to forget that there is still no viable international law governing liability for injuries and damage caused by space activities.

NEWARK, July 29 -- An Essex County grand jury presentment charged today that a Federal antipoverty program had been used as "a vehicle of political influence" by Newark city officials, including Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio.

SHELTER ISLAND, N. Y., July 29 -- M. Stuart Roesler's 45-foot sloop, Amber, out of Indian Harbor Yacht Club, Greenwich, Conn., won the first of four daily squadron runs today as the American Yacht Club fleet raced 16 miles from Fishers Island to Dering Harbor.
LONDON, July 29 -- Anatoly V. Kuznetsov, a liberal Soviet writer recently criticized in Moscow, was reported missing from his hotel in London today.

THE coronation ceremonies had ended. Organized baseball had just conferred exalted status on some of its minions, ennobling them with designations of "greatest." Although it happened a week ago in Washington during the beautifully conceived centennial celebration, some of the more memorable moments still linger with a vivid freshness.
An Indian girl from California and an Eskimo boy from Alaska are coming to New York next month to study art at Cooper Union, under the first arrangement to bring such students here.
BOSTON, July 29 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy faces an early test of his ability to maintain leadership in Massachusetts politics in a special primary in the Sixth Congressional District next month.

The Administration is still fighting hard to push through the extension of the income-tax surcharge without substantive tax reforms. It unwisely rejected a Senate compromise which would have extended the surtax through November while work on closing loopholes in the revenue code proceeded. Now President Nixon's projected intervention may be too late to induce Congress even to continue the current income-tax withholding rates when their temporary extension expires tomorrow at midnight.

A hearing will be held this afternoon in Federal District Court here on a $10-million damage suit filed Monday by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., to block Kirk Kerkorian's tender offer for 17 per cent of M-G-M's stock.

WHITE PLAINS, July 29 -- Westchester Democrats suggested tonight that the county build a $34-million network of incinerators to take care of the 3,500 tons of waste a day that is choking existing facilities.
Frank G. Paul has been named president of the systems manufacturing division of the International Business Machines Corporation.
TOKYO, July 29 -- "Please don't run away from Asia. We need you, for the sake of Asian security, at least for the next 10 years."
WASHINGTON, July 29 -Senator Gaylord Nelson said today that he would propose legislation to impose more rigorous tests on experimental drugs destined for sale to American consumers.

Three months ago, U Thant wrote Cairo and Jerusalem expressing grave concern for the safety of some 90 United Nations observers along the Suez Canal cease-fire line, which, the Secretary General said, had become a "confrontation line." Citing extensive damage to U.N. installations and constant danger for the observers, Mr. Thant declared: "I do not feel that this operation can, or should, be maintained indefinitely under such conditions."

WASHINGTON, July 29 -Faced with the immediate threat of crippling economic sanctions, El Salvador informed the Organization of American States today that she would withdraw her occupation forces from Honduras.
PASAGOULA, Miss., July 29 -- The last of a series of four roll-on, roll-off container ships ordered by the Moore-McCormack Lines was launched at the Ingalls Shipyard here today.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Willie Mays, slugging, scrambling and scraping, led the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 29 -- During practice today, Emerson Boozer was returning to the huddle after running a pass-pattern when Ken Meyer, the new offensive coach of the New York Jets, strolled near the halfback.

It is not surprising that the Administration's policy of severely tight money to slow the economy and to reduce inflation does not show clear indications of success. Business will continue to borrow even at very high interest rates as long as consumer demand justifies expansion.
Two youths were plucked from the East River last night after they went over the side of a Circle Line excursion boat.
"Mustard and sauerkraut, mister?"

Walter J. Schlager Jr., who took over as president of the Long Island Rail Road on Monday, found a way to get to his new office yesterday with none of the problems that besiege the railroad commuter: He drove to work.

The National League had just defeated the American League for the seventh straight time in All-Star Game play, and someone asked Mayo Smith, the American League manager, if he was bothered by the loss.

Limited capacity in the old Holland Tunnel alone might justify final abandonment of a Lower Manhattan Expressway. But Mayor Lindsay's flabby veto of the Cross Brooklyn project, with its imaginative linear city, is appalling. [Editorial July 19.]
The city's Neighborhood Youth Corps program, currently providing 34,900 summer jobs, received additional Federal funds yesterday to allow for 4,600 more.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange declined yesterday for the seventh consecutive session although the number of losses were not so great as on Monday when the market took its worst beating in three years.

WALDWICK, N. J., July 29 -- Arthur Ashe said today he would test South Africa's apartheid policy later this year by formally filing a request for a visa to play in that country's open tennis championships.
BELLPORT, L. I., July 29 -Close finishes were the order today as the Grand South Bay Yacht Racing Association's race week series completed its second race despite fog and a thunder squall.
A syndicate of major American banks has agreed to make a five-year, $50-million loan to the Government of Argentina at an interest rate that initially will be more than 12 per cent.
There seems to be a minitrend developing in the way some major advertisers are seeking new agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A proposed $40-million grant to Israel to help build the world's largest desalting and electrical generating plant developed strong bipartisan support today at a hearing before the House Foreign Affairs Committee.
Brian Friel's latest play, "The Mundy Scheme," is scheduled for Broadway production early next winter.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The United States showed a slim surplus of exports over imports in June and for the first half of the year, the Commerce Department reported to day.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP) -- United States infantrymen were flown in by helicopter today to reinforce South Vietnamese irregulars near the Cambodian border, and the joint force reported having killed 63 North Vietnamese soldiers in an all-day clash.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 29 -- The president of the South African Lawn Tennis Union, Alf Chalmers, repeated today, "We would be delighted to see Arthur Ashe competing in the South African national tennis championships."

SARK, Channel Islands, July 29 (Reuters) -- The 500 or so residents of this sleepy feudal island in the English Channel were jolted today by a further encroachment of 20th-century civilization -the prospect of income tax.

LONDON, July 29 -- Welsh steelworkers are embarrassing the Trades Union Congress and the Labor Government in the first major test of the T.U.C.'s ability to fulfill a pledge to curtail disruptive wildcat strikes.

HERE'S a hypothetical case for you. Supppose the United States District Court in Chicago decided to grant the injunction requested by B. F. Goodrich -- as some think Judge Hubert L. Will hinted in denying a temporary injunction about two weeks ago.

The military talk now coming out of Saigon is beginning to change. At least the words are different. Instead of a strategy of "search and destroy" or "maximum military pressure" on the enemy, United States headquarters is now talking about "reducing the violence" and a strategy of "protective reaction."
A Brooklyn grand jury indicted 23 persons yesterday on charges that they had illegally used First National City Bank credit cards that were said to have been stolen from the mail by five postmen.

TOKYO, July 29 -- The Nixon Administration is preparing a new approach to the Soviet Union on the Berlin problem as part of a general probing of Moscow's interest in relaxing East-West tensions, Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today.
PASADENA, Calif., July 29 -The first of two Mariner spacecraft that are to fly past Mars in the next few days sent 33 pictures to the earth tonight, showing the planet as no man has ever seen it.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -The Government proposed today the registration of all motor fuel additives to permit a study of "possible adverse health effects" when they are emitted into the air.
PARIS, July 29 -- The Vietnam peace talks appear to be going from "dead slow" to "dead stop".

GENEVA, July 29 -- A French television expert said today that propaganda television broadcasts from satellites direct to home television sets might enable a strong country to break the will of another country without firing a shot.
The Transit Authority may have to increase bus and subway fares to 25 cents before next summer to meet a record $120-million budget deficit.

BONN, July 29 -- A news conference this week in which the Most Rev. Matthias Defregger, Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Munich, was to have given a public account of his role in wartime executions was unexpectedly postponed today, pending further investigation of the Bishop by the Frankfurt prosecutor.
For years, some economists have looked upon the stock market as a sort of vermiform appendix of the economy. It is there, and thus to be reckoned with, but hardly necessary.
Snatching defeat from the jaws of victory, the stock market turned downward yesterday afternoon after rallying in heavy trading during the morning.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, July 30 -- President Nixon left Bangkok by air for South Vietnam today, accompanied by Gen. Greighton W. Abrams, the United States commander in Vietnam, and Ellsworth Bunker, the American Ambassador in Saigon.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 29 -- West German monetary authorities see in tumbling Wall Street stock prices the sign of an American business slowdown that could materialize by October, knocking the wind out of world inflation and reducing pressure for upward revaluation of the mark. "They're getting rid of the froth in Wall Street," said one of Frankfurt's senior central bankers.

Sixteen of the world's fastest ocean-racing powerboats will zoom off at 10 A.M. today from the starting point at the Verrazano Bridge, run down the Jersey coast to Point Pleasant, then straight out to the Atlantic and to Shinnecock Inlet on Long Island and then back to the Narrows in the Hennessy New York Grand Prix.

THE only problem with this sea of words -- 350,000 words -- is that, having dropped into it like a salvage diver, one undergoes the dislocating raptures of the deep. Speculations of every size and shape press upon the eye and bend the mind: J-curves of "relative deprivation," statistical balloonfish, squids of fact. You learn so many facts -- between 1882 and 1903, 1,985 Negroes were lynched.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -President Nixon moved tonight to break the stalemate in the Senate over legislation continuing the income tax surcharge.

BONN, July 29 -- Charges were filed today against an indefinite number of helmeted and black-gloved monitors of the extreme right-wing National Democratic party in twelve cases of beatings administered to protesters and passersby outside a meeting of the party in Frankfurt last Friday.

The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported declines yesterday in net income for the six months and 12 months ended June 30, despite higher operating revenues in both periods. Subsequently, two of the company's operating subsidiaries, the Jersey Central Power and Light Company and the New Jersey Power and Light Company, announced plans to file soon for $18.5-million a year in increases.
John F. Wharton, a lawyer, made his Broadway debut last night in a production that was preceded by an opening night party. It closed after one showing.
Foul weather lingered stubbornly over much of the Northeast yesterday and promised to stay around for at least another day.
The Manhattan, the ship that will make the first commercial attempt to transverse the legendary Northwest Passage, finally has a prow.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A Federal investigator described today the glass bottle containing carbonated beverage as the most dangerous product in American households.

El Salvador's agreement to withdraw her troops from Honduras is a significant victory for the Organization of American States and for the principle of collective security. Although El Salvador and Honduras, the belligerents in the Central American "soccer war," are small and easily susceptible to the kind of pressures the O.A.S. could bring to bear, the inter-American community has set a useful example for the rest of the world in responsible peace-keeping.

AN OPENING trump lead is sometimes made because other leads seem unattractive. The declarer can therefore infer that the opening leader has scattered honors and does not wish to make a lead that may give away a trick.
PARIS -- Kingship is a dwindling profession whose powers have been sharply cut but, both as a symbol of national continuity and a token of past grandeur, it continues into the moon age.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 29 (AP) -- Mark Spitz, American Olympic gold-medal swimmer, came within seven-tenths of a second of the world record today while winning the 100-meter free-style of the eighth Maccabiah Games in 52.09 seconds.
Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo, who finished a strong third in the Democratic mayoral primary, said yesterday that he would support Mayor Lindsay for re-election.

The principal of the high school nearest the State University center at Stony Brook. L. I., where many students have been arrested in marijuana raids recently, told a state legislative committee yesterday that drug use was also prevalent in his own school.

A controversial study, which has found a higher prevalence of early cervical cancers among women who used birth control pills than among women who used diaphragms, has been published in a British medical journal after this country's leading medical journal refused to publish it.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The 59th annual conference of the National Urban League, which has heard strong criticism of the Nixon Administration, heard one cautious note of praise today.

NASHVILLE, July 29 -- The executive committee of the Vanderbilt University Board of Trust today urged the university's chancellor to remain at Vanderbilt and decline an offer to become president of Columbia University.
Major states and cities ran into great difficulty yesterday in selling their bonds.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -Representative Seymour Halpern acknowledged today that he had "a number of loans and several personal debts" but insisted that "there has never been an iota of conflict" with his duties as a member of the House Banking and Currency Committee.

Mrs. Beverly Moss Spatt, a member of the City Planning Commission, said yesterday that the commission's counsel had advised against proceeding with a vote last week on a $3.6-million increase in appropriations for two slum-area swimming pools.

HOUSTON, July 29 (AP) -- Researchers today delayed until tomorrow the first treatment of germ-free mice with moon dust. The test is planned to determine if there are lunar organisms that could threaten life on earth.
The nation's chain stores are still showing sizable gains in sales volume, but in June and the second quarter they displayed less vigor than in the early months of 1969.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Representative Gerald R. Ford said today that the United States must build annually a merchant fleet capable of carrying 28 million tons of general cargo and 100 million tons of dry bulk cargoes to "satisfy" the nation's growing transportation needs by 1977.
The Civil Service Employes Association, an independent union, has overwhelmingly won the right to represent 30,712 professional, scientific and technical employes of New York State.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- United States analysts believe that if the Middle East crisis should boil over again into full-scale war, Israel would win once again, though in a longer, bloodier struggle than the last one, the six-day war of June, 1967.

Thomson McKinnon, Inc., a large brokerage concern with 42 branch offices and memberships on the New York and American Stock Exchanges, is cutting back its operations as a result of this year's sharply declining stock market.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 29 -- The rookies started last night, sneaking up behind one another and whispering, "The coach wants to see you." The thing was, the coach did want to see some of them.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -A member of Congress from Manhattan has managed to get $60,000 worth of topquality modern paintings from New York museums to hang on his office walls.

BANGKOK, July 29 -- President Nixon defined his do-it-yourself doctrine of Asian defense to a concerned ally here today, won what he took to be approval of his concept and then prepared for a quick visit to South Vietnam, whose travail inspired the new doctrine.

PARIS, July 29 -- The biggest competition to the 30 Blue-bell Girls at the Lido is right in the new Andre Courreges collection -- of all places. The haut couturier has some gorgeous black models in his show, and lots of dresses that show off their figures. If only men were fashion critics, Courreges would be the hit of the Paris collections.
Assemblyman Vito P. Battista, Brooklyn Republican, yesterday protested the Transit Authority's plan to shut down and demolish the 80-year-old Myrtle Avenue El in his borough.

THE first tantalizing brief color film of the descent and landing of the Apollo 11 lunar module were shown shortly after 2 P.M. yesterday by the networks and independent stations participating in television pool transmissions from Houston.
HOUSTON, July 29 -- The first photographs taken by men on the surface of the moon were released today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- In a Congress increasingly preoccupied with problems on earth, the success of the Apollo moon landing has generated little enthusiasm for bold new ventures in space.
Wheat futures recovered yesterday after Monday's sharp decline. The price range was narrow and the final quotations showed a gain of about 1 3/4 cents a bushel above Monday's final prices.
The Dictaphone Corporation entered the electronic calculator market yesterday by introducing two medium-priced calculators.

ROME, July 29 -- Pope Paul VI, on his three-day visit to Africa starting Thursday, will seek to come to the aid of a church facing problems that are almost a mirror image of those troubling the newly independent nations of the continent.

A nonpartisan committee announced yesterday that it would begin an intensive drive next month to register 250,000 voters, but there was considerable confusion about just when the drive would begin and where the voters would be registered.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 29 (UPI) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy sailed today in Nantucket Sound with his family.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Two weeks after his confirmation as a Federal appeals judge, George E. MacKinnon, the retiring vice president of six mutual funds, helped approach the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission about becoming president of the funds, Senate sources said tonight.

A reputed loanshark for the Mafia who is said to pose as an investment broker was arrested yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of conspiring to transport $1-million in stolen securities across state lines.

Alloys Unlimited, Inc., and Ranco, Inc., announced yesterday a merger agreement under which all of Ranco's common shares, valued at about $64-million, would be exchanged for two classes of new Alloys Unlimited preferred stock.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate approved by a 61-to-30 roll-call vote today the long-delayed nomination of Carl J. Gilbert as the President's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations.
RANGOON, Burma, July 21 -- Burma's military ruler, General Ne Win, is believed to be still seeking a way to entrench the military-socialist system he inaugurated with a coup d'etat seven years ago.

SEATTLE, July 29 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan of California, a leading advocate of strong measures to deal with campus violence, endorsed today the view that colleges should not be punished for the transgressions of students.
The New York Police Department has obtained a 21-ton armored personnel carrier for use in rescuing wounded policemen and civilians under fire.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, a leading advocate of more rigid gun controls, looked coldly today on a plan to take away from most Americans the right to own a handgun.

These have been dramatic days at Houston's Lunar Receiving Laboratory where scientists have begun the unprecedented task of studying the rocks and soil brought back from the moon by Apollo 11. Many meteorites have survived the fiery plunge from space through the atmosphere and landed on this planet's surface. But no one knows where these items of cosmic flotsam and jetsam originated.
NEW DELHI, July 29 -Guests are coming to New Delhi and everyone is polishing up his best silverware and best manners to entertain them.

The recent disclosures, often only after prodding, of various military misadventures with lethal chemical agents here and abroad are disquieting. The immediate cessation of specific types of testing and the use of carefully worded admissions hardly accomplish their apparent intent to reassure.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Two commonly used anticonvulsant drugs seem to help the body rid itself of DDT.

Shipping operators in New York and across the country are watching with growing interest the development of a mild controversy between Government regulatory agencies over rates in international trade.
The Transport Workers Union endorsed Mayor Lindsay for re-election yesterday, three and a half years after their heated disagreements helped precipitate a 12-day city transit strike.
Everyone in the business has his own idea of what killed tap dancing. The reasons range from George Balanchine to the bop band.

HOLMDEL, N. J., July 29 -Denmark, as everyone knows, is a small country that produces great dancers. Last night, Kirsten Simone, the Royal Danish Ballet's prima ballerina joined her countryman, the already legendary Erik Bruhn, as guest artist in "Giselle" in opening American Ballet Theater's oneweek engagement here at the Garden State Arts Center.

BABYLON, L. I., July 29 -A 23-year-old Queens woman, accused of murder here in the stabbing death of her 2 1/2-yearold daughter last night, was arraigned this afternoon in Babylon Village Police Court.

President Nixon now has a splendid opportunity to undo the harm caused by the two spokesmen for his Administration who only last week told Congress there was no need for gun-control legislation at this session.
Sharply lower earnings and sales in the second quarter and first half of this year were reported yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 29 -- Among the 95 prospects who turned out for the opening practice of the Long Island Bulls of the Atlantic Coast Football League was at least one exceptionally realistic player.

DARIEN, Conn., July 29 -- Waterlogged greens that required ramrod putting did not deter Jimmy Picard today. Despite the wretched conditions, Picard shot a three-under-par 69 to lead the qualifiers for $250,000 Westchester Classic over the 6,700-yard Country Club of Darien course.
"YOU can get anything that you want at Alice's restaurant . . ."
ATHENS, July 29 -- A hand-bill purportedly put out by an underground organization today threatened to kidnap or kill American diplomats who cooperate with the army-backed Greek regime.
WALDWICK, N. J., July 29 -- For the second consecutive day, the $20,000 Eastern grass-court tennis championships were played with grass-court balls on three surfaces, none grass.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Opponents of the Safeguard antiballistic missile system will exhibit a movie that ostensibly shows that offensive weapons can penetrate any missile defense setup.
GENEVA, July 29 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed, after long negotiations, to add six countries to the Geneva disarmament conference, increasing its membership to 26.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 23 -- As the war in Vietnam appears to move toward a conclusion, neighboring Cambodia faces two principal problems directly related to it: the presence of a substantial North Vietnamese force in border areas and the scattered activities of the small Cambodian insurgent group known as Khmer Rouge.

THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., July 29 -- Mike Ditka worries. A new hand with his third professional team, the Dallas Cowboys, Ditka has another pulled leg muscle and all he can do at the practices is hang around the perimeter of the huddles.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 29 -After leading the five-race qualifying series that concluded with one race in the rain today, the Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club crew, captained by Manton Scott won the opening race of the final series of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship off Indian Harbor Yacht Club.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 29 -- Bobby Woodhouse steered Burning Bridges of the Tartan Stable to victory in the $15,000 American Legion purse today and thereby made a successful prophet of Johnny Nerud.

TRENTON, July 29 -- Two reputed Mafia leaders walked out of a state building today and disappeared after they were threatened with contempt charges for refusing to answer questions in an inquiry into organized crime in New Jersey.

EUTAW, Ala., July 29 -Negroes won control of the Greene County Commission and the school board in a special election today, and celebrated tonight with a prayer service in the biggest church in this rural Alabama county.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- It's time to close up shop, stack the kids in the car, and go on vacation when:
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House voted today by a surprisingly lopsided margin to add about $1-billion to President Nixon's education budget.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 30 -- Fifty-three per cent of Americans interviewed in a nationwide survey expressed approval of the way President Nixon was handling the situation in Vietnam, the Gallup Poll reported today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 -- Brief as it was, President Nixon's five-and-a-half-hour visit to South Vietnam today was a political windfall for President Nguyen Van Thieu, according to the South Vietnamese leader's adherents.

TEL AVIV, July 30 (UPI) -- Mark Spitz of Santa Clara, Calif., won two gold medals and his sister, Nancy, earned one to lead the United States to a sweep of today's swimming program at the Maccabiah Games.

CHICAGO, July 30 (UPI) -- Bob Burda's bases-loaded double in the ninth inning scored Dave Marshall and Don Mason today to cap a three-run rally and give the San Francisco Giants a 6-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
IOWA CITY, July 30 -- "$4,000," an opera with a libretto by the novelist Vance Bourjaily opened last night at the University of Iowa to reactions ranging from "neutral" to "strongly excited."

Leonard Bernstein, hoarse from laryngitis and obviously a bit peeved, appeared yesterday at a hearing of the City Commission on Human Rights ready to defend himself against an accusation of discriminating in auditioning Negroes for the orchestra.

Welcome back, Captain Chris. You've made 1492 a year to remember, and you and your valiant crews have given mankind a new world. We at Raul's Ropes are proud to have supplied the rigging for those three brave ships.

LONDON, July 30 -- This is more of a warning than an essay. I implore you, never definitely make up your mind on a play at the intermission -- particularly the intermission of a classic. The director's mind may be going somewhere you cannot guess, so bear with him.

BACK in May when the world was new and the breeze of spring as soft as my daughter's hair, I met Taisto Ranta in Barnstable on Cape Cod and he told me how to build a smokehouse from a discarded refrigerator.

Sugar futures came out of their doldrums yesterday to show a substantial gain, but the spot price remained at its low level. The upswing in futures and the steadiness of the spot price could be explained by a rumor and a fact.
For the scientifically minded, the reconnaissance of Mars now under way by Mariner 6 is almost as exciting as the triumph of Apollo 11.

In seeking a way out of the controversy that rocked the City College last spring, the Board of Higher Education has charted a sensible course that offers a reasonable solution. After rejecting extreme demands made during coercive negotiations over the admission of Negro and Puerto Rican students, the board has proposed implementation of its original master plan for City University by September 1970 -- five years ahead of its timetable.

MANILA, July 30 (UPI) -- A formal investigation to determine whether three senior officers aboard the United States destroyer Frank E. Evans will be court-martialed in the loss of the ship and 74 crewmen in a collision with the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne, will begin next week, the United States Navy announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The first major acquisition by Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., one of the big conglomerate corporations, was made possible by an $84-million loan from the bank officer later hired by Gulf and Western.
BOSTON, July 30 -- The Boston College Law School announced today the establishment of a National Consumer Law Center to assist low income consumers.
JERUSALEM, July 29 -- A ministerial committee made a long-awaited visit today to the Western, or Wailing Wall in an effort to solve one of the knottiest disputes facing the Israeli Government.

An Oliver Quayle poll conducted among Massachusetts voters for the National Broadcasting Company showed yesterday that voters in Mr. Kennedy's state want him to remain their Senator, but they are not so certain about his desirability as a Presidential candidate.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I. -- In a recent effort to subsist on a welfare budget, one of the legends of Nicolo Paganini came to mind. He was considered the greatest violinist of his age, and he was also one of the world's great showmen. He would come on stage, deliberately cut one of the strings of his violin (with golden snippers) and finish the concert, using the remaining three strings.
HOUSTON, July 30 -- Apollo 11's narrow margin of success appears to have ruled out landings in craters or other sites of great scientific interest for the next four flights to the moon.
