JERUSALEM, July 30 -- The Israelis opened a new front today -- the northern border with Syria and Lebanon -- in their aerial offensive against Arab ground forces.
HOUSTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Sewer problems in the lunar quarantine laboratory today delayed plans to inject lunar soil into germ-free white mice to test for poisonous substances and germs.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 -- Following are the texts of President Nixon's statement on his arrival here today, of President Nguyen Van Thieu's statement on the occasion of his meeting with Mr. Nixon and of the latter's reply, and of Mr. Nixon's remarks to American troops at Dian:
Francis I. duPont Co., the brokerage house, announced here yesterday that it would merge with Laird, Bissell Meeds, Inc., effective Sept. 1, to form a company with a net worth of $74.5-million.

Our military spokesmen term the latest 23 per cent increase in battlefield deaths "not significant'' and turn their attention back to the engrossing game of predicting when the North Vietnamese will end their incomprehensible disinclination to fight the war full scale.

As economists, many of us are concerned about inflation and support the tax surcharge and its extension as requested by the Nixon Administration. Many of us are also concerned about inequities in the tax structure and the urgent need for tax reform.
HARRISON, N. Y., July 30 -- Early this morning the preliminary to golf's richest tourney, the $250,000 Westchester Classic, appeared to be stymied.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- Senate Democrats joined today in welcoming Mr. Kennedy's announcement that he will not resign.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the second quarter of this year totaled $41,512,000, or 94 cents a share, down from $49,702,000, or $1.09 a share, in the 1968 period.

AN impressive bill of four one-act plays, adding up to an evening that is kaleidoscopic in technique and content, opened last night at the Gate Theater on Second Avenue under the catch-all title "A Black Quartet."
Dozens of men in dark suits gathered in the spacious and dimly lighted lounge of the New York Yale Club yesterday and voted to open their all-male membership to women.

More than 40 donations of cash and other aid have been sent by readers of a news report in The New York Times last Saturday that described the plight of various welfare recipients whose relief payments have been reduced.

SEATTLE, July 30 -- Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel walked into the Western Governors Conference today and said with a grin, "I'm still not for conservation for conservation's sake -- and I'm not for progress for progress's sake."

OAKLAND, Calif., July 30 -- For the second night in a row Jack Aker of the New York Yankees came in to relieve against his former Oakland Athletic teammates and this time he came out a winner, 3-2, his sixth victory against one defeat since joining the Yankees on May 20th.
More than $400,000 has been contributed so far this summer toward the Fresh Air Fund's 1969 goal of $750,000, officials of the fund announced yesterday.

THAT Aetna Life block yesterday was a whopper -- no dobut about it. The 508,200-share bundle delayed the opening in Aetna until 11:27 A.M. when it was crossed by Salomon Brothers Hutzler for its customers at 33.

Sidney J. Weinberg, the financier whose education ended in grammar school but who became known as "Mr. Wall Street" left an estate of "more than $1-million," it was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

GENEVA, July 30 -- An important sentence from President Nixon's message to the Geneva disarmament conference asserting that "the specter of chemical and bacteriological warfare arouses horror and revulsion throughout the world" was deleted before the message was read to the conference.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 30 -- Legislators of the governing Democratic Republican party adopted a resolution this morning to present a formal bill soon for a Constitutional amendment enabling President Chung Hee Park to seek a third term in 1971.
DIAN, South Vietnam, July 30 -- The Presidential visit with the troops has become an essential piece of theater in this Vietnam era, but it is not without significance.
LONDON, July 30 -- Anatoly V. Kuznetsov, one of the best-known of the younger liberal writers in the Soviet Union, defected to the West today and received permission to remain in Britain.

ONE Sunday afternoon some years ago, a 29-year-old State Senator named Seymour Halpern put on a rumpled old blue suit and a frayed shirt and went, unshaven and under an assumed name, to the Creedmoor State Hospital in Queens, posing as the rela tive of a patient.

Broadcasts of the Ivy League football "game of the week" will be carried on radio station WQXR-AM beginning Saturday afternoon, Sept. 27, Walter Neiman, station vice president and general manager, announced yesterday.

ROME, July 30 -- Pope Paul VI, on the eve of his three-day visit to Uganda, expressed hope that his visit would permit him to work for peace in the Nigerian civil war, possibly through contacts with African chiefs of state.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The climb in wholesale prices slowed dramatically this month, rising only one-tenth of 1 per cent and offering at least some distant hope of a slowdown in soaring living costs, the Government said today.

PARIS, July 30 -- The negotiators representing the Provisional Revolutionary Government proclaimed by the National Liberation Front met President Nixon's peace appeal from Saigon today with a statement denouncing the "obstinate determination" of his Government "to pursue aggression."

Gov. Richard J. Hughes, of New Jersey, citing fears of possible massive oil pollution of his state's beaches, yesterday opposed a projected undersea oil pipeline that would run from Long Branch, N.J., to a tanker terminal 7 1/2 miles offshore.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 31 (UPI) -- A young Japanese man wielding a dagger attacked United States Ambassador Armin H. Meyer at Tokyo International Airport today, but he was subdued before he could harm the diplomat.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- General manager Red Auerbach of the Boston Celtics announced today that the club's player-coach, Bill Russell, planned to retire. The center was a key man in leading the Celtics to 11 championships in the last 13 National Basketball Association seasons.

L'AQUILA, Italy, July 30 (Reuters) -- The municipal council of this central Italian town tonight condemned a West German bishop who passed on an order during World War II, when he was a German Army captain, for the execution of Italians in Filetto di Camardo. The village is near L'Aquila.

PARIS, July 30 -- There are lots of controversial clothes to worry about in the fall-winter couture collections going on this week, mostly because so many hemlines meander up and down the shins as if no designer could really decide where they should be. But no woman need bite her nails in the pocket-size, white tiled salon of Emanuel Ungaro, which reminds some people of a dimly lighted dental laboratory.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The National Urban League moved today to take a harder line on urban affairs. The action came in the final hours of the organization's 59th annual conference after strong student agitation that the organization be more militant in pursuing its goals.
Assignment: Compose a short theme on the topic, "What I Did On My Summer Vacation."

TRENTON, July 30 -- About 1,500 banner-waving, hymn-singing "Bible believers" poured into Trenton from a dozen or more states today to defend tiny Shelton College against "the enemy in the State House."
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 30 -- Pope Paul VI will make a major effort to launch a new peace offensive in the Nigerian civil war during his visit to Kampala this week, ecclesiastical sources said today.
The "Halpern Affair" could have a major impact on the future structure of the American financial system, bankers here said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy will stay in the Senate and keep his post as Democratic whip, or assistant majority leader, but he apparently has taken himself out of the Presidential race in 1972.
Spurred by rumors of possible reductions in key interest rates, the stock market made a dramatic turnaround yesterday and posted its first advance in eight sessions.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Numerous details were disclosed today regarding the offer by the Investors group of mutual funds to Hamer H. Budge to become president of the funds -- an offer, first made in May, Mr. Budge did not finally decline until July 21.
Your July 14 news article on the risks of underground nuclear tests at Amchitka, Alaska, is commendable.
ROME, July 30 (Reuters) -- Premier Mariano Rumor reported to President Giuseppe Saragat tonight on his efforts to form a new government and end a 25-day-old Italian political crisis.

President Nixon, the statesman, in Guam last week carefully sketched for reporters a sensible new Asian policy designed to avoid future Vietnams. Richard Nixon, the politician, in Thailand and Vietnam this week carelessly tossed off remarks that were uncomfortably close reminders of old policies that have long since been discredited.

NEW DELHI, July 30 -- The Indian Government will seek President Nixon's support for a nonmilitary regional security agreement, along the lines of the Geneva accords on Indochina in 1954 and backed by the great powers, to insure peace in Asia and the Pacific after the Vietnam War, according to Indian Foreign Ministry sources.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Justice Department said today it would file suit to block the proposed merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Grinnell Corporation.
Representative Seymour Halpern fell behind in rent payments on his Congressional office in Queens at least twice in 1963 and 1964 and once had to be threatened with a lawsuit before paying.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A successful American-flag shipping operator who consistently talks optimism while most of the industry warns of decline and defeat said here today that the country's merchant marine is approaching a period of renascence.
Following are the highlights of President Nixon's itinerary for his round-the-world trip (times are local, with New York time in parentheses):

The Federal Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has held up immediate development of the long-planned $60-million consolidated passenger terminal along "luxury liner" row on the Hudson River.

Although the Dow-Jones industrial average plummeted to an intra-day low of less than 800 yesterday, it closed up 1.62 at 803.58, giving the men who manage the big money on Wall Street hope that the figurative rain may have stopped falling, along with the rain outdoors.
EUTAW, Ala., July 30 -- The election yesterday of six Negroes to public office in Greene County was hailed today by Negro leaders as a "giant political step for Alabama and for the South."

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 30 -- President Nixon made a quick trip to South Vietnam today that combined public displays of loyalty to the South Vietnamese with intense private deliberations over future American troop withdrawals and possible changes in military tactics.
Neil A. Armstrong, the Apollo 11 commander, has said that one small but important word was omitted in the official version of the historic utterance he made when he stepped on the moon 11 days ago.

Kirk Kerkorian agreed yesterday to seek elsewhere, if necessary, a 130-million loan he has negotiated with the Transamerica Financial Corporation to help finance a tender offer for one million shares, or 17 per cent, of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., July 30 -- Torrents of water and mudslides from a building site on a high hill overlooking this rural North Shore community have been plaguing residents here for the last 18 months.
Angry commuters assailed rail service on the Penn Central's New Haven Division yesterday as undependable, unclean, uncomfortable and unsafe.
Mayor Lindsay won the endorsement yesterday of another major union, Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers, in his campaign for re-election.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 30 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan called today for the Federal Government to make President Nixon's birthplace in the Orange County community of Yorba Linda a national historic site.

The recent lunar adventure has raised a debate about our nation's priorities. The position that man should tackle his problems on earth before reaching for the stars, has mortal force. But even its proponents have failed to see its most practical and compelling basis.

A Federal Court judge refused yesterday to enjoin the Lindsay administration from enforcing the city's new rent law. He said a landlord's challenge to the law's constitutionality had "little likelihood of eventual success."
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Some oil industry executives will continue to be able to escape all Federal income tax under a decision made today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
A large collection of the literary papers of the volatile Irish playwright Sean O'Casey has been acquired by the New York Public Library for an amount "in excess of $100,000."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Mrs. James Bond Stockdale stood alone in the soaring rotunda of the Capitol. She had tried to see a number of Senators, she said, but was able to meet only with an administrative aide.

BONN, July 30 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger was quoted today by a Ludwigshafen newspaper as having asserted in an interview that the extreme right-wing National Democratic party "is not neo-Nazi."

The New York Stock Exchange opened an inquiry yesterday into the possibility that widespread rumors of a decrease in the prime interest rate might have been started in an effort to manipulate the stock market.
EXPERT Earl Pruner of Los Angeles, scoring 6 1/2-1/2, captured first prize in the recent Arthur B. Stamer Memorial Tournament at San Francisco's Mechanics Institute.
Hyman Feldman, a 50-year-old engineer who has headed the Transit Authority's bus operations since 1960, was appointed yesterday to supervise the city's entire mass-transportation system.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday the broadest increase for prices of steel products in a year. Flat rolled products, which are used to make automobiles, refrigerators and many other consumer products, will rise an average of 4.8 per cent next Wednesday, U.S. Steel said.
HOLMDEL, N.J., July 30 -- The American Ballet Theater presented its version if "Coppelia" tonight at the Garden State Arts Center here with Kirsten Simone in the title role, and Erik Bruhn.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Treasury offered today to pay an effective interest rate of 7.82 per cent, the highest since 1859, on an 18-month note to refinance $3.2-billion of securities maturing Aug. 15.

EDGEWATER, N. J., July 30 -- "Man is a competitive animal. In big business you can't see the measure of your mark," said Bill Wishnick, "but when you get down with a thousand horses bombing through the ocean at 70 miles an hour, well, you can see who backs off first."

STUTTGART, Germany, July 30 (UPI) -- John Carlos and Lee Evans, San Jose State teammates, won the 100-and 400-meter races today but Europe took the lead over the Western Hemisphere in both the men's and women's competitions after the first day of a track and field meet.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 30 -- Another Star, one of the old-timers in the field, moved into the lead for the open jumper championship at the Orange County Fair Horse Show tonight when he won the knockdown-and-out event.
Rumors that leading banks were going to cut their prime interest rate moved most issues on the American Stock Exchange yesterday into the plus column for the first time in eight sessions.
The Board of Education adjourned a public meeting last night 10 minutes after it was convened when a crowd of youngsters and adults hooted and jeered, making it impossible to conduct business.

The response of many thousands of citizens of Massachusetts to Senator Edward M. Kennedy's appeal was predictable. And so was his announcement yesterday that he would indeed remain as Senator from Massachusetts and seek re-election next year. Both the appeal and his speedy "response" suggest a carefully worked-out plan to re-establish his political position in the eyes of the voters of his state.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which has been the focal point of the opposition to the Administration's Safeguard antiballistic-missile program, rested its case today with a private showing of a movie and the introduction of three secret Pentagon reports in an effort to show that the Safeguard system was ill designed for its job.
The New York Mets lost two games and a lot of glamour yesterday when they were bombed by the Houston Astros, 16-3 and 11-5, before 43,594 persons in Shea Stadium.

TEL AVIV, July 30 (AP) -- Pam Richmond of Mission Hills, Kan., defeated Israel's Pauline Peisachov, 6-1, 6-4; Julie Heldman of New York defeated Nancy Lewis of Great Neck, L.I., 6-0, 6-0, and Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, beat Ronie Kudler of Israel, also 6-0, 6-0, in opening-round women's tennis play at the Maccabiah Games today.
MOSCOW, July 30 -- Young guitar players, along with coin pilferers, are reducing thousands of Moscow telephone booths to shelters useful only for getting out of the rain.
Hank Aaron passed one Yankee first baseman last night, but Bob Tillman just missed reaching another.

The Martin Luther King Jr. Park, a 50-by-100-foot playground built on the site of a former rubble-strewn lot in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, was dedicated yesterday by the New York Urban Coalition and neighborhood groups.

Growling power shovels stopped their site-clearing work in Brooklyn's East New York section just long enough yesterday for Mayor Lindsay to break ground formally for the country's first new housing project under the Model Cities Program.
WHEN Marco Leynor shows a Saluki, ringsiders invariably note how master and dog complement each other. The dog gives an impression of grace and symmetry. There is a spring to his gait.

The controversy surrounding the proposed sale of the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory, to a commercial organization moved closer yesterday to a trial in State Supreme Court to determine the university's right to sell the well-known nonprofit research institution.

New Yorkers could be heard saying to each other yesterday that the strange bright glow coming from the sky was sunshine -- something they had hardly seen for nearly two weeks of almost continuous cloudiness and rain.
The Treasury's decision yesterday to offer a 7 3/4 per cent note at a yield of 7.82 per cent caused the Government securities market to breathe a little easier late yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- A high percentage of students who receive Government-guaranteed college loans fail to remain in school for the full term covered by the loan, Government auditors said today.

Buddy Rich's ability to reach a rock audience with his virtuoso drumming, which has been demonstrated repeatedly during the past year, was evident again last night at the Wollman Rink in Central Park where he appeared with his big jazz band.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- A compromise that will permit the extension of the income tax surcharge to come before the Senate for a vote tomorrow was worked out late today.

Among the outdoor musical treats offered to New Yorkers and visitors in recent summer seasons, the New York Philharmonic's free concerts in the city's parks have been among the choice and most popular events.

UPPER SADDLE RIVER, N. J., July 30 -- Dan O'Bryant, who was married in May and graduated from college in June, won his first tournament singles match of the summer today, upsetting Mexico's Davis Cup left-hander, Joaquin Loyo-Mayo.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday two grants totaling just under $1-million for New York City studies -- $900,000 for the general program of the new Rand Institute and $96,000 to prepare a handbook of city problems for the Mayor who is sworn in next Jan. 1.

PASADENA, Calif., July 30 -- Mariner 6 completed its dramatic encounter with Mars tonight, and radio signals from the spacecraft indicated that it had obtained a wide range of scientific data and close-up television pictures as it swept to within about 2,000 miles of the planet.

THOUSAND OAKS, Calif., July 30 -- Richmond Flowers Jr., the world-class hurdler from Tennessee who is trying to make good as a professional football player with the Dallas Cowboys, was asked today how he liked training camp here.

The Novo Corporation announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the estate of Edward L. Richter to buy approximately 493,000 shares of common stock of Wings and Wheels Express, Inc., an air-freight forwarder.
The Civil Service Employes Association won its second major victory yesterday in representation elections among New York State employes.

Negotiations to settle a three-month strike that has curtailed the operation of Harlem's first cooperative supermarket -- the Harlem River Consumers Cooperative -- have proved fruitless and have broken off.

MOSCOW, Thursday, July 31 -- Anatoly F. Kuznetsov has defected to the West at a time when his reputation in Soviet intellectual circles was at its height and only a week after his elevation to the editorial board of a major journal had been made public.
The First National Bank of Minneapolis meets newcomers at the airport and helps them get settled in their new town.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 30 -- Mike Battle doesn't look like a football player -- at least by pro standards. He is 6 feet 1 inch, lists his weight at 180 pounds, and one of his major functions with the New York Jets this season will be to return kicks and punts.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Nixon Administration is preparing a formal proposal to the Russians to tear down the eight-year-old Berlin wall, United States officials said today.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Najeeb E. Halaby, president of Pan American Airways, said that a two-hour inspection today of the Soviet Union's supersonic airliner, the TU-144, had left him and a group of United States aviation experts "very, very impressed."

YPSILANTI, Mich., July 30 (UPI) -- Gov. William G. Millikent oday asked for Federal Bureau of Investigation aid and ordered the state police to take charge of the so far fruitless search for the killer of seven young women in the Ann Arbor-Ypsilanti university area over the last two years.

TOKYO, July 30 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers delivered his long-awaited reply today to the proposals on Okinawa that Japan's Foreign Minister, Kitchi Aichi, took to Washington at the beginning of June.
Many industrial items were increased in price yesterday.
The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new computer yesterday and a new calling card to go with it.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 -- For a few hours today, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon saw at first hand some of man's inhumanity to man.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 30 -- Legislation to ban all cigarette advertising in California through newspapers, magazines, broadcasting and billboards was killed today by an Assembly committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 -- Secretary General Thant, returning to his office for the first time in nearly four weeks following minor surgery, smiled as he stepped from his limousine shortly before noon and headed for his offices on the 38th floor.

" THE CONTEMPORARY UNIVERSITY" is based on a Daedalus symposium and has been out for a while. But since publishers tend to regard the summer season as a time to Cape Coddle themselves, it's worth a backward look to see just how quickly "contemporary" becomes "irrelevant."
Three major corporations -- the Standard Oil Company of California, the Walworth Company and the United States Borax and Chemical Corporation -- announced yesterday the election of new presidents.
PRAGUE, July 30 -- A high security official warned today that subversive forces were "mobilizing" Czechoslovaks for active disturbances, as well as for passive resistance to the regime.
Unions representing cement truck drivers and riggers working on construction projects in the city reached tentative agreements with employer groups last night.

Mayor Lindsay said last night that he would "carry the fight to preserve the 20-cent fare to both state and Federal authorities," by seeking their aid to offset operating deficits on the city transit system after next Jan. 1.
The Board of Higher Education has rejected the recently opened bids for construction of a new Bronx Community College, terming them "a bidding fiasco."

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Planned parenthood advocates urged Congress today to double the $50-million authorization requested by the Administration for population control programs under foreign aid legislation.

A navigator won a rough and punishing Hennessy New York Grand Prix ocean race yesterday, though he never touched the steering wheel of his 32-foot Bertram. Bob Schiffenhaus left the driving to a fellow Miamian, Peter Rittmaster, who skirted logs, boxes, timber and a floating corpse that littered the Verrazano Bridge start of the 222.5-mile course and brought his American Moppie home 30 seconds ahead of Pat Duffy's outboard.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 -- The pampered New York bettor helped zoom Monmouth Park's per-capita betting today to $110 as the promise of sunshine gave the track its first respectable turnout of the week.

MOST players get the feeling from time to time that the fates are conspiring against them. South was fully entitled to that feeling on the diagramed deal, played earlier this month in an exhibition match in Dallas.
RYE, N. Y., July 31 -- Amy Lane of Navesink successfully retained her Metropolitan girls' junior golf championship today.

The author of the Off Broadway show "De Sade illustrated" destroyed stage settings for the show last night to protest the inclusion of a nude scene in the show. The damage, inflicted with a hammer and white paint, forced the cancellation of last night's performance.
HOUSTON, July 31 -- A spectacular second batch of Apollo 11 photographs, including the first ever taken by a man standing on the moon's surface, was made public here tonight.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- Although the New York Jets dislike the ferocity of most of their exhibition opponents, the world champions appeared enthusiastic today as they arrived for tomorrow night's game with the College All-Stars before an expected 70,000 spectators at Soldiers Field.
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 31 -- Pope Paul VI flew here today from Rome to tell members of the Roman Catholic hierarchy of Africa that they must become "missionaries to yourselves."

BUENOS AIRES, July 31 -- Armed rebels, believed to have had at least tacit backing from elements of the Argentine armed forces, seized a radio station in the city of Cordoba today and broadcast demand for the resignation of President Juan Carlos Ongania.

BUCHAREST, July 31 -- President Nixon's scheduled trip to Rumania this weekend was described in the authoritative foreign policy weekly Luema today as a contribution to "peaceful coexistence among countries with different social systems."

The news today is full of Foote, Cone Belding overtones. John G. Avrett, a 40-year-old former creative director there, has been named president of Marschalk. William E. Chambers Jr., who had headed the F.C. New York office, has been tapped for a similar slot with MacManus, John Adams, with the rank of executive vice president.
TEL AVIV, July 31 (UPI) -- The United States picked up four more gold medals in the swimming events at the Maccabiah Olympic Games today to increase its commanding lead in medals won to 24.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Department of Defense today confirmed the statement by the West German Government, which acknowledged that the United States maintained stores of poison gas in that country.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where it is indicated.
The Civil Service Employes Association scored its third victory of the week yesterday in a representation election among the state's 45,499 institutional employes.

KRONBERG, West Germany, July 31 -- American offshore mutual funds have been handed some difficult problems by the bear market in Wall Street, increasing attention drawn to some of their excesses and a crackdown by a number of European Governments.
PARIS, July 31 -- The Vietnam peace talks appeared as deadlocked as ever today despite President Nixon's call from Saigon for a start in serious negotiations.

STUTTGART, Germany, July 31 (UPI) -- Despite winning efforts by a Western Hemisphere team led by John Carlos of San Jose State and Gerry Lindgren of Spokane, Wash., Europe clinched victory in men's and women's competition in the two-day international track and field meet that ended today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 31 (AP) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk announced a Government reorganization today under which his duties as Chief of State will be transferred to a special council and he will retain only the presidency of the Sangkum party.
MARLBORO, Vt., July 31 -- In order to stay the same, the Marlboro Music Festival is changing.

MIDDLETOWN, N. Y., July 31 -- Pam Carmichael from the Acadia Farms of Northfield, Ohio, an 18-year-old blonde, has extended her horizons to the open jumper division this year. But she still hasn't forgotten her primary business -- the junior hunters.

The early retirement of Frank Aikman Jr. as president of the Long Island Rail Road is not likely to appease the army of angry commuters who daily travel on the nation's largest commuting line. Most of them will conclude -- despite denials -- that he was made a scapegoat for William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
July sales gains for the nation's large chain stores, based on volume for the four weeks ended July 26, indicate that they will be up slightly from the increases reported for June.

The System Development Corporation, a major nonprofit "think tank" specializing in computer software, announced yesterday that it was transferring its operations to a new "for-profit" tax-paying corporation.
The General Motors Corporation, the world's largest industrial enterprise, moved yesterday to try to thwart a broad steel price increase by the nation's largest steelmaker.

FULLERTON, Calif., July 31 -- Jim Seymour, the Notre Dame star of the last three seasons, will play just one football game this season. It comes tomorrow night in Chicago, when the College All-Stars, Seymour's team, oppose the New York Jets.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Guidelines for operation of community action programs under the antipoverty program are being tightened by the Nixon Administration as part of a general overhaul of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
PRAGUE, July 31 -- The United States indicated a desire today to achieve closer ties with Czechoslovakia, and voiced a veiled warning against further infringement of that country's sovereignty.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Representative Wright Patman announced plans today for "a full-scale, top-to-bottom, A-to-Z investigation" of the banking lobby.
Manhattan Democratic district leaders defeated by a vote of nearly 2 to 1 yesterday an attempt to have their organization repudiate Controller Mario A. Procaccino as the party's candidate for Mayor.

YPSILANTI, Mich., July 30 -- Fear has become part of daily living for many young women in the Ypsilanti-Ann Arbor area, 40 miles west of Detroit, where seven, five of them college students, have been killed in the last two years.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31 -- William L. McKnight, the retired chairman of the board of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, made a flying visit from Minneapolis today and landed right in the winner's circle.
TOKYO, July 31 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers reiterated today the Nixon Administrations readiness to improve relations with Communist China.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 31 -- King Hussein committed himself today to the "escalation" of resistance to Israel "until victory is achieved."
CHICAGO, July 31 -- Five policemen were shot -- none of them seriously -- in a 30-minute gun fight at the offices of a chapter of the Black Panther party early this morning.

GENEVA, July 31 -- The United States and the Soviet Union today overrode protests by nonaligned members, who complained that they had not been consulted, and invited six additional countries to join the disarmament conference.
CARLSTADT, N. J., July 31 -- An application for construction of a $30-million night harness racing track in the Bergen County meadowlands here was filed today with the New Jersey Racing Commission.

While there can be no question that a massive national attack on social and environmental problems is most urgently needed, it seems that the space program is increasingly becoming a scapegoat for our inadequate domestic policy.

The Metropolitan Opera Association announced yesterday that rehearsals for the 1969-70 season, which were to begin next Monday, had been postponed because new contract agreements have not been reached with unions representing members of the company.

SWEDESBORO, N. J., July 31 (AP) -- The body of Jane Leonardi, a Swedesboro coed missing for four days, was found Thursday night several miles from her home, on a wooded lane just off the Harrisonville-Swedesboro Road.
It was a glorious day on Wall Street yesterday as the stock market turned in an unusually strong performance, scoring its best gain in three months.
The July 28 news article gave an excellent account of the problems of railroad commuter service in the New York metropolitan area. It did not, however, present possible solutions to the problem.
BONN, July 31 (AP) -- The West German Government announced today that a limited amount of poison gas was being stored by the United States in West Germany.

TOKYO, July 31 -- Shigetsugu Hamaoka, a 21-year-old Japanese youth who attempted to attack Ambassador Armin H. Meyer of the United States today, had no systematic plan behind his action, the police said.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 31 -- Elliott Burch brought Arts and Letters to Monmouth Park today, after being promised clear weather and a fast track for the $100,000 Monmouth Invitational Handicap on Saturday.

Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, announced yesterday a series of news department promotions and assignments that he said would "advance by another step our program to give increasing authority and responsibility to talented younger executives on the staff."

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee today assured sponsors of a loan-guarantee approach to Latin-American aid that his group would include some form of the plan in this year's foreign aid legislation.

CHICAGO, July 31 -- The Students for a Democratic Society reported today that it expected thousands of people to participate in a demonstration here Oct. 11 against the Vietnam war and in support of the "black liberation struggle."
The Hanes Corporation announced yesterday it planned to purchase a 42 per cent interest in the Bali Company, a women's undergarment manufacturer, for about $12.6-million.

The American Stock Exchange turned in its best performance in more than a year yesterday as the list advanced sharply on moderate trading. The exchange's index soared 51 cents, to $25.70, its biggest gain since April 23, 1968, when the indicator rose 52 cents.

NEW DELHI, July 31 -- The Nixon-round-the-world cavalcade touched down for 22 hours in India today. En route here to discuss matters of interest to the Indians, the President went out of his way to express new praise and support for the Government of South Vietnam.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 31 -- A special commission appointed by the Illinois Supreme Court called today for the resignation of two court justices because of "acts of impropriety" in financial dealings while serving on the court.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- After nearly four weeks of debate, the Senate agreed to vote next Wednesday on the Administration's proposal to start deploying the Safeguard missile defense system.

ATLANTA, July 31 -- In a somewhat chaotic scene, 13 Negro high school students, some of them from the slums, flew out of Atlanta this afternoon for a three-week trip to Moscow to test their skill in Russian.
I wish to voice my support of President Nixon's extension of Government birth control programs. Our nation must address itself to this urgent problem. [Editorial July 29.]

YONKERS, July 31 -- District Attorney Carl A. Vergari, citing "evidence of irregularities and possible fraud," announced today that Yonkers was withholding the payment of nearly $1-million in bills for snow removal pending a review of the evidence by the August grand jury.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Nixon Administration planners, eager to cut about $2-billion more from the already slimmed-down defense budget, are seriously contemplating reducing the size of the armed forces by 50,000 to 200,000 men over the next year.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Counsel for the House anti-trust subcommittee attempted today to show that Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., had thrown business to the Chase Manhattan Bank to the detriment of smaller banks around the country.
Atlanta's road show act of Tillman and Aaron was a big hit again last night, but just like the night before, they made their exit too early.

BOSTON, July 31 -- District Attorney Edmund Dinis of Bristol County said today that he had requested a Superior Court inquest in the automobile accident July 18 of Senator Edward M. Kennedy that resulted in the death of a Washington secretary.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Exhausted from days of stormy debate, the House tonight passed a $17.6-billion appropriations bill after writing into it a sharp curb on Federal efforts to desegregate schools.

LONDON, July 31 -- It has been a strange Bolshoi Ballet season at Covent Garden -- with more than its share of contrasted miseries and glories. The last new production of the season was a very truncated version of Yuri Grigorovich's "Legend of Love."
The Federal Reserve System hit the money market hard this week to counteract the developing trend toward lower short-term interest rates, banking data published yesterday showed.

LAS VEGAS, July 28 -- The explosions of neon on the Strip hawk such attractions as "Pardon My Can Can" and the "Fillies de Soul Revue." Other marquees try to lure people away from the crap tables to hear Steve Lawrence and Edyie Gorme and Elvis Presley.
LONDON, July 31 -- The cozy, feudal island of Sark, which enjoys cheap cigarettes and liquor and has neither income taxes nor automobiles, has staved off the 20th century.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Government took the first official steps today toward issuance of a new mortgage-backed security, though the first of these securities will not be marketable bonds as originally expected.

LAHORE, Pakistan, July 31 -- President Nixon's close and friendly associations with Pakistan when he was Vice President in the Eisenhower Administration will assure him a warm personal welcome when he arrives in Pakistan tomorrow for an overnight stay.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The recent intensification of fighting in the area of the Suez Canal has sharpened the competition between Israel and the United Arab Republic for headlines abroad and has widened the gap between their conflicting claims of victory.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission has expressed strong opposition to a bill granting antitrust immunity for joint operating agreements between competing newspapers.

PARIS, July 31 -- At the Dior opening today, Lauren Bacall, in a very short pink "old Norell" dress that showed lots of thigh when she sat, almost made up her mind about the new long skirts that are fluttering in and out of the winter couture collections.

The nation's airlines are preparing to ask the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to increase fares for all travelers within the United States. Last Feb. 20, the board approved a 3.8 per cent rise, the first in seven years.

Anthony L. DiLorenzo, who is reputed to be the heir-apparent to the Vito Genovese family of the Mafia, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to transport $1-million worth of stolen International Business Machines stocks across state lines.
Bill Pevear bore a smile on his face and wore a rose on his lapel yesterday.
BERLIN, July 31 -- The Western allies told the city Government of West Berlin today to halt for the time being any extradition of army deserters to West Germany.

NEW DELHI, July 31 -- A throng of policemen, angered by the killing of a policeman by a mob, rampaged through the West Bengal legislative assembly in Calcutta today, breaking furniture and terrorizing the legislators, who fled.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- Aleksandr T. Tvardovsky, chief editor of the liberal magazine, Novy Mir, was accused in a Soviet newspaper today of allowing his publication to depict Soviet society in an unfavorable light.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Secretary General Thant today termed the death on Sunday of a United Nations cease-fire observer at the Suez Canal "a dramatic symptom of the breakdown of the cease-fire" that could prove "of the utmost seriousness for the peace of the world."

FOR his first novel, "The Free-Lance Pallbearers," Ishmael Reed was celebrated above ground and under as a promising practitioner of the "black esthetic." His freewheeling, surrealistic satire of America had presumably broken loose from the strictures of the traditional white man's novel and tapped life rhythms and experiences that only blacks could understand.
ALBANY, July 31 -- Sidney S. Hein, chairman of the Queens County Republican organization, has been named a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority.
Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he would ask Governor Rockefeller to add the transit fare problem to the agenda for the expected special session of the Legislature on Congressional redistricting.

ANATOLY VASILYEVICH KUZNETSOV, the Soviet author who defected in Britain Wednesday, was born Aug. 18, 1929, hard by Babi Yar, the ravine in Kiev where tens of thousands of the city's Jews were to be massacred by the Nazis in 1961.

Theophilus (Theo) Curtis sat in the office of Paramount Creations, a hat manufacturing company that he said is one of the largest in the city, and explained how he -- a black former employe -- became the boss.

PARIS -- The conceptual revolution in foreign policy now being unfolded by President Nixon indicates remembrance of things past. There are elements of the Truman Doctrine in Greece where the U.S. warned off external intervention but only sent arms and advisers to help Athens beat off the Communist takeover bid.

Elderly residents of an apartment house built for them at 17 East 124th Street with 100 per cent Federal aid are trapped in a struggle between two corporations over who owns the building and is entitled to receive their rents.

The New York Mets regained some respectability against the Houston Astros yesterday -- at least they didn't suffer any 11-run innings. But they did suffer their fourth straight defeat when a rookie named Tom Griffin outpitched Tom Seaver, 2-0.
Joseph Monserrat, president of the Interim Board of Education has resigned as director of -- Migration in the Puerto Rican Department of Labor, after 18 years with the Puerto Rican Government.

AREA A -- The fine run of bluefish that has lasted for more than two weeks was interrupted earlier in the week by storms that kept charter boats on shore, but blues of 10 to 16 pounds are again being taken.

A group of four major United States banks -- the Bank of America, San Francisco, the First National City Bank, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company -- have each agreed to lend about $5-million to the International Telephone and Telegraph Company to finance the purchase of telephone equipment by Telefonos del Estado, the state-owned telephone company in Argentina, an Argentine spokesman said yesterday.
The savings bank industry, after long delay, will begin Monday to offer depositors the chance to purchase shares in a mutual fund created for them -- the Fund for Mutual Depositors, Inc.

PASADENA, Calif., July 31 -- The planet Mars, since time immemorial hidden from close scrutiny by its vast distance from earth, was seen tonight in a breathtaking series of views such as those that an astronaut coming in for a landing might experience.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 31 -- The practice field got a little bigger today, or maybe it was the New York Giants' squad getting smaller.

Mayor Lindsay, who yesterday announced formation of his Independent party, continues to pick up endorsements from important labor and political organizations, from Democratic leaders and office holders, including members of the State Legislature from Brooklyn and Queens as well as Manhattan. As the list lengthens, it may appear that the Republican Mayor has captured most of the Democratic party. This appearance is grossly deceptive.

The defection in London of the leading Soviet writer, Anatoly V. Kuznetsov, is a symptom of the crisis now convulsing the Soviet cultural world. That crisis springs from the efforts of Moscow reactionaries, who enjoy powerful Kremlin support, to re-Stalinize Soviet intellectualism and to annul the last vestiges of freedom and heterodoxy still surviving from the Khrushchev era.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell confirmed today his intention to seek a new test of the Supreme Court's ruling governing police interrogation of criminal suspects.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- When Sgt. Maj. Herbert J. Sweet enlisted in the Marines at the age of 17, they were landing on the beaches in whaleboats instead of helicopters.

In Public School 23, at Bayard and Mulberry Streets, there is a faded, 40-year-old photograph that shows two Chinese pupils in a graduating class that was nearly all Italian. Now all the pupils at the school are Chinese.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 31 -- Thomas Koch of Brazil staved off five match points in the 12th game of the fifth set today and went on to defeat Mark Cox to even the Davis Cup interzone semi-final match between Britain and Brazil at 1-all on Wimbledon's lightning fast No. 1 court.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The "war of nerves" between the Administration and the Senate Democratic leadership over extension of the surtax ended in an uneasy truce today but not without considerable political embarrassment to the White House.

J. Burch McMorran, who earned 30 cents an hour as a laborer on a road gang 52 years ago, retired yesterday as State Transportation Commissioner. Mr. McMorran stepped down from his $34,675-a-year post after reaching the statutory retirement age of 70.
HARRISON, N. Y., July 31 -- "I really didn't appreciate what I had done until later on," said Tony Jacklin. "I concentrated so hard during the final round that my mind was numb."

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to suspend trading in the common shares of the Pittsburgh Coke and Chemical Company and the Piper Aircraft Corporation, effective Monday.

ROME, July 31 -- Following are excerpts from Pope Paul's address delivered in English today to the closing symposium of African prelates in Kampala, Uganda, and from his remarks to President Milton Obote of Uganda:
Mayor Lindsay formally introduced his new party yesterday -- the Independent party of New York City. It is sponsored by a committee of 14 Democrats and three Republicans.

A committee has been formed by community and labor leaders to help keep R. Hoe Co., the printing-press manufacturer, in business as an operating company, according to Sal Iaccio, of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers.

MIAMI, July 31 (UPI) -- A Federal prisoner, wielding a used razor blade he had fished out of a restroom receptacle, commandeered a jetliner with 131 persons aboard over Oklahoma today and forced it to fly to Havana.

Wheat-future prices, which came alive in midweek after setting life-of-contract lows on Monday, lost their vigor yesterday. The September delivery, for example dropped to close at $1.23 5/8-3/4, down from $1.24 1/2 a bushel on Wednesday, but still above its low of $1.19 1/2 on Monday.

HUNTINGTON, Ind., July 31 -- Msgr. Vincent A. Yzermans, editor in chief of Our Sunday Visitor, the nation's largest Roman Catholic weekly newspaper, resigned today "after several weeks of serious thought."
Pan American World Airways, Inc., had a loss of $1,881,000 in the second quarter in contrast to a profit of $17,630,000, or 52 cents a share, in the year-earlier quarter.

One of the fascinations of attending the fortnightly jazz concerts at Muse, at Lincoln Place and Bedford Street in Brooklyn, is the constant act of discovery. The jazz groups that play there are as a rule made up of young musicians whose reputations, if any, do not extend much beyond the neighborhood.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31 -- Syria employed her air force and heavy artillery today in her first offensive operation against Israel since the six-day war of June, 1967.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., July 31 -- When the United States Lawn Tennis Association sanctioned non-open prize money tournaments this summer, the object was to pad the payrolls of its top players and keep them from signing lucrative contracts with rival promoters.
JERUSALEM, July 31 -- Witnesses said there was no Israeli response when two Syrian MIG-17's attacked an Israeli mountain position today in the northern part of the Golan heights.
SEATTLE, July 31 -- Western Governors ended their annual conference here today without taking action on environmental problems that had generated sharp discussion during the four-day meeting.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 31 -- The so-called "one clean" and continuous putting rules are to be stricken from the book after two years. The United States Golf Association announced today that its executive committee had sanctioned the move, which will be effective Jan. 1.

BAY SHORE, L. I., July 31 -- Herbert Buerger sailed Huntress III to a second-place finish today and all but clinched the Lightning Class series in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Race Week regatta today.
NEW DELHI, July 31 -- A good many political scientists, journalists and other observers of the public scene have spent a sizable percentage of their lives dividing Richard M. Nixon into halves.

OAKLAND, Calif., July 31 -- Mel Stottlemyre, who leads the major leagues in complete games, picked up his 18th of the season last night but failed to get a victory as the Oakland Athletics defeated the New York Yankees, 3-2.

The July 12 editorial, "Going Public on Wall Street," contains an unwarranted criticism of the so-called "third" and "fourth" markets. This attack was repeated in the July 22 editorial "A Milestone on the Street." These markets exist only because they have proved to perform useful services for institutional investors.
Following are the highlights of President Nixon's itinerary for his round-the-world trip (times are local, with New York time in parentheses):

An official of the Penn Central Company acknowledged yesterday that proposed fare revisions on its New Haven line could increase travel costs "substantially" for riders making two or three round trips a week.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 31 -- Dick Siderowf, the defending champion who was supposed to advance, Art Borinsky, who wasn't, and Bud Zachary, who should have, provided some of the highlights as the 67th annual Metropolitan Amateur Golf championship tournament began its four-day run today over the Garden City Country Club course.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Nixon Administration's forthcoming maritime policy will contain features designed to increase the United States merchant marine's ability to carry 30 per cent of the nation's sea trade, compared with the current level of 7 per cent, a ranking Administration official said today.

President Nixon is now trying to apply to the world the techniques of the American political campaign trail. He is dominating the news and wowing the locals. Just as he flew from one state to another in the election of 1968, so he is now vaulting the oceans and the continents, telling each audience what he thinks it wants to hear
THE Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League begin a week from today in Los Angeles and will probably set a world record for attendance.
Bond prices advanced on three fronts yesterday -- Governments, tax-exempts and corporates.

The question of whether a Civil Service examination that prevented a Negro police lieutenant from being promoted was discriminatory was argued yesterday at a public hearing before the state's Human Rights Division.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Senate Labor Committee approved today a tough coal mine health and safety bill that provides stiff violation penalties for both operators and mine workers.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy resumed his Senate duties today and confirmed that he would not run for President in 1972.
MOSCOW, July 31 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy's right-wing enemies have started a "campaign of persecution" against him in the United States, a Soviet newspaper reported today.
BERLIN, July 31 -- A Western approach to the Soviet Union to seek an easing of tensions over Berlin is expected to be made in August, allied officials said here today.
LONDON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Soviet Embassy has asked the British Government for permission to talk with Anatoly V. Kuznetsov, Foreign Ministry sources said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31 (Reuters) -- United States combat deaths in South Vietnam dropped to 110 last week, the lowest weekly toll this year and the fourth lowest in two years, it was announced today.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- Two-run homers by Ernie Banks and Randy Hundley and a homer by Billy Williams helped Ferguson Jenkins gain his 14th victory today as the Chicago Cubs routed the San Francisco Giants, 12-2.

WASHINGTON, Conn. -- From the slender spire of the First Congregational Church with its fine Palladian window to the neat handkerchief of village green, this town, which dates from 1742, is a perfect example of New England.

NEW DELHI, July 31 -- Chattarpur, a modernized villiage 12 miles south of here, had never seen a President's wife before, and Mrs. Richard M. Nixon had never seen an Indian village. When the two met briefly today, the result was something that might be described as a joyous riot.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Tax relief for every income group in the nation -- the rich, the poor and the middle class -- was recommended today by the House Ways and Means Committee.
NORTHWEST INDUSTRIES, in its quest for half the shares of B. F. Goodrich, appears to be moving slowly.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel warned the State Narcotics Addiction Control Commission yesterday that unless it got the addicts under its care out of the Rikers Island Penitentiary and into a "true rehabilitation program," he would order the release of all who had served a year or more.
The General Dynamics Corporation and subsidiaries had a loss of $19,372,000 in the six months ended June 30.
The New York Philharmonic concerts to be played in the parks next week will be led by a man who has not been seen or heard around here for a long time.
