The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation joined yesterday the steel producers reporting reduced earnings for the second quarter and first half of this year.
Negotiators for building contractors and Local 28 of the Sheet Metal Workers resumed negotiations yesterday in an effort to end a strike that began July 1.
The abandoned papyrus raft Ra may still reach the shores of the New World, though without its crew, Thor Heyerdahl, the captain, said here yesterday.

HARRISON, N. Y., July 31 -- The younger generation that has been doing so well on the pro golf circuit this year received a jolt from Tommy Bolt today. The 51-year-old former carpenter, who was the 1958 United States Open champion, led the $250,000 Westchester Classic field with a six-under-par 66.

Just before a House committee last month shelved her bill to punish students and teachers involved in campus disorders, Representative Edith Green of Oregon predicted that if her proposal was not adopted more repressive measures would be proposed. Although her bill was wrong, her prophecy was right.
KAMPALA, Uganda, July 31 -- Between Nov. 15, 1885, and Jan. 27, 1887, 22 Roman Catholic converts were put to death on the orders of the King of Buganda, whose Kingdom now forms part of modern Uganda.
TEL AVIV, July 31 -- Loans and other incentives are to be offered by the Israeli Government to those who establish enterprises in the occupied Arab areas to employ the inhabitants.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 1 -Just an hour down the Connecticut Turnpike, the East Side of Manhattan quivers and winks its neon eye. And who knows? May be even in Fairfield County there are one or three places where the steaks are tender and the music has a beat.
ROME, Aug. 1 -- Italy's caretaker Premier, Mariano Rumor, returned tonight the presidential mandate given him 19 days ago to form a new Government to replace the one he led until its fall July 5.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 1 -- The contention between the National and American Football Leagues picks up again tomorrow night with the first two of the 33 inter-league preseason games scheduled over the next six weeks.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Aug. 1 -- Two players from lower Connecticut, Dick Siderowf of Aspetuck and Jerry Courville of Shorehaven, and two Westchester collegians, Greg Zorila of Briar Hall and George (Sandy) Dillon of Sleepy Hollow, made their way into the semi-final round of the 67th Metropolitan amateur golf championship today.

IF you're looking for a rationale for holding onto your American Telephone and Telegraph shares -- the stock touched its 1969 low in midweek before the stock market began its rally -- you might just say: "I'll go along with the pros."

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., the giant Dallas-based conglomerate, announced yesterday that it had obtained an extension of loans totaling $110-million that the company owes to a group of 25 major banks. The debts came due this week.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Pierre Cardin and Hubert de Givenchy have joined that pack of Paris couturiers who are showing lots of long skirts and long coats in their collections for winter. But any comparison between the two men, and the clothes they dream up, stops right there.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- There are indications that the United States is testing the enemy's willingness to scale down the Vietnam war gradually by reducing its own large offensive operations during the current battlefield lull.

HOUSTON, Aug. 1 -- The doctor who has been quarantined with the Apollo 11 astronauts since they splashed down in the Pacific and who is tending to the world's three most famous patients is a thwarted bush pilot who decided to combine medicine and aviation.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Mayor W. W. Dumas imposed a curfew on Baton Rouge today for the second straight day to stop sniping and fire bombing. He said anyone caught looting or burning would be shot.

THE young blonde was playing her own obscure game this June night at Bachelors III, weaving among the back tables with slightly vacant, slightly hysterical eyes. Casually, she slipped onto a banquette next to O.J. Simpson.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- With the boos of 74,208 spectators as background music, the New York Jets struggled to defend their stature as the world champions of pro football with a 26-24 victory over the College All-Stars tonight in the 36th annual game at Soldier Field.
PASSIVE leads are usually indicated against suit contracts, but circumstances will often indicate that the risk of losing a trick by making an attacking lead is worth taking.

Your July 20 coverage of the accident involving Senator Kennedy, which appeared in the Sunday issue of July 20, was comprehensive and informative. Until this paper arrived at our home in Alpine, Calif., we had only the usual biased and incomplete account offered in the local San Diego newspaper.

KINSHASA, the Congo, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Justin Bomboko, political survivor of countless coups and countercoups since this former Belgian colony became independent in 1960, was replaced today as Foreign Minister in a sweeping cabinet shuffle by President Joseph D. Mobutu.
KAMPALA, Uganda, Aug. 1 -- Pope Paul VI attacked racial discrimination today as a "manifest and inadmissible affront to the fundamental rights of the human person."
The city yesterday began enforcing the new law restricting fuel oil sold here to types with a low sulphur content -- 1 per cent of sulphur or less.
A number of top-ranking Democrats urged their party yesterday to give young people a greater role in the party structure and in policy-making.

WIMBLEDON, England, Aug. 1 -- In a decisive doubles triumph, Brazil leads Britain, 2 to 1, in the Davis Cup interzone semi-final and now suddenly emerges as a potential opponent of the United States in the challenge round at Cleveland in September.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- A recently completed draft treaty to expand Nordic economic cooperation with a customs union and joint financial institutions is facing a doubtful future in Scandinavian capitals.

In the untimely death of Mary Jo Kopechne, associated with so much discussion and speculation of national concern, it seems most unfortunate that no autopsy was performed. More than that, it is incredible that this important procedure was neglected -- and, even more, that it is not legally compulsory in all such cases.

Pan American World Airways reported yesterday that 5,000 feet of motion picture film of Thor Heyerdahl's voyage on the papyrus raft Ra, mislaid last Tuesday, had been found in a workshop at the airport.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Three of the young women who went to an ill-fated cookout with Senator Edward M. Kennedy and his friends say they saw only two cars at the cottage on Chappaquiddick Island that night.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 1 -The sponsors of the Newport Music Festival are correct. There is indeed something sublimely right in listening to such pieces as Sir Arthur Sullivan's Grand Duo Concertante and the Saint-Saens tarantella in the great halls of The Breakers and The Elms.
Several weeks before Pope Paul VI left for Uganda, a Vatican official remarked, "The importance of the trip is that it's not very important."
When Boston's Carl Yastrzemski was caught trying to score in the first inning last night, he wasn't just out at the plate. He was also out of the game.
Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for legislation to give the Office of Collective Bargaining the power of "final and binding" arbitration in contract disputes between the city and its employes.
Harry R. Seelen has been appointed to the new position of division vice president of international development and glass operations at RCA.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The Executive Commission of the European Economic Community, playing a more active role in antitrust enforcement, today accused 10 European dyestuff manufacturers of price fixing and levied fines of the equivalent of $490,000.

One of the two corporations that claim the right to collect rents from elderly people in an apartment house built with 100 per cent Federal aid has accused officers and members of the other corporation of illegally using government funds to pay $80,000 to an insurance company that was not entitled to the payment.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The field for the Whitney Stakes will be headed by Verbatim when the 1 1/2-mile test for older horses has its 42d running tomorrow. Only five will compete, a disappointming number indeed for the first Saturday program of the meeting.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan yesterday ruled invalid the election of Luis Fuentes as unit administrator by the governing board of the Two Bridges Demonstration District.

The managing director of The New York Philharmonic, which has been charged with racial discrimination in hiring musicians, told a City Commission on Human Rights hearing yesterday that he did not believe in the use of screens during auditions for orchestra members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Justice Department filed a lawsuit today against Georgia to require its state school officials to complete the abolition of the racially dual public school system there. This was the first Federal suit against a state board of education. It is part of the Nixon Administration's shift of emphasis from cutoffs of funds to use of the courts in desegregating schools.
EUTAW, Ala., Aug. 1 -- While Justice Department observers looked on, Greene County, Ala., passed from white control to Negro control today for the first time in its 153-year history.
ALGIERS, July 29 -- Al Fatah, the Arab commando group, has begun a drive to spur anti-Israeli sentiment among black African nations represented at the Pan-African Cultural Festival here.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Federal complaint charging a 32-year-old prisoner with hijacking a Trans World Airlines jetliner over Wichita yesterday was filed today.

The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday "modest improvements" in net income for the quarter and six months ended June 30. Operating revenues in both periods ran higher than in the comparable periods of 1968.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 --A telespectrograph, which discloses conditions encountered by a vehicle re-entering the atmosphere from space, is being installed at the White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico.

BOSTON, Aug. 1 -- Chief Justice G. Joseph Tauro of the Massachusetts Superior Court refused today a request by District Attorney Edmund Dinis for an inquest in the death of a Washington secretary in an automobile accident July 18 involving Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
LOS ANGELES -- Richard, or Big Tree, as he is sometimes called, was working as a chemist for a mining company several years ago. He lived in a sumptuous Hollywood apartment and drove a Jaguar.
Unusually heavy rainfall last month failed to dampen shopper's enthusiasm. As a result, New York's major department stores finished the month with a substantial average gain in sales.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 1 -- Student leaders here said today that their annual Day of Affirmation of Academic and Human Freedom might have to be canceled next month if the guest speaker, Representative Ogden R. Reid, Republican of Westchester, was not allowed to speak.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Sharply defined return pulses were recorded early today from the laser reflector left on the moon by the Apollo 11 astronauts. This made it possible to establish without question the location of the landing site.

New York Typographical Union No. 6 plans to ask "substmtial' age increases, monthly rather than annual cost-of-living adjustments and numerous other contract improvements in its forthcoming negotiations with the city's newspapers
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 1 -- Mariner 7, with one of its pressure tanks apparently pierced by a meteorite and with a certain amount of internal damage, is plunging toward Mars faster than scheduled.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Representatives of major wheat-producing nations met in London today in an effort to forestall disorderly market conditions and the collapse of the year-old International Grains Arrangement.
Thursday's rally on Wall Street was reflected yesterday in firmer prices on the London Stock Exchange.

New York City is facing once again a perennially painful question: how long can it and should it maintain its subway and bus fares at their present level? If arithmetic means anything, the twenty-cent fare is doomed, but arithmetic does not always hold the answer to a question so intertwined with politics.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed today two separate anti-trust suits aimed at preventing the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation from acquiring the Hartford Fire Insurance Company and the Grinnell Corporation.
Just when life in the big leagues began to seem very hostile, the New York Mets snapped out of a four-game losing streak last night by defeating the Atlanta Braves, 5-4.

Mayor Lindsay has offered the job of adjudicating landlord-tenant disputes under the city's new rent law to Judah Gribetz, a 40-year-old lawyer who resigned in June as the top Federal housing official in the Northeast.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- Governor Rockefeller today rejected a plea by Mayor Lindsay and others that he ask a special legislative session to find more money to meet transportation, welfare, Medicaid and education problems now facing New York City and other local governments.
The 96-foot sloop Clearwater, her green hull cleanly slicing through the fetid waters of New York harbor, sailed into port yesterday as part of a low-key fight against pollution of the Hudson River.
Jazz floated out across a breeze-swept pier on the East River last night at the first of four weekly concerts sponsored by the South Street Seaport Museum.

TRENTON, Aug. 1 -- A manufacturing plant employing 13 people in Clifton, N.J., has been ordered, in effect, to close permanently for polluting the air, according to Richard J. Sullivan, director of New Jersey's Division of Clean Air and Water.

VIENNA -- When politicians seek to outdo one another in supporting the arts, you know that a nation is agreed on the importance of the arts. In this city, the conservative Peoples (Catholic) party, which controls the national government, and the liberal Social Democratic party, which dominates the city government, express the country's consensus that its cultural institutions are among its prime ornaments.
HOUSTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Two more technicians joined the Apollo 11 crew in quarantine today because of a vacuum chamber accident that exposed them to moon rocks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Oil seeping from the Pacific Ocean floor in California's Santa Barbara Channel has been reduced from about 1,100 gallons a day to 450 gallons through emergency measures, Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Air France was accused today of violating the Federal Aviation Act by denying a Negro the right to take part in an air tour to Africa.
LAHORE, Pakistan Aug. 1 -- An obviously concerned Nixon Administration is turning to the Soviet Union for help in preventing the collapse of the fragile coalition in Laos.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Aug. 1 -- The Board of Bishops of the million-member African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church, one of the nation's major Negro Protestant denominations, rejected today the demands of James Forman, the black activist leader, for $3-billion "reparations" from white churches in payment for past oppression.
HOUSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Following are the names of the 19 men quarantined in the Mobile Quarantine Facility:

THE stucco cottage -- halfway through resurrection -- sits a little vagrantly under a maple tree on a quiet street in the northeast Bronx. Inside the cottage, ranged around the kitchen table, is the family.

KAMPALA, Uganda, Saturday, Aug. 2 -- Pope Paul VI met last night with representatives of the Nigerian Federal Government, but he appeared to have made no progress toward a settlement of the civil war that has wracked Africa's most populous nation for two years.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Superior Court judge affirmed today the demotion of a Seabright police chief accused of having had an illicit affair with a councilman's wife.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- French leftists have mounted a fierce rhetorical attack on John Wayne's Vietnam war film, "The Green Berets," which is now entrenched at seven Parisian movie theaters.
Charges of obscenity have been brought against the Garrick Theatre staff for exhibiting the new Andy Warhol film, "Blue Movie."
RIFTON, N.Y., Aug. 1 -"Other kids in the high school have a lot of funny ideas about us," said Else Arnold as she ground some freshly picked cucumbers. "Like some think we live in huts."

President Nixon's one-day "splashdown" in New Delhi this week focused attention on India's international role. Once that role is fully understood by the American Government, our policies in all of Asia will become more realistic.

In ordering the dismemberment of the Naval Applied Science Laboratory in Brooklyn, the Navy Department has launched a ship full of holes. There appears to be no good reason for such action -- not an economic, social or military one -- and excellent arguments against it.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 1 -Taking dead aim on second, third or fourth money, four more horses were entered today for tomorrow's $100,000 Monmouth Invitational Handicap, in which Arts and Letters will make his first appearance since his victory in the Belmont Stakes on June 7.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 24 -- Jovan Bulj has gone on vacation. Normally, the tall, smiling policeman can be found directing traffic through the heart of Belgrade with the deft grace of a ballet dancer manque.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Senator J. W. Fulbright and George Meany argued heatedly for nearly three hours today, but they parted with a handshake.

One of the traditional fringe benefits enjoyed by railroad employes -- free passes on other lines -- is fast disappearing as the lines look for ways to raise revenues, railroad officials said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- The Intelsat 3 communications satellite in orbit over the Atlantic Ocean was restored to service today after a month-long blackout, according to the Communications Satellite Corporation.
Ten thousand shipyard workers along the Eastern Coast are deadlocked in new contract discussions with three shipyards.

The Travelers Corporation, one of the largest life and casualty insurance companies in the United States, is negotiating to acquire the Randolph Computer Corporation, which is involved in computer leasing, software development and data processing education.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 1 -- Rumania will be President Nixon's host tomorrow during a highly controversial overnight stay, and this nation's leaders are understood to hope that the visit will mark the beginning of a new look in East-West relations.
ROME, Aug. 1 -- Following as made public here by the Vatican, are excerpts from an address to African heads of state in Kampala, Uganda, today by Pope Paul VI:

I cannot agree with Philip Sisk's statement [news story July 29] that Paul Markham and Joseph F. Gargan would have breached lawyer's "ethics," to have made known the facts of the Martha's Vineyard accident without Senator Kennedy's consent. What is the president of the Massachusetts Bar Association trying to tell us -- that lawyers have a sort of "honor among thieves" code?
Two major advertising accounts with total billings of some $30-million were assigned to new agencies yesterday.

IN the middle of summer, when women need fewer clothes, the beauty people have their day. Like sirens, they call out from their salons and cosmetics counters: Why don't you do something about your hair, your face, your body?
The metals markets appear confusing these days, and yesterday a price change in both palladium and copper pointed up that fact.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Productivity in the American economy declined in the second quarter, marking the first time there has been a drop for two consecutive quarters since 1960, the Labor Department reported today.
WOODBURY, N.J., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A 20-year-old college girl was found Thursday was murdered, the Gloucester County Prosecutor said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- A United States official said today that the American Embassy in Saigon was "embarrassed" by the fact that the South Vietnamese radio broadcast a live account of President Nixon's visit here Wednesday while all international communications were cut off.

For the third time this year, the price of primary copper is going up again. It appears certain that the move will bring about still higher brass mill prices for products used widely in homes and industry.

A wide range of fare reductions between the United States and the Far East was proposed yesterday by Pan American World Airways. The cuts would range from 5 to 23 per cent. The plan is subject to the approval of the Governments concerned.

GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it had drafted new proposals "which may reasonably be expected to permit the start of daylight relief flights to Biafra."

OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 1 -- "Take any boy, start him down the river and right away he loves it. Then show him what man has done to the river and the boy changes his image of man. It's something he'll never forget."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Top Treasury officials hailed today the tax reform and relief bill completed by the House Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- A private New York researcher asked Congress today to ban pesticides that he said were chemically related to nerve gas and were spreading death and injury among farmer and suburban gardeners.

The agreement to extend the income surtax through December 31, which will take final shape in a House-Senate conference early next week, is not without virtues. It puts an end to a political war of nerves and should dispel some of the uncertainty that has disrupted the financial markets. It insures automatic review in the event that an economic slowdown by the year's end obviates the need for higher taxes.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Is this the year Clark Graebner finally sheds his single curse in the Eastern grass-court tennis championship?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Navy chose the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation today for a potential $3.2-billion program to build a fleet of advanced antisubmarine warfare planes capable of dealing with a growing Soviet submarine threat in the 1970's.
Another 11-point rise sparked the stock market yesterday, marking the second straight day of big gains on the Big Board

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Marty Fleckman of Port Arthur, Tex., neatly sank a six-footer on the 18th green today for a birdie 4, thus holding his second-round score in the Westchester Classic to 85 -- his worst in two years on the tour.

Sutton Terrace, a three-building complex of luxury apartments on York Avenue between 62d and 63d Streets, was sold yesterday to six East Side hospitals and educational centers for eventual use as a staff and faculty residence.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Enemy forces in South Vietnam are destroying helicopters and fixed-winged planes at about the same rate as they were before a lull in ground fighting began seven weeks ago, United States statistics showed today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman said last night that Thailand would like to withdraw her 12,000 combat troops from South Vietnam because of the burdens she faces at home.
Charges of insubordination against a Long Island Rail Road conductor who refused to order an overloaded train out of Pennsylvania Station have been dropped.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- An angry Soviet Ambassador was unwilling today to accept an assurance from Britain's Foreign Secretary that Anatoly V. Kuznetsov, the Russian author who has defected, did not want to meet a Soviet representative.
In your July 27 editorial concerning Senator Edward Kennedy's tragic accident on Chappaquiddick Island you demand from the Senator explanations of conduct that no human being could possibly give.

HARRISON, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Charles Herbert Greene, a member of the younger corps of the touring professionals moved Tommy Bolt out of the lead in the Westchester Golf Classic today with a 36-hole aggregate of 136.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The weather cleared here yesterday, as it did in other sun-starved parts of the Northeast. But at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, there was an extra reason for rejoicing: Last night was the opening night of the Philadelphia Orchestra's four-week season here.

DETROIT, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A physician who collected $169,000 in Medicaid fees in one year has returned the full amount pending an audit, because of crank letters and what he termed harassment of his family.

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 1 -With so much glory -- and money -- at stake in tomorrow night's $90,170.64 Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway, nothing is being left to chance where Nevele Pride is concerned.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 1 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers left today for Taipei, the next stop on his Asian tour, after a 26-hour visit here during which he repeatedly reassured the South Koreans of prompt help from the United States in case of an attack.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk's announced decision to resign as Chief of State of Cambodia appeared today to have been simply a threat, not a fact.
LAHORE, Pakistan, Saturday, Aug. 2 -- President Nixon completed the Asian phase of his world tour and departed from here this morning for Bucharest, Rumania.
YPSILANTI, Mich., Aug. 1 -- A 22-year-old college senior who likes to ride a motorcycle was charged today with the murder of an Eastern Michigan University coed.
PRAGUE, Aug. 1 -- The Most Rev. Frantisek Tomasek, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Czechoslovakia, left by air today for Rome amid reports that delicate church-state negotiations were under way.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The United States is willing to try to return Okinawa to Japan by 1972 but the issue of nuclear bases on the island remains open, a Japanese Government official said today.

MANILA, Aug, 1 -- The Philippine police said today that they battled Hukbalahap dissidents early this morning in Cadiz, a town in the southern province of Negros Occidental. You remember Mark Strand's poem about the "blue-eyed government," and it's very much in evidence here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Enemy saboteurs touched off a huge explosive charge under a bridge 40 miles southeast of Saigon today wrecking nearly half of the 210-foot span and cutting traffic on Highway 15, one of South Vietnam's busiest roads.

OTTAWA -- The failure of a new $105-million American-designed heavy water plant in Nova Scotia to come into production has dismayed Federal authorities here and embarrassed officials in the economically depressed Atlantic province.

FIRE ISLAND, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Two hundred playful Fire Island activists staged a brief invasion today of the staid community of Point O'Woods, long regarded as a fortress of exclusiveness in this free-wheeling vacation spot.

FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Aug. 3 -- Dressed comfortably in short-sleeved shirts, no jackets, open collars and looking calm and cool, the Berkshire String Quartet gave a warm concert at Music Mountain here yesterday afternoon.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3 -- Pierre Boulez ran into expensive overtime while rehearsing for the Boston Symphony concert he conducted at Tanglewood last night, and eyebrows rose in upper management echelons.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State Rogers closed his two-day visit to Taiwan today with a news conference in which he affirmed United States willingness to have more friendly relations with all nations, including Communist China.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- An American pacifist in Hanoi, Renard G. Davis, reported today in a telegram to the Associated Press in Tokyo that North Vietnam had released several captive American pilots to the pacifist group sent to receive them.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Scientists at the Lick Observatory said yesterday that they had measured the distance between the earth and the moon at 226,970.9 miles by bouncing laser beams off a mirror placed on the moon by two of the Apollo 11 astronauts.
Americans are taking a forgiving view of Senator Edward M. Kennedy after his automobile accident July 18, the Louis Harris polling organization reports in today's issue of Time magazine.

A new method for shipping fine ore concentrates in slurry or liquid suspension, form has been developed by a San Francisco-based mining and transportation company. Marcona Corporation.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Aug. 3 -- The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia outlasted the Union Boat Club of Boston today and regained the Hanlan Memorial Trophy in the senior eight-oared 2,000-meter event of the 87th Royal Canadian Henley regatta.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Union workers at two Fort Worth area aerospace plants accepted contracts today offered by their companies.

DAVID FROST, the London bachelor with the mid-Atlantic accent, might just possibly upset, the status quo in television talk shows, the potpourri of vaudeville and chitchat that is proving such a contagious format in American television.

MONTREAL, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Gary Sutherland beat the throw to the plate on Mack Jones's ninth inning grounder today, giving the Montreal Expos a 1-0 victory over the Houston Astro's in the second game of a double-header.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 -- The General Motors Corporation reported today that its car sales in the final third of July and in the full month fell well below last year's evels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The defense industries were well represented among the signers of a prominently circulated newspaper advertisement promoting the Nixon Administration's antiballistic missile defense proposal.

The recent reverses of Mill Factors Corporation could reap a small harvest of dollars for its 1,374 unhappy stockholders if they act expeditiously.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Aug. 3 -- Pope Paul VI, waving his arms in a rare display of exuberance, said today the greatest thing about his visit to Uganda had been the warmth of his reception by the African people.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 3 -- Following are the texts of a statement issued jointly today by the Governments of Rumania and the United States at the conclusion of President Nixon's visit here and of farewell remarks by Mr. Nixon and President Nicolae Ceausescu. Mr. Ceausescu spoke in Rumanian through a translator:

Concerned with the over-compensation of some managers serving abroad, many United States companies are taking a closer look at what they are paying their men overseas, a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board has found.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Beaming and bare-headed in a driving rain, President Nixon returned home tonight from his trip around the world and invoked the "the spirit of Apollo," which, he said, "can bring the people of the world together in peace."

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- Frank Beard received applause today under gray skies. After all, he did win the $50,000 first prize in the Westchester Classic. But the loud, spontaneous hand-clapping was for the runner-up, unheralded Bert Greene.

Charles J. Urstadt, Commissioner of Housing and Community Renewal, has stated (letter July 18) that housing for the low and moderate income families "consigned to substandard, overcrowded housing in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Crown Heights, East New York, Brownsville and Ocean Hill" must take priority over the municipal park for Jamaica.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 3 -- John Unitas is back, his arm intact. The 36-year-old quarterback of the Baltimore Colts worked the second quarter here last night against the San Diego Chargers and completed seven out of eight passes for 86 yards as his team won, 26-6.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A move is under way to make Death Row less lonely in New Jersey.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 3 -- In one of the most tightly waged contests ever played in the final, Dick Siderowf of Westport, Conn., won the 67th annual Metropolitan amateur golf championship today by defeating his good friend, Jerry Courville of Norwalk, 2 and 1.

NELSON, New Zealand, Aug. 3 (Reuthers) -- Prince Tuipelehake, the Prime Minister of Tonga, scoffed today at reports that three New Zealanders had found a treasure worth millions of dollars off the coast of his Pacific Island country.
HONG KONG, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers today reiterated the willingness of the United States to talk with Communist China, but held out no hope of any early response from Peking.

SEATTLE, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Miss Budweiser, with Bill Sterett driving, turned in a flawless performance on Lake Washington today to win the 45-mile annual Seattle Seafair Trophy race for unlimited hydroplanes. The victory was worth $5,900.
Th United States Information Agency is shifting the emphasis of its overseas propaganda from motion pictures to television.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Skirting some of its own guidelines, the Farmers Home Administration has approved a $265,000 loan guarantee for a golf course in the district of a Mississippi Congressman whose subcommittee controls the agency's budget.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Three skippers won both of their races today when the Pequot Yacht Club's annual Junior Blue Jay Class regatta be gan on Long Island Sound. A fleet of 105 of the 13 1/2-foot sloops sailed in the four divisions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The president of Brandeis University told Congress today that it could help end campus turmoil by extricating this country from Vietnam and channeling the energies or an idealistic generation into a "human service" corps.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 22 -- After years of unsatisfactory relations with the United States, Cambodia's Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, was once moved to comment: "What characterizes the policy of the Americans, with respect to us, is their total ignorance of our mentality, of our situation and of our hopes."

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Wearing a tennis dress sprinkled with 20 tiny shamrocks and a ponytail tied with kelly green yarn, Patti Hogan won her most impressive tournament title today at the Eastern grass-court championships.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The French, who are supposed to know how to live, are furnishing a good example in the railway service they offer vacationing motorists.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 4 -- Bad music can be fun, too, and the Newport Music Festival, which has been looking at a good deal of music by minor romantic composers, has come up with a few dillies. To counterbalance these, there also have been a few discoveries.

Theodore W. Parker, who as an Army general supervised the build-up and movement of forces in the United States during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962, yesterday was named New York State's new Commissioner of Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to the Senate today a bill granting authority to increase veterans' educational training allowances by an average of 27 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Hamer H. Budge, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, defended today his actions in considering a job offer from a group of mutual funds that the commission regulates, the group managed by Investors Diversified Services.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- Top French officials received lengthy briefings today on President Nixon's round-the-world trip from his chief foreign policy adviser, Henry A. Kissinger. An official visit to Washington early next year by President Pompidou was the most concrete announcement to be made by Mr. Kissinger after his talks with the President, Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas and Foreign Minister Maurice Schumann.

HANOVER, N. H., Aug. 4 -- The Dartmouth College Board of Trustees, acting on the recommendation of a faculty committee, has voted to suspend two assistant professors for two years each for their participation in the occupation of the college's administration building in a protest against R.O.T.C. May 6.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- New-car sales in the final third of July trailed last year, leaving sales for the full month well below the 1968 levels, the four major automobile makers reported today.

MANILA, Aug. 4 -- President Nixon's statement that the United States would seek to avoid gradual involvement in future guerrilla insurrections in Southeast Asia appears to have left only small shock waves in the region after his visit last week to three of its countries.

The proposed Tax Reform Act of 1969 falls far short of being an ideal blueprint for equality in taxation. One of the gaping loopholes in the present code is not affected at all, and others are narrowed inadequately. But the very fact that the Ways and Means Committee, which rarely suffers a reverse on the House floor, reported out so comprehensive a measure is itself a sign of genuine progress.
SWEDESBORO, N. J., Aug. 4 (AP) -- More than 400 people attended the funeral today at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church of Jeanne Leonardi, a 20-year-old coed who was found murdered Thursday.

Kinney National Service, Inc., which last month acquired Warner Bros. - Seven Arts, Ltd., has appointed Ted Ashley as chairman and chief executive officer of the film company, Steven J. Ross, president of Kinney, announced yesterday.

TOKYO, Aug. 4 -- All Japan's opposition parties, major universities, newspapers and educational organizations criticized the Government and the ruling Liberal-Democratic party today for the forcible passage last night of the controversial bill on university administration. The port of New York Authority confirmed yesterday that it was negotiating with an organization of supplemental airlines over a new passenger terminal for those lines at Kennedy International Airport.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Britain's gold and foreign-exchange reserves increased by the equivalent of $33.6-million in July, to $2.48-billion, the Treasury announced today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The Cedar Point Yacht Club crew of Westport, Conn., captained by Laurie Jackson, sailed into an 8-point lead in the qualifying series today as the 28th Long Island Sound girls' championship regatta began with four races off Belle Haven Club.

NOEL, Mo., Aug. 4 -- Residents surveying the rubble of this Ozark town wondered aloud today why train explosions continue in a technological age.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The unemployment rate for the nation rose to 3.6 per cent last month from 3.4 per cent in June, according to figures released today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Nevertheless, the bureau reported employment continued to show "moderate strength" in July.

THE recent Denver Open Tourney, a seven-round Swiss system with 74 players, was a clean 7-0 sweep for the young San Francisco star, Jude Acers. David Baker of Denver was second with 6-1 and the Wyoming expert Robert Wendling was third with 5 1/2-1 1/2.

The recent decision of our Mayor to drop the Lower Manhattan Expressway and the Board of Estimate's rejection of the Second Avenue subway as recommended to them, suggests that we are going about the business of planning in Lower Manhattan in the wrong way.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company awarded the General Electric Company a contract yesterday for two nuclear reactors rated at 1.1 million kilowatts each. The utility said it had not yet selected a site for the plant, which is expected to be operating in 1975-77.

OTTAWA, Aug. 6 -- Canada is replacing the ambassador who has been conducting talks in Stockholm aimed at establishing diplomatic relations with Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Nixon asked Congress today to establish a new Federal agency that would impose health and safety standards to protect American workers if the states failed to do so themselves.

HANCOCK, Mass. -- Although the Shaker culture is not nearly so famous as that of, say, the Pennsylvania Dutch, it represents one of the most fascinating aspects of American life. Oddly enough, it has a tremendous audience among foreigners.

Municipal bond prices continued to move upward yesterday, and San Francisco's $72-million transit financing -- written off last week as an almost certain casualty of its 6 per cent rate limitation -- was sold at an interest cost of 5.842 per cent.

Bobby Murcer's sudden hot streak, which began Tuesday night with a game-winning ninth-inning home run against the California Angels, continued yesterday in the Yankees' 3-1 triumph over the Angels at Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Aug. 6 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany will be honored at a state dinner tomorrow at the White House. On Friday, he will be host to Vice President and Mrs. Agnew at a dinner at the German Embassy. "No. I'm not uptight to the music. I have the words, but I don't have the thing yet."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- President Nixon was reported to have told Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany today that Soviet opposition would not inhibit the United States from dealing directly with the Communist nations of Eastern Europe.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Detroit City Council President, Ed Carey, a former automobile worker who rose to a position of power and influence in Detroit, withdrew today from the mayoral race after suffering a heart attack.

The Consolidated Edison Company is planning to apply for an increase of about 15 per cent in electric rates sometime before Sept. 1.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 7 -- Bob Lutz of Los Angeles used 17 service aces and a sweeping backhand that hit winning shots late in the match to defeat George Goven of France, 11-9, 2-6, 7-5, today in the quarter-final round of the Meadow Club's 80th men's invitation grass court tennis tournament.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante, leader of a Mafia family in New Jersey, has been convicted in Princeton Township Municipal Court for speeding -- driving 52 miles an hour in a 45-mile-an-hour zone near his home on Mercer Road.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Senator Charles E. Goodell has undertaken a major effort to try to mend fences with a discontented Republican organization in New York State.

LONDON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Jimmy Ellis, the World Boxing Association heavyweight champion, and Henry Cooper of England, the European champion, will meet in a 15-round non-title fight at Wembley Stadium on Saturday, Sept. 27, it was announced today by the promoter, Harry Levene.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The Justice Department said today that it did not intend to ask the Supreme Court to reverse the acquittal of Dr. Benjamin Spock and Michael Ferber on charges of conspiring to counsel evasion of the draft.

MURRAY HILL, N. J., Aug. 8 -- Bell Telephone Laboratories will patent tomorrow a technological process to produce tiny disks of magnetic energy, called "bubbles," that it believes may one day perform the work of a conventional computer or a telephone switching system

HARTSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot and Mrs. Harold Kilpatrick of New Canaan reached the final today of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's 47th annual championship at the Scarsdale Golf Club.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- The United States, British and French Embassies announced today that they had made formal approaches to the Soviet Union in a search for ways to reduce tensions over Berlin and to bring East and West Germany closer together.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Louis R. Bruce Jr. of New York City, whose father was a Mohawk and whose mother was an Oglala Sioux, was named today to be Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 7 -- The split within India's governing Congress party has widened over the last several days, and the two sides -- those aligned with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and those with the old-guard state bosses of the party -- have taken to trading public insults.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 10 -- The field for the $100,000 International Trot, which will be contested next Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway, was completed today with entrants from West Germany, the Netherlands and a second representative from France.

As suggested in your July 29 editorial, it is not too late to stop MIRV. Philip J. Farley, the President's appointee to Deputy Director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, in his testimony before a House foreign affairs subcommittee raises two questions.
SKOWHEGAN, Me., Aug. 10 -- Mayor Lindsay of New York said here today that he thought his re-election campaign was "moving up a little bit" in his favor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Ralph Nader said today that thousands of cotton textile workers suffered from byssinosis, or "brown lung" disease. He said that the textile industry did not concede until this year that the disease existed among its workers.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The bodies of a young woman and two sons were found today in the rubble left by a tornado that tore through nine miles of the Cincinnati suburbs last night. Another woman died of injuries suffered when her car was blown over by high winds.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 -- The steel market is showing new firmness and strength.

The runaway victory won by the old-line Civil Service Employes Association in elections to pick bargaining representatives for 137,000 New York State employes is a repudiation at the state level of the kind of militant tactics that have kept New York City's relations with its unionized public workers in perpetual turmoil.

Further speculation on what happened at Chappaquiddick Island on the night of July 18 is morbid for the country and unjust for Senator Kennedy. But unless the public is given more facts and the Senator directly answers a number of questions, both the speculation and the injustice will continue.
ATHENS, Aug. 10 -- Alarmed by a widening trade gap this year, Greece's army-backed regime has taken drastic action to stem the inflow of costly imports causing a heavy drain on its dollar reserves.
Action by the House Ways and Means Committee to retain accelerated depreciation for apartment house construction will encourage investor funds for the type of housing so needed in New York City.
HOUSTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The Apollo 11 astronauts got out of quarantine today, but the lunar rocks and dirt they picked up July 20 remained locked behind germ-proof barriers.

On that eventual day when the first men walk on the surface of Mars, they will find much "magnificent desolation" akin to that seen by Neil Armstrong and Edwin Aldrin when they strolled on the moon last month.

The Columbia Broadcasting System said yesterday that it would accept a tobacco industry plan to stop broadcasting cigarette advertising by the end of the year if the plan received Congressional approval.

HOMESTEAD, Fla. -- At the bottom of Florida, beyond the burgeoning Miami suburbs, past the last television tower, the last alligatorium, the last serpentarium, the last used car lot, the last snakorama and pancake house, is a wonderfully quiet place where the only offending spoor of civilization is a rusty litter of beer cans along the infrequent trails.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10 -- Clark Graebner, playing near the top of his form, put together three hot streaks that propelled him past a subpar Bob Lutz today in the men's singles final of the 80th Meadow Club invitation tournament.

BRAINERD, Minn., Aug. 10 -- David Hobbs of England won the Donnybrooke Grand Prix today in a wild closing sprint in which the runner-up, Tony Adamowicz of Wilton, Conn., crossed the finish line leaving a wake of smoke.
The little guy, that fellow whose stock market speculations never get past four digits, is in trouble on Wall Street.

The chairman of the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday that he would request a meeting soon, possibly this week, with city, state and Federal officials to find agreement on the utility's plans for increasing generating capacity in the next 10 years.
ROME, Aug. 10 -- Italy's 30th postwar Government -- a Christian Democratic Cabinet headed by Mariano Rumor as Premier -- won its first parliamentary vote of confidence today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mickey Lolich, backed by a 14-hit attack, including Norm Cash's 16th homer, checked the Chicago White Sox with four hits today and hurled the Detroit Tigers to an 8-2 victory and a sweep of the four-game series.

DALLAS, Aug. 10 -- President Nixon's decision to name a new Supreme Court Justice without consulting the American Bar Association drew mild criticism today from the incoming president of the bar group.

Moscow is evidently preparing a new stage of humiliation for conquered Czechoslovakia. As the first anniversary of last August's Soviet invasion nears, signs mount that the stage is being set for an official Prague declaration that it was Alexander Dubcek and his collaborators who were at fault, that it was their political and personal weaknesses that forced Moscow to "save socialism" in Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- "Signposts from this Administration point to a dead end for the consumer," according to a report issued today by 17 liberal House Democrats. The attack on President Nixon was coupled with 30 legislative proposals for consumer protection.
SEATTLE -- "There are a lot of people pretending very hard and very fast that Seattle is a big league town," said Diane Lindsley, a college student clerking in a downtown bookstore.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Billy Martin, manager of the Minnesota Twins, disclosed today he knocked out Dave Boswell, a Twins' pitcher, during a fight in Detroit last Wednesday after Boswell had socked and kicked Bob Allison, an outfielder with the club.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- Conservationists are challenging the system under which the Federal Government has built many billions of dollars' worth of dams and irrigation and navigation projects over the last two generations.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Aug. 11 -- North Vietnamese troops attacked two United States Marine bases along the demilitarized zone with grenades and dynamite bombs yesterday, inflicting the heaviest American losses in the area in five and a half months.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Britain's experience in managing her economy following the devaluation of the pound offers lessons for the French authorities, who will face similar problems following devaluation of the franc.

Striking ground employes of Pan American World Airways began voting last night on a tentative contract, but the largest group of strikers, those in New York, will not begin to vote until late this morning.
The recent Broadway tendency toward bringing back popular plays of the 1920's and 1930's is continuing into the 1969-70 season.

ZELTWEG, Austria, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- Jo Siffert of Switzerland and his co-driver, Kurt Ahrens of West Germany, assured Porsche today of the 1969 sports car manufacturers' championship when they drove their giant Porsche 917 to victory in the 1,000 - kilometer (620 - mile) Austrian Grand Prix.
BONN, Aug. 10 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger reasserted before his key economic ministers and the public today that the mark would not be revalued upward.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 10 -- One of the longest legislative sessions in state history ended early yesterday after California lawmakers had approved Gov. Ronald Reagan's proposal for an $87-million election-year rebate to state personal income taxpayers.

Governor Rockefeller charged yesterday that President Nixon's welfare reform proposals would shortchange New York and other industrial states that were bearing the heaviest burden of public aid to the poor.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 10 -- A wave of buying orders from throughout the world is expected when the Johannesburg stock exchange opens tomorrow following the devaluation of the franc on Friday.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mike Taliaferro threw two touchdown passes in the first half today to lead the Boston Patriots to a 21-13 victory over the Cincinnati Pengals in an American Football League exhibition game.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 -- Mike Cuellar pitched a no-hitter for eight innings today before Minnesota's Cesar Tovar singled to open the ninth as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Twins, 2-0.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican-Conservative candidate for Mayor of New York, completed a weekend of campaigning among vacationing city voters at Catskill Mountain resorts today with a brief stop here at the Concord Hotel.
OMAHA, Aug. 10 -- Two Omaha fortune hunters are salvaging a Missouri River steamboat that sank 104 years ago, reportedly with a treasure of gold, quicksilver and whisky aboard.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Don Sutton of the Los Angeles Dodgers, who had been beaten 13 times by Chicago, scattered four hits and got ninth-inning help from Jim Brewer and Pete Mikkelsen today to beat the Cubs, 4-2, for his first victory over them.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 -- A former mental patient bought a shotgun yesterday, then shot his neighbor and five Detroit policemen early this morning from inside his home.

INWOOD, L. I., Aug. 10 -- Four members of a Queens family were killed today when their auto exploded and burned after colliding with what the police said was a stolen station wagon. The other driver was unhurt.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 10 -- The Spingold Knockout Master Team championship began here last night in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, and several top-ranked teams found themselves in danger of failing to qualify for the knockout stages.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The civil war in Nigeria has given an American "packaged disaster hospital" its first test under the conditions for which the self-contained units were originally conceived.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Seven persons were injured this afternoon when the 21-foot pleasure boat in which they were riding caught fire and sank off Premium Point in the Long Island Sound. Two others aboard were uninjured.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Gary Nolan retired the first 18 Phillie batters and finished with a three-hitter today as the Cincinnati Reds gained a 10-0 victory over Philadelphia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 -- Gov. Ronald Reagan, after two and a half years of criticizing campus radicals and administrators, has captured effective working control over California's system of higher education.
New York City's limited supply of reserve power should surprise no one. Consolidated Edison has been warning the public of this danger for the last five years.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has won an economic foothold in the Persian Gulf and a stake in the Iraqi oil industry under a major aid agreement announced in Baghdad, Iraq.

A clergyman whose congregation was among the first to give money to James Forman as "reparations" for past injustices to Negroes said yesterday that the demand for reparation would not succeed, but that he supported Mr. Forman anyway.

NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 10 -- The Newport Music Festival ended last night with a gala concert at The Breakers and also with some good news. During the afternoon the Rhode Island Arts Foundation at Newport had met to consider the future of the festival.

The Miami Dolphins may be playing the exhibition games with the intent of getting ready for the regular American League season, but the Minnesota Vikings and Chicago Bears of the National League have acted as though they were playing for keeps.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- One of my favorite night visions is of a dear sweet old English biddy, living deep in the heart of the British provinces, who used to adore -- indeed, simply adore -- the old-look Ballet Rambert, with its happy version of "Giselle" and its practically delirious production of "Coppelia."

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 10 -- Cornelius (Glit) Shields Jr. built a lead of an eighth of a mile on the opening leg of a 12-mile course today and won with his International Class sloop, Aileen, for the second day in a row.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The French Government today ordered a freeze on prices to accompany the devaluation of the franc, which became formal at 10 o'clock tonight (5 P.M. New York time).
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI) -- President Nixon went for a drive along the coast south of his new Pacific home today, the first full day of his planned month-long working vacation.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Mike Shannon's homer started a four-run rally in the ninth inning today as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the San Francisco Giants, 7 -- 4.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 10 -- The line of fiberglass stock racing yachts identified as Cal, with a numeral depending on size, gained a remarkable sweep today in a race that reintroduced the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club as a sponsor of distance sailing events. The race was to Faulkner Island and back.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The United States took both the men's and the women's individual over-all titles today at the 11th world water ski championships on Lake Bagsvaerd.

Joe Namath intends to remain at quarterback until the Jets are in command of next Sunday's game with the Giants at the Yale Bowl in New Haven.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The International Monetary Fund faces an embarrassment of riches -- too many countries want to give it too much money.

ROME, Aug. 10 -- Unofficial but authoritative Vatican sources said today that the Most Rev. James P. Shannon, former Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul-Minneapolis, became automatically excommunicated from the church at the time of his marriage Aug. 2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Chancellor Kiesinger said today that his Government would do "whatever we can" to support the British pound in the wake of France's devaluation of the franc on Friday. But he again ruled out any upward valuation of the West German mark that might ease the selling pressure on British currency.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it had awarded a contract for the construction of five electric substations that eventually would double the power on the Port Washington branch of the Long Island Rail Road.

An eruption of four Yankee home runs, three hit consecutively, lifted the Bombers to a 5-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics yesterday at the Stadium and moved them to the .500 level for the first time in two months.

The French American Banking Corporation, a Wall Street institution that opened for business 50 years ago last month, has recently expanded its operations by becoming a less exclusive arm of its French owners and interested in doing more business with Americans.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The devaluation of the franc that went officially into effect at 10 o'clock tonight is the 13th devaluation in 41 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Treasury officials said over the weekend that they did not "see any need for or expect any move by any other important currency" following the devaluation of the French franc on Friday.

GARY, Ind., Aug. 10 -- The six-day strike of city firemen ended abruptly late tonight. Firemen returned to duty shortly before midnight after the Gary City Council promised to set up a blue ribbon committee to study ways of improving wages for the 281-man force.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 -- Israeli jets today shattered sections of the Ghor Canal, the most vital irrigation project in Jordan.

The international money markets took the devaluation of the French franc in stride yesterday.

The attempted rape of a police lieutenant's daughter was foiled yesterday by an inquisitive family dog, touching off a chase through the streets of Queens that ended when the alleged assailant was struck over the head with a bottle by an unidentified passer-by.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A reorganization of the Maritime Administration to increase efficiency without increasing the staff was announced today by Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Eleven American newspaper editors will tour the Soviet Union for more than two weeks beginning Aug. 24, under an exchange agreement providing for Soviet editors to visit the United States.

MONTE CARLO, Aug, 11 -- The party Prince Rainier and Princess Grace gave at the Palace yesterday was a casual outdoor luncheon, and although only a few guests actually ventured into the royal pool, everybody seemed to be having a good time.
ATHENS, Aug. 11 -- One symbol of the opposition in Greece these days is a man who is not here -- the United States Ambassador.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Landlords made a last-minute rush yesterday to register their uncontrolled apartments under the city's new rent law before the deadline tonight. After that, unregistered units will be placed under the standard, strict rent-control law.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- An exultant James Cox Brady saw his filly Meritus win the $30,850 Adirondack today, and he was prompt to exclaim, "The right one won this time." The daughter of Bold Ruler registered a five-length triumph in the six-furlong sprint for 2-year-old fillies.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 -- Evidence that the enemy plans a new offensive in the next month or so has been captured recently by the allies, officers here report.
A Brooklyn bar owner foiled an attempted holdup by four men early yesterday by killing one of the men with a shotgun blast. The others fled after a brief gunfight the length of the bar.
The National Broadcasting Company yesterday rejected a tobacco industry plan that would have forced cigarette commercials off the air by the end of the year, but it did offer a plan of its own.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 -- Israeli jet fighter-bombers struck in Lebanon today against sites described as guerrilla encampments. The air strikes were the first against sites in Lebanon in what the Israelis term their policy of retaliation.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- The new Communist party chief for Soviet Azerbaijan has charged that the Transcaucasian Republic is rife with corruption and is suffering from large-scale mismanagement.
The Quaker Oats Company, a leading producer of cereals and foods, announced yesterday its first major diversification outside of the food field since 1942.

The Long Island Rail Road, starting the first full week of its attempt to fulfill Governor Rockefeller's promise of the best railroad service in the country within the next two months, canceled a record number of rush-hour trains yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- The National Medical Association with a membership approaching 5,000 physicians, most of them black, gave notice today through its president that it was "deeply concerned with the inadequacy" of President Nixon's welfare proposals.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- The Ford Motor Company tentatively raised new truck prices 5 per cent today, providing a hint of the coming price increase on automobiles.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- The police this afternoon released William E. Garretson after holding him for almost three days in their investigation of the slaying of Sharon Tate, the actress, and four other persons.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 11 -- U Nu, who still regards himself as the legal Premier of Burma, today denounced the regime of Gen. Ne Win, now ruling his homeland, as fascist.

MIAMI, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Tokyo Dragons, a Japanese baseball team that got caught in a bad financial squeeze-play in Venezuela, arrived here from Caracas today and their manager complained they were "treated worse than dogs" by the Venezuelans.

An undercover detective testified in State Supreme Court yesterday that an alleged right-wing extremist gave him an orange-juice can filled with TNT to detonate on the doorstep of a purported draft-resistance leader.

When two summer campers, Robert Shepard, 15 years old, and Robert Beer, 14, took a Federal examination the other day for third-class radio operator, they were not starting a career They were demonstrating the radio expertise they had acquired this rainy summer in a wooden shack at Camp Ramah, in Glen Spey, N. Y., where the camp's tiny radio station carries Met games, news and recorded music.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Dr. William J. Fitzpatrick, most grand commander of the National Supreme Council of Ancient and Accepted Scottish Rite Masons, said today that his organization was opposed to the Vietnamese war and believed that it should have never been started.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 11 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that despite the new outbreak of fighting initiated by the enemy in South Vietnam, the United States was still interpreting the basic military situation there as a lull.

MUNICH, West Germany, Aug. 11 -- Often called the "world's biggest village" because of its rustic ways, this Bavarian capital became a remote village for air travellers today when its airport was closed for three weeks for urgently needed repairs and improvements.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department today estimated the 1969 corn crop at 4,309,776,000 bushels, up slightly from last month but 1 per cent below last year's crop.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- The Soviet Union said today that its latest unmanned moon probe, Zond 7, was on its way back to earth after having looped the moon and photographed its surface.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- The Federal Reserve System amended today its truth-in-lending rule (Regulation Z) to clarify a provision on discounts granted by creditors on sales to their customers for prompt payment of bills.
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The Government sought today to enlist the working man in its battle to stabilize the franc at its new rate.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- House investigators indicated today that Charles G. Rebozo's application for an $80,000 small business loan in 1962 had the endorsement of former Senator George A. Smathers, a Florida Democrat, but no support from Mr. Rebozo's more famous friend and neighbor, Richard M. Nixon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Aug. 12 -- Enemy forces attacked more than 100 allied cities, towns and bases across South Vietnam today with rockets, mortars and infantry charges, military spokesmen reported.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Administration's refusal to provide more money for policing of the construction of a $900-million oil pipeline in Alaska has aroused fears for the protection of the environment in the northland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Senate critics of the Pentagon, gathering influence since they nearly blocked the antiballistic-missile system last week, continued to chip away today at the Defense Department's $20-billion authorization bill.

The art works of Robert Lehman, who had one of the world's great private collections, are to remain largely with the family, according to the will of the investment banker. The 97-page will was filed for probate yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate's Court.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 11 -- A total of 196 players from 31 states, Canada and England began the opening round of the 70th annual Unted States open chess championship at the Lincoln Hotel here last night.

LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Members of the United States track and field team asked President Nixon tonight for Government intervention to revive American amateur athletics.
