A leading Southern educator told the opening session of the American Management Association's fifth annual conference on education and training yesterday that "we should put our college professors in jail" so that they might come "face to face with some realities of life."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Portrait of the all-purpose White House staff man, composed after having read one newspaper article too many on the men of President Nixon's staff:

State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican and Conservative parties' candidate for Mayor, yesterday denounced his Democratic opponent, Controller Mario A. Procaccino, as a "silent, acquiescent partner until recently" in the Lindsay administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The mother of a Special Forces soldier facing a possible court martial in the murder of a Vietnamese said today she had "been entrusted by him not to say a word."
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- The qualifying stage of the Spingold Knockout Team championship in the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals was marked by some resounding upsets.

SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 11 (AP) -- James P. Shannon, former auxiliary Roman Catholic Bishop of Minneapolis-St. Paul, said today that the automatic excommunication he incurred by marrying was "the greatest single burden of my life."

PRAGUE, Aug. 11 -- Leaders of all Christian churches in Slovakia appealed today for an "atmosphere of peace" in the face of tensions surrounding the first anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion Aug. 20-21. The Communist leadership's information media gave the plea nationwide publicity.
Joe Namath may not play more than the first half against the Giants at Yale Bowl Sunday despite the Jet quarterback's strong desire to prove a point in the first confrontation of the New York rivals.
The declining stock market has compelled Northwest Industries, Inc., to abandon its drive of the last six and a half months to take over the B. F. Goodrich Company.

VIENNA -- The art of drawing is the chamber music of the visual arts. Its characteristic pleasures and epiphanies call for small spaces and intimate circumstances. There are masterpieces of painting and sculpture that are actually enhanced by the presence of a crowd, which dramatizes the scale and the grandeur of the artist's conception; but drawings require an atmosphere far removed from the hurry and bustle of the workaday world.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 -- Don Drysdale, the last of the Brooklyn club's players still with the Dodgers, announced his retirement from baseball today at the age of 33.

A strike by ground personnel that had cut off virtually all Pan American World Airways flight service for four days ended early this morning. A union tabulation showed that the striking workers had voted by a "very narrow margin" to accept a new three-year contract.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that a massive subway tie-up July 18, in which one passenger was killed and 150 were prostrated by heat, had been caused by "uncleaned streets and clogged catch basins" that it had warned city officials about eight days earlier.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- William H. Brown 3d defended today the Administration's bill to enforce through the courts a ban on discrimination in employment.
QUNEITRA, Israeli-Occupied Syria -- The white-bearded rabbi from Hatzor was having a busy and unusual evening -- conducting seven wedding ceremonies in Kibbutz Meron Golan.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 11 -- The Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association championship crew from Noroton Y. C., captained by Manton Scott, won all three Thistle Class races today when the Area B semi-final series for the North American junior sailing championship began off Cedar Point Y. C.

To the dismay of tree conservationists and the mild interest of park bench kibitzers, the Transit Authority has begun construction of a 300-foot-long pedestrian tunnel under the north side of Bryant Park.

A Roald Dahl novel for youngsters. "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory," is head-up for the screen as a joint venture of the Quaker Oats Company of Chicago and David L. Wolper. Mr. Dahl will begin an expansion of his scenario outline in two weeks, and the film, a musical in color, will go before the cameras next summer.
The city Parks Department has assigned a 16-hour daily watch over Kingsland Mansion in Queens, the borough's second-oldest building, until its restoration is completed.
The Consolidated Edison Company reported that it had "adequate capacity" to meet all consumer demands yesterday, despite the continued shutdown of one of its giant generators in Ravenswood, Queens.
New York City began for the first time yesterday a comprehensive study to find out how much carbon monoxide is finding its way into people's bloodstreams.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- The Government will end mining rights held in perpetuity by the country's two major copper companies and will give them 25-year leases instead, President Kenneth D. Kaunda announced today.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday increases of 1 to 2 cents a pound for Natsyn polyisoprene rubber, effective Aug. 20. The advances will range from 4 per cent to 10 per cent.
AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 11 -- A state official said today that "pirates and plunderers" had stolen tons of valuable historical treasure from the floor of the Gulf of Mexico off the coast of Texas.
Trading was cautious yesterday on the London Stock Exchange. Prices edged down fractionally.

Kirk Kerkorian has received tenders for about 1,325,000 shares of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. The figure was announced yesterday by Fred Benninger, president of the Tracy Investment Company, Mr. Kerkorian's personal holding company.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 11 -- A committee representing the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations heard allegations here today that the Israelis used at least 17 torture methods to extract information from prisoners.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 11 -- June Slee, a 22-year-old Paterson State senior, won the qualifying medal in the 44th annual New Jersey State women's golf championship today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 -- A Federal court ordered the Illinois Secretary of State today to discard a "discriminatory" ballot for the upcoming state constitutional convention, on which he testified he had given the favored first line position to political acquaintances.
The Federal Communications Commission was directed yesterday to tell New York State broadcasters just what they might or might not report about the state lottery.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- Renault, the automobile producer wholly owned by the French Government, was the recent winner, among 10 bidders from seven countries, of a Colombian Government contract to participate in the establishment and operation of an automobile assembly plant.

Lawrence F. O'Brien, the former Postmaster General, disclosed yesterday that he had resigned as president of McDonnell Co. At the same time the brokerage house announced substantial additional cutbacks in its business.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Army has decided to terminate its Reserve Officers Training Corps programs at Harvard University and Dartmouth College at the end of the coming academic year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Retail sales rose slightly in July but continued to show essentially the same flat trend of other recent months, the Commerce Department reported today.

MELBOURNE BEACH, Fla., Aug. 11 AP) -- The bodies of a teen-ager and her boy friend were found at a lover's lane south of here last night. The girl had been shot 17 times apparently while her bound companion looked on, the authorities said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- If adopted by Congress, President Nixon's welfare reform proposals would work as follows on three key groups among the nation's poor:

I challenge the oft-repeated and unrefuted misconceptions argued by Governor Rockefeller that the state has been short-changed by the Federal Government in returning to the state only a small portion of the revenues it transmits to Washington in taxes.
WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 11 -- The $100,000 International Trot, scheduled for Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway, is likely to be delayed a week.
A white Marine lance corporal at the Kaneohe Base telephoned his father in Brooklyn yesterday to tell him that the base had been placed on alert as a result of the rioting there.
HONG KONG, Aug. 11 -- Communist China reported briefly today on the accord reached in recent talks with Soviet representatives on river navigation along the bitterly disputed Far Eastern frontier.
A 7-year-old Bronx boy was saved from hanging yesterday when a young woman rescued him from a tree and gave him mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.
WIMBLEDON, England, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Six checks bounced at a Wimbledon bank today, and nobody cared.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to orbit tomorrow a spacecraft carrying 13 experiments.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Aug. 11 -- Four players scored 146 each at Sleepy Hollow Country Club and nearby Briar Hall Golf and Country Club, Briarcliff Manor, today in sectional qualifying for the 69th United States Golf Association amateur championship.

The formal endorsement of Mayor Lindsay's re-election made yesterday by Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo is the most important gain the Mayor has yet had from the ranks of liberal and reform Democrats. Although it had been anticipated for several weeks, the declaration is bound to have a great impact in the areas where the Mayor most needs votes to retain his office.
LEVITTOWN, L. I., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- If a group of Levittown, L. I., housewives have their way, supermarket fish sales will zoom and meat sales and prices will go down, down, down.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 Sixth-seeded Sharon Walsh of San Raphael captured the 52d United States girls' grass court tennis championship today with a 6-2, 10-8 triumph over ninth- seeded Gail Hansen of Palo Alto in an all-California final at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- Everybody tells you that this is the part of the football season when the games don't count, but Ron Blye, the New York Giants' running back, doesn't care about that. He likes to win.
TOKYO, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- France, Bulgaria and Argentina are expected to take part in the weekly wheat import ten-[ der here Wednesday, the Japanese Government Food Agency said today.

The precious metals took center stage yesterday in futures trading, with observers wondering what the devaluation of the French franc would mean to prices. Many looked for a sharp increase both in prices and in trading volume.

HADLYME, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Driven into a near-cometose state by warm water and a blazing sun, the trout were difficult to woo, but that did not trouble me for I had netted a greater prize: a copy of Art Flick's out-of-print "Streamside Guide to Naturals and Their Imitations."
Trading was light as prices moved down moderately on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

Former Water Commissioner James L. Marcus was released from a Federal minimum security prison in Florida yesterday morning after having served almost 11 months of a 15-month sentence for conspiracy to accept a bribe on a city reservoir contract.

The Nixon Administration's proposal that many mothers who head welfare families be required to seek jobs or training was described yesterday as a "major mistake" by the city's Human Resources Administrator, Mitchell I. Ginsberg.

It's going to be hard to beat Libby, McNeill Libby when it comes to belief in the value of advertising and promotion. For the big food processor, which only last month said that its loss for the fiscal year ended June 30 could reach $15-million, announced yesterday an advertising increase for the current fiscal year of up to 15 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to decide whether an Army reservist from New York can keep his hair long.

No city is more insatiable in its demand for electricity than New York. It suffered through one disastrous blackout four years ago. Now it gets almost daily reminders that another such catastrophe is not unthinkable.

O. J. Simpson's first 24 hours as a member of the Buffalo Bills were memorable. He was kissed by Miss Buffalo, issued the wrong uniform number, jeered by one teammate, ignored by another and served a glass of tomato juice.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The civilian lawyer for one of the eight accused members of the United States Special Forces said today that the military authorities had temporarily suspended hearings to determine whether the men should be court-martialed on charges of murder in the mysterious case of a missing South Vietnamese.

OTTAWA, Aug. 12 -- A complaint charging Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau with assault was sworn out today in Vancouver, British Columbia, by a 17-year-old youth who participated in a name-calling demonstration there against Mr. Trudeau Friday night.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, chairman of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting, attacked the three major networks yesterday for their responses to a request that they voluntarily stop broadcasting cigarette commercials by the end of this year.

MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (UPI) -A Soviet space scientist said today that the "brilliant implementation" of the Apollo 11 flight had opened the way to setting up underground scientific laboratories on the moon.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 12 -- On the second business day after the devaluation of the French franc, European foreign exchange markets continued to act nervously with the weak currencies such as the pound sterling and the Belgian franc losing ground, while Europe's strongest currency, the mark, moved higher.
Iberia Airlines of Spain announced yesterday the choice of Compton Advertising as the agency for its worldwide advertising account. Its estimated annual billings are $6-million to $8-million.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 12 -For the general music public, Tanglewood means summer concerts of familiar well-loved music played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra in an idyllic setting of magnificent lawns and monumental trees.
A Bronx railroad cut that has been the site of a series of fatal auto accidents will be shielded by steel barricades, Mayor Lindsay's office announced yesterday.
LISBON, Aug. 12 -- Portugal isn't exactly agog over the impending visit of the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, but for a small, proud country with a minuscule aristocracy, it's pretty excited.
TRENTON, Aug. 12 -- New Jersey officials sought a court order today to bar jetliners that use Newark Airport from polluting the air with their exhausts.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Aug. 13 -- Allied military sources said today that 1,450 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers were killed during the last 24 hours in the heaviest fighting in South Vietnam in three months.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 12 -- The White House said today that the fresh outbreak of enemy attacks in South Vietnam could signify the beginning of a major offensive, but that it was still too soon to evaluate firmly the nature of the assaults.
The citizens of Montreal were so jubilant, one might have thought it was Dominion Day. But when it came to celebrating, they didn't have anything on another Canadian, Mike Kilkenny.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -California prepared today to put its best, if rather chauvinistic, face forward for the state dinner tomorrow night honoring the Apollo 11 astronauts.
Transportation officials warned the city yesterday to expect several months of difficulties after the new exact fare plan goes into effect on buses Aug. 31.

The addition of two members to the roster of The Jockey Club was announced by Ogden Phipps, the chairman of the organization. Both newcomers, John M. Olin and Jack Dreyfus Jr., are prominent in the world of finance as well as in thoroughbred activities.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Wednesday, Aug. 13 -- The police used tear gas against a rioting Roman Catholic mob last night in an effort to break up savage sectarian fighting after nearly eight hours.

In the first two summers of its existence, the Berkshire Boy Choir demonstrated its virtues locally in the prosaic, if acoustically sharp, auditorium of the Lincoln Center Library. For the choir's third annual appearance, someone had the inspired notion of having the ensemble sing in the 12th - century Spanish apse of The Cloisters.

ROME, Aug. 12 -- The Vatican said officially today that the German prelates who nominated the Most Rev. Matthias Defregger for promotion to bishop in July, 1968, did not reveal the candidate's involvement in a wartime mass execution in Italy.
IF there's an intentional design to this bouillabaisse of essays, some chronological or geographical plan, or some hidden didactic purpose, I failed to locate it.
The organist broke into "Seems Like Old Times" as the final out was made at Yankee Stadium last night and the Yankees had a delightful 10-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that 15 grants totalling $143,809 had been awarded by the New York State Council on the Arts under its Ghetto Arts Program for the 1969-70 season. Most of the funds will be used for salaries and for expenses incurred in the various programs in the performing arts.
Mayor Lindsay spent 15 minutes yesterday describing methadone as "perhaps the greatest hope" in dealing with a vast amount of "street crime" attributed to heroin addicts.

Eight years ago, a needy 12year-old New Yorker named Sylvia Paneque had what she has since called her "first glimpse of a different way of life" when she spent several weeks as the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Stinard in the little village of Greene, Chenango County, in South Central New York.
The election of five new directors of the piper Aircraft Corporation was announced yesterday by W. T. Piper Jr., president.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 12 -- President Nixon criticized Congress today for not supporting his revenue recommendations.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- The sudden increase in enemy military activity in South Vietnam was viewed by sources in the United States delegation to the peace talks here today as a possible attempt to renew pressure on Washington for more concessions.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 12 (AP) -Premier Golda Meir cautioned the leaders of Lebanon today that they could not escape responsibility for Arab guerrillas operating from Lebanese soil.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 12 -- Unusually placid, Johnny Sample doubted today that he would perform for the Jets against the Giants on Sunday at the Yale Bowl but Jim Hudson, the other casualty in the world champions' defensive backfield, expected to be in the starting line-up.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Defense Department announced today that an investigation by the Army into the alleged misuse of funds of noncommissioned officer clubs around the world had been under way since October, 1968.

RYE, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Cort Steck of Port Washington Y. C., with an unnamed boat in the even-numbered Lightning Class division, and Stanley Sneath of Riverside Y. C., with Zazz among the odd-numbered Lightnings, won four-mile races today when the Junior Yacht Racing Association's annual race week began off American Y. C. in weak air that made a 180-degree shift during the regatta.

WASHINGTON, Aug 12 (UPI) -- Jack Anderson, the columnist, said today that he had learned Senator Edward M. Kennedy did not swim the 150 yards between Chappaquiddick Island and Martha's Vineyard the night his car plunged off a bridge and killed Mary Jo Kopechne.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- The Security Council condemned South Africa today for what was termed its persistent defiance of the United Nations in refusing to permit it to take over control of South-West Africa, which the United Nations now calls Namibia.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 12 -Three long-time grandmasters of chess -- Pal Benko of New York, Arthur Bisguier of Hartsdale, N. Y., and Robert Byrne of Indianapolis -- scored second successive victories in the second round of the 70th annual United States Open Chess Championship at the Lincoln Hotel here last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -Federal tax dollars would be divided among small units of local government as well as major American cities in President Nixon's revenue sharing plan, it was reliably reported today.

A State Department official said yesterday that the United States had acted for humanitarian reasons in permitting a member of the Central Committee of the Cuban Communist party to come here for eye surgery.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Informed military sources said today that six North Vietnamese ordered to leave Laos had begun a hunger strike to protest their arrest on charges of trying to obtain important military documents.
Traffic Commissioner Theodore Karagheuzoff will spend two weeks in Japan in mid-October to advise on traffic engineering and safety problems at the invitation of the Japanese Government.
THE tax bill that the House of Representatives has sent to the Senate must have arrived to the accompaniment of a chorus of weeping by the real estate companies that build office buildings.

The inside story of President Nixon's new welfare proposals tells quite a lot about the new chief executive's approach to his job. He was opposed, on one point or another, by a majority of his Cabinet and at some points by three-quarters of the Cabinet members, but always he came back to a simple proposition -- he might not have the answer, but the existing welfare policy was a failure and had to be changed.
The operations of Pan American World Airways were near normal-last night, following the settlement of a strike by ground personnel that had cut off virtually all service since Friday.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday record results for the second quarter and first half of 1969. It was the 40th consecutive quarter in which sales and earnings have exceeded the similar period of the previous year, Harold S. Geneen, chairman and president, noted in the company's report.
Alexander Heard, the chancellor of Vanderbilt University, informed Columbia University yesterday that he was refusing an offer to succeed Grayson Kirk as its president.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 12 -- President Kenneth D. Kaunda abruptly adjourned the scheduled four-day meeting of his party's National Council this morning so that the delegates could return to their districts to rally public support behind his economic program and forestall possible attempts to sabotage it.

PRAGUE, Aug. 12 -- The Communist party published a previously secret document today purporting to show that Alexander Dubcek and other leading liberals had warned against "counterrevolutionary" dangers in May, 1968.

A move to block this week's pop rock festival at Bethel, N. Y. -- the Woodstock Music and Art Fair and Aquarian Exposition -- was dropped yesterday. A motion for an injunction against it was withdrawn in the State Supreme Court at Catskill.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12 -- Morgaise, William Haggin Perry's fine filly, returned to her winning ways today in the Saratoga Springs Purse. The 4-year-old daughter of Round Table beat nine rivals in the six-furlong event that served as the highlight of the day.

WASHNGTON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- Treasury Secretary David M. Kennedy said today that he would ask President Nixon for additional steps "as soon as possible" to ease restrictions on foreign direct investment.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today that the Department of Health, Education and Welfare had abused the intent of Congress in cutting off Federal funds to school boards not complying with desegregation guidelines.
John W. Kneller, an Englishborn, American - educated French scholar who has been provost of Oberlin College in Ohio since 1965, was named president of Brooklyn College yesterday.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Governor Keith H. Miller of Alaska announced today that the Bank of America, San Francisco, the nation's largest, had been engaged as investment manager for the proceeds of the state's Sept. 10 sale of Arctic Slope oil leases.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 12 -- Allie Sherman, the New York Giants coach, continued to avoid making any rash statements about his team in comparison with the New York Jets today, but there was some indication that the confrontation between the teams in New Haven's Yale Bowl this Sunday would be more than "just an exhibition."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12 -- King Hussein of Jordan shifted his country's political course today by changing Premiers and naming a new Cabinet.
PEOPLE are so much more interesting than statistics, a fact demonstrated once again last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System's superb television study of the generation gap, "Fathers and Sons."

It has been sadly asked in these Vietnam years whether we will ever learn anything from the horror of war. The question was posed when the horror of the nuclear era first dawned on Hiroshima Day, Aug. 6, 1945.
Two Negroes and a Puerto Rican were "appointed" to the City Planning Commission yesterday by a coalition of groups protesting Mayor Lindsay's failure to name a nonwhite to the agency.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- The Senate approved legislation today intended to help 200,000 college students obtain Government -backed loans for the coming school year.
The city has a backlog of 4,000 to 5,000 congested catchbasins similar to those that caused the flooding of the Lexington Avenue IRT July 18, a Department of Water Resources spokesman said yesterday.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 12 (AP) -- District Attorney Edmund Dinis asked a Pennsylvania court today to order exhumation and an autopsy on Mary Jo Kopechne, the Washington secretary who drowned July 18 in a car accident with Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -A program intended to make it easier for an individual to obtain and complete Federal job training was presented to Congress today by President Nixon.

The baseball game between the New York Philharmonic Penguins and the Orchestra Society of Westchester, scheduled for yesterday afternoon in Central Park, was not postponed because of rain, unfortunately for the Philharmonic.

SEATTLE, Aug. 12 -- The "protem" will officially be erased from the title of commissioner of baseball tomorrow when Bowie Kuhn's election to the post for a four-year term will be ratified by the owners of the 24 major league teams at a joint meeting. The leagues decided separately this afternoon on this step.
Car sales moved lower for three of the nation's four major automobile producers in the first 10 days of August, continuing the trend of the previous month.

WHO would want to take a room in an apartment in the Sutton Place area and turn it into a grotto where everything, including walls, sconces and table base are covered with shells, where a little waterfall splashes onto goldfish in a curving stream and where the humidity has to be experienced to be believed?
The American Academy in Rome has announced the appointments of Reginald Allen to the new post of executive vice president and of Bartlett H. Hayes Jr. as director.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -Public hearings on the 800mile pipeline proposed to siphon off Alaska's new oil discoveries will be held in Alaska and probably also in Washington.
The stock market, which struck gold on Monday, failed to file any spectacular claims yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 12 -- "The European Common Market has just buried its joint farm pricing program and is now awaiting the resurrection." Dawn had broken over the gray slabs of the Palais des Congres in Brussels as a haggard Dutch minister, emerging from an 18hour meeting, made this observation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The Republican National Committee has begun a new "listening" program to record the views of people that the party does not ordinarily hear from and pass them along, in digest form, to President Nixon and his Cabinet officers.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to weaken yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by more than a 3-to-1 ratio.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- An American woman living in Beirut charged today that Israeli authorities carried out willful destruction of property and a concerted policy of humiliating Arabs in the occupied territories.
MOSCOW, Aug. 12 (UPI) -Informed literary sources said today that security agents raided the apartment of Anatoly Kuznetsov, the defected writer, five days ago and seized 170 private letters.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., Aug. 12 -- Negotiations between 90 of the 96 Palisades Interstate Parks lifeguards and park officials broke up today without settlement of a salary dispute and all swimming installations except the Anthony Wayne remained closed for the fourth day.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged private businesses and city agencies to arrange their schedules to allow the maximum number of employes to see the Apollo 11 astronauts during their 3-hour 15-minute visit to the city today.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 12 (AP) -- A $12-million experimental spacecraft went into orbit today on the wrong side of the earth and began tumbling end over end.

DALLAS, Aug. 12 -- Having devoted the opening days of its annual convention primarily to discussions of broad national issues, the American Bar Association turned today to the business of protecting the lawyers' professional turf.
BOSTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) -The Boston Celtics were purchased today for $6-million -the largest price ever paid for a professional basketball team.

Computerization is coming to the rescue of Penn Central customers who like its fast Metroliner between New York and Washington but are annoyed by the uncertainty and inconvenience of an old-fashioned ticket-reservation system.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 12 -- George Morton Levy, the president of Roosevelt Raceway, officially postponed today the 11th annual $100,000 International Trot, scheduled for Saturday night, until Aug. 23.
Mayor Lindsay took political advantage of a Model Cities ground-breaking ceremony in East New York yesterday to level harsh criticism on both the state government and Assemblyman Vito P. Battista.

Marchi, the Republican - Conservative candidate for Mayor, declared yesterday that the support given Mayor Lindsay by Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo "raises the inescapable conclusion that the New Left has chosen New York City as the launching pad for an effort to dominate both major parties on a national level."
Real estate brokers who have been charging the city's poor "exorbitant and unconscionable" fees for finding apartments for them have become targets of a state campaign.
HOUSTON, Aug. 12 -- The New York Mets lost their eighth straight game to the Houston Astros tonight and they went to bizarre lengths to preserve their record of not having won a game indoors in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -- Senators dedicated to trimming the Pentagon's programs and policies began today their most ambitious project -- eliminating altogether from defense planning a $700-million nuclear aircraft carrier.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 12 -- Thanat Khoman, Thailand's Foreign Minister, said today that President Nixon's recent visit to Thailand and other Asian countries had underlined the fact that foreign troops were unsuited "physiologically, psychologically and morally" for fighting wars of internal subversion.
The foreign exchange markets continued to react uncertainly yesterday to the devaluation of the French franc.

A third-floor window opens at a brownstone on West 89th Street. An old woman sticks her head out and shouts: "Get out of here, you kids! Get away before I call the cops!" And six youngsters who had been playing stoop ball, sneer and skip down the block.

BONN, Aug. 12 -- Foreign Minister Willy Brandt's Social Democratic party announced today that it still regarded revaluation of the West German currency as a "necessity," because devaluation of the French franc had not eliminated disparities among the world's major currencies.
A new election was ordered yesterday in the upset primary defeat of one of the leaders of the City Council.

PARIS -- The students of the Western world are now on holiday, wandering from the beaches of Acapulco to the crags of Kabul and seeking romance and refreshment from Haight-Ashbury to the Rue de la Huchette. It is a splendid, carefree season and nobody yet knows which among the vacationers plan new scholastic insurrections in the fall.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 12 -- The Rumanian Communist party congress ended this afternoon with cheers and applause for President Nicolae Ceausescu, the party leader.

Glore Forgan, William R. Staats, Inc., the brokerage house, announced yesterday that Archie E. Albright, an investment banker and former chemical industry executive, had been elected president.

PARIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Ambassador George Christopoulos of Greece has resigned in protest against his summary recall by the Athens military Government.

HOUSTON, Aug. 12 -- The first men to land on the moon said today that their Apollo 11 mission might have opened a new era in dealing with problems on the earth.

A friendly sun, as languid as a society owner, climbed slowly into a cloudless sky, drying the glistening leaves and turning puddles of water to mud.

CLOMP, clomp, clomp the clogs are marching, right past summer, leaving indelible footprints on the shape of shoe fashion. For the influence of clogs, which, in their original Swedish guise, were summer's No. 1 fashion fad, is heading right into fall. Most shoe designers have translated them into platform sales, the likes of which haven't been seen since the end of World War II.
A 17-year-old Brooklyn boy hanged himself yesterday morning at the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island in the latest of a series of suicides in city prisons or police stations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The Republican National Chairman said today that his office was available to supply advice and information -- but not to provide money -- for State Senator John J. Marchi's campaign for Mayor of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The Civil Rights Commission accused state governments today of failing to promote equal opportunities in state and local government employment. The commission also urged that Federal funds be withheld when discrimination has occurred.
Prices backed down along a broad front yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
WHEN the weather is good on weekends, John William Kneller walks the mile from his home in Oberlin, Ohio, to a modest farm, where he boards a standardbred bay gelding.
Three photographers just back from North Vietnam sued yesterday to recover movie film that was seized by Customs after they landed at Kennedy International Airport last Thursday.

There will be no live television of the Giants-Jets game Sunday afternoon in New Haven, because Commissioner Pete Rozelle has imposed pro football's blackout rule on the contest. The rule, which has stood up in court, states that no television station situated within 75 miles of the site of a home game may televise that game.
Dr. Thomas Nicholson, director of the American Museum of Natural History, has announced 14 staff appointments, including 8 promotions to the post of curator.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Members of a crowd of 100 Negro demonstrators wearing red berets fought with the police today at the gates of a University of Illinois at Chicago Circle campus construction site.
A streamlined voter registration drive is under consideration -- with the savings in expenses to be used to train election inspectors.
The American Management Association's fifth annual education and training equipment exhibition opened yesterday afternoon at the New York Hilton.
GREENVILLE, S.C., Aug. 12 -- There is persuasive evidence that Clement F. Haynsworth, a Federal Circuit Court judge, may soon be appointed to the Supreme Court.
THE five-story whitewashed "brownstone" at 307 East 12th Street has a bright blue door and a name that often makes people think that it is something that it is not.

Preservation of the twenty cent subway fare is an economic "must" for New York City. A rise in the fare to 25 cents could well be self-defeating. The number of riders might fall off so sharply as to bring in no more revenue than the present fare structure is producing.

BONN, Aug. 12 -- Some Vatican authorities close to Pope Paul have called for the resignation of Bishop Defregger, according to background reports of the West German Catholic News Agency made public here by mistake.
LOS ANGELES Aug. 12 -One major upset occurred in the first knockout round of the Spingold Knockout Team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here last night.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 12 (UPI) -- Three of the nation's major plumbing fixture manufacturers and three company executives received today fines, brief prison terms and suspended sentences for criminal conspiracy to fix prices.

SAIGON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -Reliable sources today said that there was a link between the Green Beret case and the recent report that a spy ring had been discovered by the South Vietnamese police in the presidential palace.
Hundreds of angry, bewildered persons lined up all day yesterday outside the city's Medicaid center after having been notified that they had been dropped from the Medicaid rolls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Three Representatives introduced today a new public income maintenance program far more costly and extensive than the one President Nixon sent to Congress yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 12 -- In what is destined to be the last major meet on the worn cinder track of White City Stadium, the United States led Britain, 9984, tonight, after the first half of their track and field meet. The American men were ahead 74-47, but the women trailed 37-25.

PARIS, Aug. 12 (AP) -- A French official working for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has been arrested and charged with "a grave breach of security," official sources said today. The official, who was unidentified, was being questioned by the French counterespionage service and will be tried by the State Security Court, the sources said.
LONDON, Aug. 12 (Reuters) -- The major wheat-exporting nations agreed today at a meeting here on new measures to tackle a slump in prices caused by a world surplus of wheat.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 12 -- Members of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's faction of the governing Congress party are charging that her opponents within the party are seeking the support of rightist parties in the hope of forming a right-wing coalition to topple her from office.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., Aug. 12 (UPI) -- An explosion ripped through a chemical plant in Raritan Township today, injuring five men -- three of them critically. Scores of other workers fled to safety.

A few curious pajama-clad Queens residents blinked their eyes in disbelief early yesterday when they looked out their windows and saw Mayor Lindsay riding a street sweeper down deserted Bell Boulevard in Bayside.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) -- The Pentagon stood firm today on its refusal to supply the Senate Foreign Relations Committee with a secret agreement between the United States and Thailand.

MIAMI, Aug. 12 -- Three Florida bank groups proposed today that they be "joined together" in a $1.7-billion complex that would make them collectively the largest banking organization in the Southeast.
The Long Island Rail Road yesterday pursued its newly adopted policy of canceling large numbers of trains in an attempt to operate those that continue to run more efficiently.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 12 -A 25-year-old post office porter. Tommy Lee Ingram, was indicted by a Nassau County grand jury today on a charge of felony murder in the deaths of four members of a Queens family in an automobile collision last Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -Business at all levels added $500-million to inventories in June, the smallest monthly increase since January, the Commerce Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The United Mine Workers of America acknowledged today that Joseph A. Yablonski had been nominated for president of the troubled union. Mr. Yablonski said yesterday that the U.M.W. would try to block his candidacy to remove a threat to the re-election of W. A. Boyle.

The Security Council meeting today to discuss Israel's air raids against Arab guerrillas on Lebanese soil will be another exercise in futility if it limits itself to Beirut's complaint. A state of continual, though still limited, border warfare has been developing between Israel and all its Arab neighbors, with Lebanon as the least active sector.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -Gasoline stations and food stores that use give-away games for promotion will have to inform customers of their slim chances of winning a big prize, according to a Federal Trade Commission ruling today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 -The nation's money supply grew more rapidly than had been thought in the first half of this year, and particularly in the second quarter, the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today.

PARIS, Aug. 12 -- France has obtained substantial relief from price inflation as a result of decisions taken by the European Common Market in Brussels yesterday. But labor was unimpressed and even appeared to stiffen its opposition to the devaluation of the franc.

Kennedy, would have to present his petition in person or send a representative.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 -- A high-level commission recommended today a new, two-part plan aimed at minimizing the problem of discounts or "points" on mortgages backed by the Government.

Bond prices declined yesterday as the optimism that pervaded the credit markets last week continued to evaporate. WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 (UPI) -- The United States, Canada and Australia have lowered wheat export prices for Asian and Latin-American markets in the latest development of what appears to be an international price war.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 13 -- Thirty-two persons were arrested in raids early today in connection with the Sale of heroin and other narcotics.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of the Essex County Country Club won the women's New Jersey state amateur golf championship today, defeating June Slee of Mount Tabor in a 36hole final, 4 and 3.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Aug. 15 -- President Judge Bernard C. Brominski of Luzerne County today set Aug. 25 for a hearing on a petition for an autopsy on Mary Jo Kopechne, who drowned July 18 when an automobile driven by Senator Edward M. Kennedy ran off a bridge at Chappaquiddick Island, Mass.

The governing board of the Two Bridges school district on the Lower East Side was ordered yesterday by State Supreme Court to show cause why its election of Luis Fuentes as $30,000-a-year unit administrator should not be invalidated.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 15 -- The crisis in the Indian Government and the governing Congress party deepened tonight on the eve of the nation's crucial presidential election.
LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 15 -Grandmaster Arthur Bisguier of Hartsdale, N. Y., took the undisputed lead in the 70th Annual United States Open Chess Championship here last night with a fifth straight win.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. said today that the Justice Department had investigated what he termed "blatant falsehoods" accusing him of a conflict of interest in connection with a judicial decision in 1963.

HONOLULU, Aug. 15 (AP) -"It's just my thing. I have to be here. I hope you understand that," said Army Specialist 4 Alan Porter, a oncewounded veteran, of two combat tours in South Vietnam's Mekong Delta.
Can a $3 - million face - lift "beautify" and "revitalize" a four-mile section of squalid old Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn?
State and city officials announced yesterday that 1,000 prisoners would be transferred from the city jail on Rikers Island to Clinton State Prison in Dannemora.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Six North Vietnamese who were arrested six days ago and accused of spying left for Hanoi today, while an angry civilian crowd shouted: "Communists, go home!"

The head of an organization representing 500 of the city's 700 probation officers said yesterday that unless the city provided salaries comparable to those paid at the state and Federal level "a work stoppage is pretty likely."

The revelations of connections between numerous signers of a pro-ABM advertisement and military contractors do not bother me nearly as much as the nomination of the advertisement promoter, William J. Casey, to the General Advisory Committee of the U.S. Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 15 -- A teen-ager in jeans climbed from the red cab of a flatbed truck and waved his submachine gun as his friends helped a freightened family -two women and an old man in a checkered cap -- load their bright blankets, limp mattresses and a few chairs and tables.
DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 15 -Arnold Palmer, an ailing golfer, received advice from friends today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15 -- Qualified sources familiar with the investigation of the reported murder of a Vietnamese double agent asserted today that intelligence officers of the Special Forces had repeatedly tried to get clear instructions from the Central Intelligence Agency before the victim's death.

Welfare officials estimated yesterday that President Nixon's proposal to eliminate the food-stamp program with the introduction of a Federal family grant could cost the city's poor $20-million to $40-million a year.

The United States Customs Bureau yesterday returned 12,000 feet of motion picture film it seized last week from three American photographers when they landed at Kennedy International Airport after a trip to North Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The President's proposals on welfare reform, manpower training and revenue-sharing have already drawn a good deal of comment throughout the nation.
HONG KONG, Aug. 15 -- Communist China accused the Soviet Union today of mobilizing for war against China and continued to warn the Chinese people to prepare for conflict with the Russians.

THE former Giant defensive back, Allan Webb, was eating lunch and explaining how he would inspire the team he helps coach, the Long Island Bulls, to win its game last night against the Bridgeport Jets. "I keep telling them," 'said Webb, "it's not Long Island and Bridgeport, it's the minor league Giants against the minor league Jets. The world's watching your game, fellers, it'll be a sign for the big game.

DUBLIN, Aug. 15 -- Unlike Northern Ireland, which has two Protestants to each Roman Catholic, Ireland is so overwhelmingly Catholic that its tiny Protestant minority presents no problems to the members of the dominant faith.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 15 -- Robert Carmichael, unfamiliar in tennis circles on this side of the Atlantic Ocean, who left Australia to take up residence in Paris, upset Ray Ruffels, Australia's No. 2 ranking player, 6-4, 8-6, 6-3, today to gain the men's singles final of the $15,000 Pennsylvania grass court tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 15 -- The First Lady proudly unveiled the Western White House yesterday, a Spanish-type home that was in fashion here even before California became a state.

HAMPTON, Va., Aug. 15 -The roar of the Boeing 707 that is so unpopular around airports can be muffled, Federal researchers reported this week, but one said that the price of less noise might be an increase of 5 per cent in the cost of an airline ride.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- A course on revolution and guerrilla tactics taught in the Scarsdale High School summer session has caused considerable concern among Scarsdale residents, the Superintendent of Schools said here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The Government announced today some refinements in its method of calculating poverty and discovered as a result that there were 1.6 million more poor persons in 1967 than had been thought.
PEKING -- In a way, it's like Au Printemps in Paris, or Macy's in New York, or Simpsons in Toronto. Maybe it's even like the GUM, department store in Moscow.

SANTA FE, N. M., Aug. 15 -John Whiting's "The Devils" has always been an efective play. Now Krzysztot Penderecki has made an opera out of it, naming the three-act work "The Devils of Loudon," after the Huxley novel on which Whiting based his script.
FRESNO, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- A group of California grape growers has filed a $75million amended antitrust suit against the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee and three other unions.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Gary Hall, an 18-yearold dynamo from Long Beach, Calif., swam to his second world record in 24 hours tonight at the National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor swimming and diving championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Sources in the Nixon Administration disclosed today that a secret contingency plan drawn up with Thailand in 1965 contains provisions for using American troops to help the Thai Army oppose Communist forces in Laos before any such troops cross the Thai borders.
WIMBLEDON, England, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Ion Tiriac and Ilie Nastase won their doubles match today and gave Rumania a 2-1 lead over Britain in the interzone final of Davis Cup play.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -A Michigan inventor, who has devised electronic switches made of amorphous, glassy materials, has added another factor -- light.

CANTERBURY, England, Aug. 15 -- A top official of the World Council of Churches proposed today that Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches convene a series of "universal councils" similar to those that took place in the early centuries of Christianity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Sun Oil Company has been authorized to resume drilling operations on its Federal lease in the Santa Barbara Channel off the southern coast of California, Secretary of the Interior Walter J. Hickel announced today.

The wheat futures market rose yesterday on export hopes, not by much but enough to indicate some encouragement. Traders talked about a purchase of 3,730,000 bushels of wheat by Brazil for export this month and during September. They noted also the resumption of buying by Japan.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- President Nixon will address the National Governors Conference at Colorado Springs on Labor Day, the White House announced today.

As a follow-up to the story on how welfare cutbacks affected a blind man and the very large family of a TB victim, you carried a story on the generous outpouring of funds and dog food deliveries from sympathetic readers who were concerned by the deprivation that would be suffered by the blind man and his dog.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -- Ten New York Athletic Club crews qualified today for the finals as 21 colleges and clubs rowed in 24 heats of the national championship regatta on a placid Schuylkill River.
WHAT happens when your broker leaves his employer and goes to work for another investment house? Do you go with him or stay put?

MIAMI, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The hurrican called Camille churned across Cuba's rich tobacco country today and headed for the Gulf of Mexico, where she was expected to aim her 115-mile-an-hour winds at the United States mainland.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- United States troops supported by helicopter gunships killed 96 guerrillas in heavy fighting near the Cambodian border, a United States spokesman said today.
The words that have long been the solace and the glory of the Irish flowed like Liffey's waters yesterday as the Irish of New York mourned and raged about "the troubles."
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 15 -- British army units moved tonight against Roman Catholic and Protestant bands terrorizing areas of Belfast.
TORONTO, Aug. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Three young men rushed at Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau from a picnic crowd on Toronto Island today, pushing protest signs in his face.

TRENTON, Aug. 15 -- Robert (Bobby Basile) Occhipinti, a reputed enforcer in the Mafia, surrendered to the New Jersey state police today after being a fugitive from the State Commission of Investigation for 17 days.

A CHAIR presents a designer with a problem in limitations, the principal one being the human form. A chair must have its seat far enough off the ground to allow a man's leg to be extended and relaxed. It should offer support for his back and, possibly, for his arms.
For the past two years the heartening debate over America's strategic military posture has been dominated by a single issue -- whether or not we should deploy an antiballistic missile system.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- Chairman Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, said today his proposed investigation of lobbying by banking interests would be delayed at least a month by objections from members of the House Banking Committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Officials of the Central Intelligence Agency declined comment today on assertions that the agency was involved in the assassination of an alleged Vietnamese double agent.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The Marine Corps commandant, Gen. Leonard F. Chapman, acknowledged today a serious racial problem in the Marines. He said "it is obvious we have been less successful than we thought" in stopping racial outbursts.

I read your July 4 editorial "Benefits to Veterans" with interest, amazement and alarm. The Fourth of July was indeed a fitting time for citizens to reconsider the debt they still owe to the survivors of wars.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP) -- The Court of Military Appeals upheld today the conviction of Capt. Dale E. Noyd of the Air Force for refusing to train pilots for duty in Vietnam.

LYNN, Mass., Aug. 15--For two days this town has been the world capital of drumming, bugling, marching, banner waving saber twirling, rifle tossing, bizarre costumes and sometimes brilliant showmanship that collectively are known as a drum and bugle corps competition.
When you call the New York Jets' office, the switchboard operator answers, proudly and simply: "World Champions."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The Defense Department, denying charges that the number of United States troops in South Vietnam has been rising rather than falling, disclosed figures today to show that the gains were temporary and would soon disappear.

The National Can Corporation, the nation's third largest can manufacturer, entered the glass business yesterday by purchasing Oil City Glass, a division of the Questor Corporation, for more than $8.5-million in cash and notes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- The Federal Reserve has amended recently adopted regulatory provisions narrowing exemptions under Regulations D and Q that are available to banks using repurchase agreements.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- O. J. Simpson gave a crowd of 34,206 in Tiger Stadium a quick peak at the skills that made him the most widely acclaimed college player of the last decade. Tonight's preseason game, won by Detroit over Buffalo, 24-12, was the professional debut for Simpson the Bill's first draft choice who signed a three-year contract last Saturday for a reported $350,000.

LONDON--The National Theater at the Old Vic will begin Sept. 1 to build the Young Vic, theater center for young people. The new building has been designed deliberately to be temporary. It will occupy a site about 150 yards from the Old Vic, the theater on the South Bank of the Thames that is being used by the National Theater until its new home is ready in a couple of years.
Vandals broke into a Selective Service office in Jamaica, Queens, Thursday night, dumped files on the floor, tore some up and spattered others with black paint.

Six persons, including two who said they were college teachers and two filmmakers, were arraigned in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday on charges of possessing hashish valued at $384,000 and a .38caliber revolver.

A 21-year-old Cornell University graduate student, who was believed to have been killed in an accident on vacation last month in Lyons, France, arrived from Europe at Kennedy International Airport early today and was reunited with his parents.

AJACCIO, Corsica, Aug. 15 -- President Georges Pompidou, a replacement for Charles de Gaulle, delivered the 200th-birthday speech for Napoleon Bonaparte in the Emperor's native city today. What was to have been the climax of a year of glorious nostalgia turned out to be anticlimax.
As swingers, neither Dave Boswell nor Rich Reese might be in Joe Namath's class. Rated in their own classes, however, the Minnesota Twins prefer Reese's way of swinging to Boswell's.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 15 -- Toy Soldier, a one - time United States Equestrian Team star, took the lead for the open jumper championship by winning the bonus-point class today at the rain-splattered Monmouth County Horse Show.
The new-issue market remained depressed this week as only seven companies made first public offerings of fully registered common stock.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed today a school desegregation suit against a school district near Houston, asking that construction of new classrooms be halted pending proof it would induce desegregation.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Dr. Hugh Ashmore, Suffolk County's deputy chief medical examiner, said today that it would take "one to two weeks" to determine if the late Joseph Magliocco, a reported Long Island crime boss, was poisoned.

MOSCOW, Aug. 15 -- Yuri Bondarev, a writer known for his anti-Stalinist views, has published a new story whose villain is a prominent Soviet professor who survived the Stalinist days by condemning his sister to 15 years in prison camps.

" IT is my experience," remarked T. S. Eliot in his 1940 lecture on Yeats, "that toward middle age a man has three choices: to stop writing altogether, to repeat himself . . . or . . . to adapt himself to middle age and find a different way of working."

Stock prices rose briskly on expanded volume yesterday, giving the market its best gain in two weeks. The Dow-Jones industrial average finished at its peak level of the session, climbing 7.65 points, to 820.88.

BONN, Aug. 15 -- The chief West German Government spokesman, Gunter Diehl, emphatically denied today newspaper reports that the United States or France had put pressure on Bonn to revalue upward the mark.

In Peter Cooper Village yesterday, residents ran bucket brigades and used club soda for brushing teeth. But in most other places affected by Thursday's water main break at First Avenue and 36th Street, water was flowing normally again.

LONDON, Aug. 15 -- Britain today firmly rejected a proposal from Ireland for a joint peacemaking force in embattled Northern Ireland. Thus London made still another attempt to discourage -- or at least restrain -- Ireland's involvement in the problems of the Britishcontrolled area.
The Columbia Gas System, Inc., showed an increase of 6.83 per cent in earnings for the first half of this year on a gain of 7.13 in operating revenues, according to the company's report yesterday.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 15 (AP) -- James H. Meredith announced today the formation of an organization to "improve the living conditions in black communities throughout the United States."

BETHEL, N. Y., Aug. 15 -A crowd estimated at more than 200,000 poured into this Catskill Mountain hamlet today for a three-day rock and folk music festival, creating massive traffic jams and a potentially serious security problem.

Dr. William J. Ronan last night charged that Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson had made "false and misleading statements about the Long Island Rail Road and its operations."

DUBLIN, Aug. 15 -- The Government ordered a mobilization of the 2,000 members of its first-line reserves today for use in possible "peace-keeping operations" in Northern Ireland, which has been torn by fighting between Protestants and Roman Catholics.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Aug. 15 -- "With great reluctance," a Federal judge allowed this city's school board today to achieve desegregation by busing black students only. But next year it must be a different story, he said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -- Computer programs are patentable under a decision yesterday of the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, in the controversial computer software case, several lawyers said today after studying the decision, which supercedes one handed down last November. At the request of the Patent Office, a re hearing was held in March.
A ruling by a State Supreme Court justice yesterday opened the way for a Queens couple to go to court to regain custody of a foster child they had cared for from her infancy.

HOUSTON, Aug. 15 -- On the day before the biggest celebration in years in this sweltering city, the Mayor grew nervous, the Chamber of Commerce was puzzled and the space agency was angered and a little confused.
One of the Lindsay administration's top planners resigned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The United States and Hungary today announced a four-point understanding described here as a further stage in the Administration's policy of improving relations with the countries of Eastern Europe.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 15 (AP) -- Police and fire officials reported today that they had received a barrage of phone calls about the course and had asked the village administration to inquire about the contents of the course.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 15 -- There was a "good-by, Allie" chant and one fan even remembered watching the Jets (called the Titans, then) in the old Polo Grounds tonight as clubs wearing the Giants royal blue and the Jets Kelly green brought professional football to Long Island.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Aug. 15 -Mr. McCarthy charged today that the Department of Transportation had withdrawn two safety requirements in permitting the gas shipment.

DAYTON, Ohio, Aug. 14 -Ray Floyd moved away from a nine-way tie today and took over the lead after 36 holes in the Professional Golfers' Association championship as Arnold Palmer reluctantly withdrew.
DENPASAR, Indonesia, Aug. 6 -- The people of Bali, who live in a Garden of Eden and know it, are now debating whether tourism may be the serpent that will destroy their tropical paradise.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -A narcotics investigator for the Government said today that drugs that were found at the home where the actress Sharon Tate and four other persons were found slain last weekend were not considered to be a motive for the slayings.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 -- A major upset seemed in the making here today following last night's play in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.
SEATTLE, Aug. 15 (AP) -Policemen using tear gas and night sticks clashed with longhaired, bearded "street people" in the third night of violence in Seattle's University District.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Marcia Kessler is not about to look a gift horse in the mouth, even if it is from the Internal Revenue Service.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he did not want the Nixon Administration to remove Robert M. Morgenthau as United States Attorney of the Southern District of New York at this time.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -Housing starts suffered a big drop in July while industrial production continued to boom, Government reports disclosed today.

Seilon, Inc., formerly the Seiberling Rubber Company, which lost $1.24-million in the first half of this year, and Gale Industries, Inc., which recently was delisted by the American Stock Exchange, announced major executive shake-ups yesterday.

As evidenced by your Aug. 6 editorial, you read the handwriting on the Blue Cross wall for all to see. On Aug. 14, with the Governor's blessing, the New York Insurance Department approved a 43.3 per cent rate increase.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 15 -- Ever since he reported to camp four weeks ago, Darrell Dess has been off by himself in the corners, a solitary chunk in a gray sweatsuit, pushing his 34-year-old body into shape.

PORT JERVIS, N. Y., Aug. 15 -- Fifty-seven youths attending a summer camp near here were injured today, nine of them seriously, when a truck they were riding in overturned on a wet, winding road in New Jersey's High Point State Park.

The recent letter of John C. Walsh with regard to the killing of the North Pacific fur seals was a matter of great concern to all humanitarians and conservationists. Unfortunately, that letter was far behind the times. The problem is infinitely worse.

The saddest thing about the state's certification of a staggering 43.3 per cent increase in Blue Cross rates is that no form of effective consumer resistance is open to New Yorkers. If they say, "We'll die before we pay these rates," that may be exactly the result of their defiance. Workers may strike against hospitals, even though it is against the law, but the sick cannot.
A little island that was a big obstacle to shipping on the Tamar River in Tasmania state in Australia, is being blasted out of existence.

DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- The Chrysler Corporation today joined the Ford Motor Company in raising the prices of new trucks. Like Ford, Chrysler said it was increasing the cost of 1970 models by 2 per cent, but the actual rise appears much larger.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 15 (Reuters) -- Murder charges were brought today against three Palestinian Arabs who shot up an Israeli airliner here Feb. 18.

Philharmonic Hall's new decor and specially designed acoustical ceiling will undergo its first public appraisal on Tuesday, Sept. 23, when the auditorium is reopened with a benefit concert by the New York Philharmonic.
DETROIT, Aug. 15 -- Two Canadian customs officials refused today to allow a train loaded with phosgene gas to enter the country.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The Department of Defense declined comment today on the action of Canadian customs officials.
MOOSE, Wyo. -- When a cookbook lists recipes for morels, spruce tips, trout shish kebab, braised bear paws, roast mountain sheep and pickled elk heart, any cook worth her salt knows it's different.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- The Agriculture Department further limited today the use of several long-lasting pesticides -- including DDT -- in Government-sponsored programs.

Western Air Lines said yesterday it had canceled a $45-million purchase agreement for five Boeing 707 jetliners because it could not arrange financing now. The planes had been scheduled for delivery in the last three months this year and in January next year.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 15 -- The Travers, the oldest stakes race in the United States, will have its 100th running tomorrow at the Saratoga track and, with its added money raised to $100,000, the renewal will be its richest.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 15 -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy pledged today to transfer the Southern Christian Leadership Conference annual convention, which was to have ended here tomorrow, to Chicago next week to join in another potentially jarring confrontation there between blacks and Mayor Richard J. Daly.
PRAGUE, Aug. 15 -- Defense Minister Martin Dzur told the Czechoslovak Army in an order today that it must be prepared to fight internal opposition forces next week.
Trading remained light but prices continued to edge ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

MANILA, Aug. 15 -- The two-nation board investigating the collision of the United States destroyer Frank E. Evans and the Australian carrier Melbourne placed the primary blame today on the American vessel.
TIFFIN, Ohio, Aug. 15 (UPI) -- Plans to halt a trainload of phosgene gas at an ordinance depot in northern Ohio were scrapped tonight after Army officials said they would refuse the lethal cargo.

We hope, with no confidence whatever, that the ultimate in academic nonsense has been reached in Scarsdale, where a high school course is being given in revolutionary tactics and guerrilla warfare. Last year the students mapped a strategy for taking over the village, and this year student guerrillas, government forces and peasants have been chasing each other through the woods with empty air rifles, water pistols and cans of shaving cream.

The increased level of enemy-initiated attacks in South Vietnam, after a two-month lull, complicates the decision President Nixon now faces on the dimension and timing of the next American troop withdrawal.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 -- Fritz Peterson, the Yankee southpaw, who entered tonight's game against the White Sox with an eye infection, proved there was nothing wrong with his left arm by posting an artistic pitching performance for his 13th victory of the season.

PERTH, Australia, Aug. 15 (AP) -- L. Miller, president of the Australian Inland Exploration Company, a subsidiary of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, said the value of Texas Gulf's previously announced mineral deposit in Australia would likely be lower than the estimate placed on the deposit by industry observers in Australia.

The Nixon Administration has its ax out again for United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau. Apparently the plan is to force him out right after the mayoral election in November and replace him with former State Senator Whitney North Seymour Jr.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 15 -- Zambia's two copper-mining groups have been called upon by the Industrial Development Corporation to present their books for inspection as soon as possible, according to informed sources here today.
Heavy rains pounded the metropolitan area last night, causing widespread power failures in northern New Jersey and flooding that disrupted subway service briefly on the West Side IRT line.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 15 -Residents of Philadelphia's Model Cities neighborhoods charged the Government in Federal District Court today with illegally limiting citizen participation in the Model Cities program.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 15 -Twelve men armed with submachine guns took over a radio station today in Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, and broadcast an attack on the military Government of President Arthur da Costa e Silva.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 -The Federal Communications Commission asked the nation's telephone companies today to discuss with it the quality of their interstate service.
The New York Mets, who lost three straight games under a roof in Houston earlier this week, returned to Shea Stadium last night and lost an 82-minute wait with the weather.

IRVING, Tex., Aug. 15 (AP) -Catherine Lacoste of France, seeking to become the first foreign United States Women's Amateur queen in 33 years, advanced to the final today of the 69th championship, along with Shelley Hamlin, a Stanford University student.
After all the "Injuns," and Tonto (the Uncle Tom of the West), here at last is a novel about a real girl who happens also to be an Indian.
The New York Mets showcased their stars yesterday at Shea Stadium, swept a doubleheader from the San Diego padres and slipped back into second place in the Eastern Division of the National League.

AACHEN, West Germany, Aug. 13 -- Newly presented evidence discloses that the Frankfurt neurologist who first warned against possible dangers in thalidomide was shadowed and spied upon by private detectives working for the drug company that had developed and marketed the tranquilizer.

WASHINGTON -- The three measures sent to Congress last week by President Nixon, if they become enacted, amount to a genuine revolution, probably the equivalent of President Roosevelt's launching of Social Security a third of a century ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Rick Wise pitched a four-hitter and smacked a home run and a single today as the Philadelphia Phillies routed the Houston Astros, 7-0, for their fourth consecutive shutout victory.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Six North Vietnamese officials expelled from Laos last night returned to Vientiane three hours later when their plane was refused permission to land in Hanoi.

ATLANTA, Aug. 16 -- Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia put together today a makeshift coalition of white school board members and a handful of politicians in what may turn out to be the South's last-ditch fight for "freedom of choice" in school desegregation.

THE White House, temporarily situated in the Palm Room of the Waldorf-Astoria while President Nixon visits his dentist, discloses plans for him to greet the men from the moon in mid-Pacific and then to fly around the world with stops in the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand, India, Pakistan and Rumania.
A police stakeout on the Upper West Side resulted yesterday in the arraignment in Criminal Court of a 25-year-old suspect in scores of robberies and muggings recently.

The Japanese, who have learned how to succeed in the automobile business by copying Detroit styling, have gone a step further. The country's largest car manufacturer, Toyota Motor Company, has "liberated" a prestigious Detroit nameplate for its leading 1970 model, which it calls Mark II.
More than half the people receiving welfare money in Nassau, Suffolk and Westchester. Counties are white, many of them ironic victims of a search for a better life in the suburbs.

A FRIEND of mine -- a tough man and a top television director -- once confessed to me over a second highball, "Actors are daredevils . . . I'd never be able to do it." Coming from him, it was the nicest thing I'd ever heard said about the profession. Daredevils! Why, choosing the profession at all is an act of stubborn courage.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 16 -- Denis Hulme, current leader in the Canadian-American Challenge Cup series, ran a record qualifying lap of 100.58 miles an hour today to win the pole position for tomorrow's Buckeye Can-Am.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 16 -- The reigning Vanderbilt Cup champions were eliminated from the Spingold knockout teams tournament here last night in the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals.

The special session of the South Vietnamese National Assembly President Thieu has summoned for tomorrow to act on his revolutionary land reform program has substantial significance for Americans as well as Vietnamese. It could hasten the end of the war.

Alexander Hamilton, "the bastard brat of a Scotch pedlar" -- in John Adams's unkind words -- has only recently had good treatment at the hands of historians. Adams's well-remembered stricture is not the reason for this neglect. Hamilton has suffered from the inordinate popularity of Thomas Jefferson, his antagonist, whose views have often been made out to be the reverse of his own.

MANY players of some experience are in the habit of proclaiming a dangerous half-truth: "Always show a four-card major." By this they mean that the responder to an opening suit bid must strain every nerve to bid spades or hearts holding four cards in either of those suits.

H. Rap Brown, recently elected chairman of the new Student National Coordinating Committee, was granted permission yesterday to travel from New York City to Washington to speak at the National Association of Television and Radio Artists Convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 16 (AP) -- Ed Stroud laced a two-run triple in the eighth inning today and scored on Paul Casanova's sacrifice fly, giving the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 16 -- President Suharto announced this morning in his annual Independence Day state address that 2,500 Communist prisoners were being shipped to the island of Buru in an attempt to rehabilitate them.
