LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 -- A major breakdown in organization disrupted play in the semi-final stage of the Spingold Knockout Team championship here last night. In the third quarter, the transfer of boards between tables was carried out incorrectly, so that the hands played originally in one match were replayed in the other.

Fifteen white Roman Catholics, supporting James Forman's demands for "reparations" and objecting to what they termed the "callous treatment" he had received from the New York Archdiocese, tried unsuccessfully yesterday to see Cardinal Cooke to complain.
MIAMI, Aug. 18 -- Airborne scientists seeded an Atlantic hurricane with silver iodide particles today in an attempt to rob the storm of its heat and thus reduce its energy.

The Times on July 28 presented several commendable news articles detailing the factors behind the crisis in commuter service into New York. One article gave an excellent description of the measures taken by the Chicago and North Western to build a first rate commuter system.
The national field marshal of the Black Panther party said yesterday that four men arrested during the weekend in connection with an alleged Panther robbery plot were not active party members.

Consumers will pay more for their gifts this Christmas despite currency devaluation and an increase in the number of imported products, according to manufacturers displaying their wares at the New York Gift Show. Almost all material costs have gone up since a year ago, they said, and labor rates also have risen.

LOS ANGELES -- Mrs. Loretta Coffman and her three children, Stephanie, 10, Audrey, 6, and Keith, 3, drove happily into the yard of a metal plant on the Los Angeles outskirts a few days ago, deposited 200 battered aluminimum beverage cans, and proudly collected $1.
Total heart transplant operations are here to stay but should be continued only on a controlled experimental basis, several leading heart experts said yesterday.

PRAGUE, Aug. 18 -- Thousands of Communist party activists from across the country poured into the capital tonight for last-minute instructions on how to deal with possible disturbances on Thursday, the first anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion.

At an earlier stage of Nigeria's civil war the arrival of Nnamdi Azikwe in Lagos and his meeting with General Gowon would have created a sensation and sent peace hopes soaring. But the foundering of countless peace initiatives has left the world so pessimistic and cynical about this African tragedy that the visit of Nigeria's first President has nearly escaped notice.
Two producers announced price increases for packaging materials yesterday.
George H. Lesch, chairman of the board and president of Colgate-Palmolive Company, has been elected to the board at American Sugar Company.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 18 -- President Nixon announced today the nomination of Judge Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. of South Carolina to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- The Special Forces officers and men held in a stockade in connection with the reported slaying of a Vietnamese intelligence agent were transferred today to ordinary Army quarters.

ATCO, N. J., Aug. 18 (AP) -- An undercover agent for the Internal Revenue Service was shot and wounded by a sniper today in this Camden County community, about five miles from the spot where another I.R.S. agent was found shot to death a year ago.
There probably were few people who watched the televised pictures of Mars from Mariner 6 earlier this month with more anxiety and satisfaction than Ann Hutchinson.

Abraham D. Beame, the Democratic candidate for City Controller, proposed a series of fiscal measures yesterday designed to yield additional revenues of $333-million a year to the city and $250-million a year to the state.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Prince Metternich of Austria, who had matched wits on numerous occasions with the equally crafty Viscount Castlereagh, is said to have reacted with characteristic suspicion upon learning that Castlereagh had committed suicide on the eve of an important international conference in 1822.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- The Helping Hand Society, made up of outstanding professional basketball players, started arriving today from all parts of the nation for their 11th annual get-together -- the Maurice Stokes benefit game.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 -- Operation Phoenix, a program designed by the United States Central Intelligence Agency to track down and sideline Vietcong officials, is reported to be bogging down. American officials blame local accommodation by the South Vietnamese.
Mayor Lindsay campaigned for two hours in Harlem and the Bronx yesterday afternoon but attracted only small crowds with meager enthusiasm.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- With the death of Robert Kennedy and the retirement of Lyndon Johnson, Everett Dirksen has become the politician Americans most like to imitate. Professional comedians break up Las Vegas with Dirksen imitations; children do Dirksen imitations at the table; even radio commercials now use Dirksen imitations to sell machinery and nostrums.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 18 -- Viktors Pupols of Holly, Wash., a dark-horse entrant in the 70th annual United States Open Chess Championship, took the lead at the end of the seventh round last night by upsetting grandmaster Pal Benko of New York at the Hotel Lincoln here, scoring 6 1/2 points out of 7.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Lawyers for the House of Representatives told a Federal court today that Representative Adam Clayton Powell was not entitled to compensation for his illegal exclusion from Congress and indicated that the lawmakers might not pay it even if it were ordered.

THERMAL pollution, the heating of aquatic habitat by man's works, is a matter of increasing concern to ecologists, for fish, unlike warm-blooded animals, cannot adjust to violent shifts in the temperature of their environment.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 14 -- Bahjat al-Talhouni, whom King Hussein named Premier two days ago, has taken over leadership of the Jordanian Government at a time of apprehension on the part of the King and his top officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- Secretary of the Army Stanley R. Resor flew to Asia today on a trip that will include a visit to the war zone and a review of the investigation in the Special Forces case in South Vietnam.
TOKYO, Aug. 18 -- To her own and everyone else's astonishment, Japan is approaching the status of a creditor nation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 18 -- Ireland's Government pressed hard here today for Security Council intervention in Northern Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The Justice Department has filed a new civil suit for $142,000 in back taxes against Fred B. Black Jr., an aerospace lobbyist and close associate of Robert G. Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- The World Bank reported today net income of $171.4-million in the year ended June 30, little changed from $169.1-million in the previous year.

The passing of a giant in the arts scarcely ripples the surface of a world preoccupied with novelty and the merchandising of a new "avant garde" every Monday morning. Mies van der Rohe, in his own words, was not a "Monday-morning architect." His "avant garde" lasted a half-century and is still going strong. His values -- order, clarity, rationality, discipline and an uncompromising adherence to absolute standards of art and excellence -- are unfashionable today.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 18 -- Two frustrating plays undid Mel Stottlemyre and the New York Yankees tonight as they lost to the Kansas City Royals, 6-1, in the opener of a three-game series.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 18 -- While Protestants and Roman Catholics in most countries are being drawn into cooperation by the ecumenical spirit, those in Northern Ireland have been throwing firebombs at each other in the name of Christ.
The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, facing a strike threat by its tunnel employes, agreed yesterday to cooperate in a study to be made on the extent of carbon monoxide in the city's tunnels.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Lawyers concerned with the legal aspects of welfare reform hailed today the decision of a Federal court in New York upholding the privacy of welfare recipients as one of the most significant in a growing list of court-ordered protections of the poor.
DALLAS, Aug. 18 (AP) -- A Federal District judge told lawyers in a civil case today that food must be distributed in 106 Texas counties that do not have a program of Federal food for the poor.

WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, will revise its Saturday night schedule next month to provide an evening of continuous musical variety, including folk, pop, jazz and classical music. The program changes, which will begin Sept. 6, will be carried from 7:06 P.M. to midnight on WQXR-AM and from 7:06 P.M. to 2 A.M on WQXR-FM.
Mayor Lindsay urged the Board of Education yesterday to begin a large-scale program of preventive narcotic and drug abuse education in the city's schools.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Jimmy Ellis, who used to help Cassius Clay get in shape for his championship fights, sparred with the former titleholder today to prepare for a fight in London next month.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 18 -- Secretary General Thant disclosed today that he had asked Israel and Lebanon to permit the assignment of United Nations observers on both sides of their troubled border.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy would run a slightly poorer race against President Nixon in 1972 than either Senator Edmund S. Muskie or Hubert H. Humphrey, and his popularity has declined since his accident in Chappaquidick, according to a Louis Harris poll published yesterday in The New York Post.

In a decision that could radically affect welfare procedures, a three-man Federal Court ruled here yesterday that recipients may not be denied public assistance solely for refusing to allow case-workers into their homes without a warrant.
WABC Radio has rejected as "too political" a religious program on which a Methodist bishop criticized the South Vietnamese Government and the American position in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- President Nixon's nomination of Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. to the United States Supreme Court aroused immediate opposition today among civil rights, labor and other liberal groups.

About 60 demonstrators, including women with baby carriages, blocked off Foster Avenue between East 55th and 58th Streets in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn yesterday, to protest the lack of sanitation services and the spread of rats in the area.

Against a backdrop of decaying tenements, a low-income housing project and the Penn Central tracks that carry commuters to the suburbs, a purple-bereted youth told yesterday why his group, the Young Lords Organization, had sparked a garbage-dumping protest in East Harlem on Sunday.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 18 (AP) -- Nahashon Isaac Njenga Njoroge, a 32-year-old member of the Kikuyu tribe, was ordered today to stand trial in the Kenya High Court on a charged of having murdered Economics Minister Tom Mboya on July 5.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved higher yesterday, helped by the firmness of the pound sterling on foreign-exchange markets.

Senator Charles E. Goodell said yesterday that there would be no Republican party battle over his Senate seat next year. He denied that he had "complained" to Governor Rockefeller about opposition to him within the party, and said he expected Mr. Rockefeller to support him if he ran.

The City Planning Commission deferred decision again yesterday on the proposed $1.1-billion housing and office development, Battery Park City, scheduled to be built on landfill in the Hudson River near the tip of Manhattan.
Robert K. Ruskin, Commissioner of Investigation, announced yesterday the arrest of three men involved in thefts or swindles in connection with welfare money.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Apg. 18 -- Members of the National Union of South African Students applauded with politeness tonight the empty chair on the stage at the University of Witwatersrand's great hall after having heard the taped speech of the man who did not come to deliver it, Representative Ogden R. Reid of New York.

" What we wanted to do," said the shipping man from London, "was to enter the era of containerization in a big way, very large scale, with capital expenditure far beyond the normal commitment of any individual shipping line."
LONDON, Aug. 18 -- The British pound recovered strongly today after the sinking spell last week produced by the devaluation of the franc.

SEATTLE, Aug. 18 (UPI) -- The General Assembly of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) voted overwhelming support today for its General Board, which had denounced the "black manifesto," but expanded its own program to help end poverty and racial injustice.
GULFPORT, Miss., Aug. 18 -- Just what will a hurricane wind of 190 miles an hour do?
HAMAMATSU, Japan, Aug. 13 -- "Attack is the best defense," a Japanese general told a group of visitors at the air base here.

NORTHPORT, L.I., Aug. 18 -- The first of six cables that will enable the Long Island Lighting Company to tap power from New England for emergencies on the Island and, if needed, in the city, was laid on the bottom of Long Island Sound today.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 18 (Reuters) -- Talks between the United States, Peru, Chile and Ecuador on fishing rights off the Pacific coast of South America will adjourn tomorrow until later this year, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 -- A group of 200 Korean rsidents in the United States asked President Nixon by telegram today not to endorse the attempt by President Chung Hee Park of South Korea to have that nation's Constitution amended so that he could run for a third term.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Aug. 18 (AP) -- A hearing will be held in Federal District Court here on a Government attempt to have secret testimony, heard by a grand jury in its investigation of price-fixing charges against the Hanes Knitting Company, turned over to the Federal Trade Commission for possible action.
Steel production climbed 1.5 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
The Jets and the Giants had something in common yesterday -- no running, no hitting, no football.

The choice of Court of Appeals Judge Clement Haynsworth for the Supreme Court is disappointing. HONG KONG, Aug. 19 -Communist China accused the Soviet Union today of hundreds of aggressive military actions along the Chinese-Soviet border during June and July and demanded that "activities of intrusion and provocation" end immediately.

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 19 -Grandmaster Robert Byrne of Indianapolis moved into a threeway first-place tie with William Martz of Wisconsin and Milan Vukcevich of Ohio in the eighth round of the 70th Annual United States Open Chess Championship at the Hotel Lincoln here last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -President Nixon's welfare reform plan will not scrap Federal food stamps for needy families, the White House consultant on hunger said today.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 19 -- The game against the world champion New York Jets had come and gone, the morning after had come and gone, and today only the coaches and about a half-dozen players showed up at the New York Giants' training camp.
NARRAGANSETT, R. I., Aug. 19 (AP) -- All six seeded players scored straight set victories and advanced today in the secondday matches of the national senior women's tennis championships.
The late Charles Edison, a son of Thomas A. Edison, left an estate of between $8-million and $12-million, according to his will filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court here.
Speaking from the stage of the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center yesterday, Mayor Lindsay hailed 3,000 college students who had summer jobs with the city as New York's "peace corps."

Victor Muscat, the embattled financier, disclosed yesterday that he was considering an effort to stall the merger of Defiance Industries and ElTronics, Inc., because Defiance had failed to declare a dividend.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to advance yesterday as trading volume expanded.
Madison Square Garden was given a 50-50 chance yesterday of corralling Forest Ward into the ring with George Foreman.

Operations of Norton Simon, Inc., in the fiscal year ended June 30 resulted in a 15.9 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 4.7 per cent. The company's report was issued yesterday by David J. Mahoney, president, who became chief executive officer on Monday.
A group of Puerto Ricans announced yesterday their support of Controller Mario A. Procaccino for Mayor.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19 (AP) -Ken Holtzman pitched the fifth no-hit, no-run game of the season today and the first by a Chicago Cubs hurler in nine years as he beat the Atlanta Braves, 3-0.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Rudy Turcotte demonstrated that he knew exactly how to ride Isidor Bieber's Parida today. The 20-year-old younger brother of the more seasoned Ron moved his mount to the front soon after the start of the one-mile purse for fillies and mares, kept her there all the way, and scored a three-quarter length triumph.

SAYVILLE, L. I., Aug. 19 -High winds and heavy seas resulted in only one of the two scheduled races being sailed today, as the Raven Class national championships got underway in Great South Bay. A member of the City Council urged yesterday that bus drivers at least give change in redeemable scrip when the exactchange requirement goes into effect on city buses on Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -President Nixon is getting conflicting advice from Administration officials on whether to propose to the Russians a joint moratorium of flight tests of multiple warheads for intercontinental missiles.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- Lew Alcindor led the East All-Stars to an 80-79 victory over the West All-Stars in the 11th annual Maurice Stokes benefit game tonight at Kutsher's Sports Academy. Willis Reed of the Knicks scored two fouls in the final three seconds to decide the game.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Third Monarch won his third straight race today as he outsprinted six other rivals in the Staten Island purse and finished one length ahead of Pretty Tweetie. Final Encore was third in the blanket finish.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman said today that the Thai Government had pledged to President Nixon during his recent visit here that it would never ask for United States combat troops to fight insurgents here.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe and Mrs. Margaret Smith Court, the defending champions, led an advance of American men and foreign women in the United States National tennis championships -- Ashe with difficulty and Mrs. Court handily.
A 14th-inning home run by Tommie Agee gave the New York Mets a 1-0 victory over Juan Marichal and the San Francisco Giants last night in a soap-opera classic before 48,968 persons in Shea Stadium.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 19 -- An Israeli spokesman announced today that Egyptian antiaircraft fire downed an Israeli jet this afternoon during a 20-minute raid against Egyptian positions west of the Suez Canal.

JERUSALEM -- The drab first anniversary of Czechoslovakia's military occupation by Soviet troops underscores the fact that small countries are passive pawns to great power whim unless they audaciously master their own fate at the risk of holocaust.

Howard Samuels, a former Under Secretary of Commerce, charged yesterday that "partisan political" appointments to the Public Service Commission by Governor Rockefeller were responsible for the state agency's alleged lack of longrange planning.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 19 -- An old New York Yankee formula used all too seldom in recent years -- a powerful pitching performance backed up by slugging outfielders -- produced a 5-1 victory over the Kansas City Royals tonight.

NIAGARA FALLS, Aug. 19 -The State Air Pollution Control Board opened hearings here tonight aimed at setting new and tougher air pollution standards for the Niagara Frontier, a heavily industrialized region that once was to have been allowed to have the most lenient controls in the state.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 (AP) -- Hundreds of Americans were sent into a battle near Danang today to aid two United States infantry companies in the biggest ground fight in the north since the enemy stepped up attacks last week.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United States Auto Club directors named William J. Smyth of New Orleans today as the organization's first executive director. They also froze racing engine sizes until Jan. 1, 1972.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19 -- The director of the Cook County Hospital blood bank resigned today in the midst of several investigations into possible mishandling of the agency's funds.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, responding to a request from Brooklyn District Attorney Eugene Gold, yesterday appointed a special prosecutor to replace the District Attorney's office in seven pending criminal cases.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- Joseph A. Yablonski rejected today a proposal by W. A. Boyle, president of the United Mine Workers, to have the union's election this fall supervised by a "fair election committee.''

LONDON, Aug. I9 (UPI) -The 1.2 million bags of coffee exports withheld from the world market by a decision of the International Coffee Council last months will be released as planned to the market tomorrow, the Secretariat of the International Coffee Association announced here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board today authorized Lincoln First Bank, Inc., a Rochester holding company, to acquire control of a new bank that will take over the National Bank of Westchester, White Plains.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 -- Roman Polanski, the film director, denied today reports that his hillside home had been the scene of a wild drug party on the night of Aug. 8, when his wife, Sharon Tate, the actress, and four other persons were murdered.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 19 -A State Supreme Court Justice has ruled that a religious institution loses a portion of its immunity from taxation when it leases part of its property for commercial use.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -The capital is now relaxing in the summer heat. The Congress has gone on holiday and the President is running the Government from California with the help of three Jet-Stars which fly documents and aides across the continent to San Clemente three days a week.

Jules Irving, head of the Lincoln Center repertory company, confirmed yesterday that he was well along in negotiations for Sam Shepard's "Operation Sidewinder." If details are agreed on, Michael A. Schultz will be the director.

A hitherto unknown short story by F. Scott Fitzgerald, believed to be his only serious fiction about a Negro, has been discovered among his papers at the Princeton University Library. Thrift institutions in New York are moving rapidly to take advantage of a new state law that permits mergers between mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations.

Electrical power was restored to more than 2,800 families in a large apartment development in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn yesterday after a transformer fire had plunged the complex into darkness Monday night.
CAIRO, Aug. 19 -- The Egyptian military command announced today that antiaircraft gunners shot down three Israeli aircraft during a raid on positions in the southern sector of the Suez Canal.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The National Basketball Players Association threatened today to take all necessary measures, including a strike, to prevent the proposed merger between the National and American Basketball Associations.

The long-awaited endorsement of Mayor Lindsay's candidacy by Herman Badillo serves to cap a new trend in city politics. The realization on the part of many Democratic leaders that the welfare of the city as a whole must supersede rigid party lines bodes well for the type of innovative fusion government that Lindsay has come to represent.
Commercial shipping in the New Orleans-Mobile area was dealt a severe blow by Hurricane Camille.

Board of Education reported yesterday that construction contracts totaling $174million were awarded in the year that ended June 30. It was twice the figure for the best previous year, 1965-66, when the sum was $84.5-million.

RICHMOND, Aug. 19 -- William C. Battle today defeated Henry E. Howell in a runoff primary for Virginia's Democratic gubernatorial nomination.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Aug. 19 -- The nomination yesterday of Clement F. Haynsworth Jr. to the United States Supreme Court has, predictably, excited many of his fellow citizens here in his home town.

For the 11 races of this season's $1-million Can-Am, the Sports Car Club of America has made two changes in scoring: (1) The season is divided into two segments and (2) points are distributed to a depth of 10 positions (20-1512-10-8-6-4-3-2-1) instead of the previous six.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -- The number of persons officially classified as poor in the United States declined by two million last year to 25.4 million, but one-third of the Negroes are classed as poor, a new Census Bureau report disclosed today.

The National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence has stated that "with a few scattered exceptions handguns are not sporting guns." (News story, July 29.) Policyholders in the fourstate area swept by Hurricane Camille are expected to recover as much as $100-million, the Insurance Information Institute estimated here last night.
DOVER, Del., Aug. 19 -- The General Motors Corporation has paid under protest more than $1-million in Delaware state income taxes so it can fulfill a contract to build buses for a state agency.
The stock market stretched its technical rally yesterday to four gaining sessions in a row as trading volume boomed to 12.64 million shares.

EMEKUKU, Biafra (Nigeria), Aug. 19 -- Among the Biafran casualties brought to the hospital here are soldiers with a strange and bloodless disability unknown in past Nigerian tribal wars. Biafrans call them "ndi artillery," or "artillery people."
MIAMI, Aug. 19 -- Weather scientists said today that their attempt to seed Hurricane Debbie was "a huge operational success."

JERICHO, L. I., Aug. 19 -The team of Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis and Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches took a one-stroke lead in the first round of the Barbara S. Kirkland Memorial 36-hole golf tournament today.

WHEN he was 10 years old, Jacques Ernest Jean Piccard stood in a field one day in Switzerland and watched a balloon carry his father up into the blue sky until the huge balloon became a speck and disappeared.

BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- Bobby Seale, national chairman of the Black Panther party, was arrested here today in connection with the kidnap and murder of a Panther member in Connecticut last May.
Benning Wentworth, an admitted homosexual, yesterday fought another round in his three-year effort to prevent the Defense Department from revoking his security clearance.
An organization supporting the Roman Catholics in Northern Ireland called yesterday for a boycott of British goods in this country.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19 -- A proposal to deliver more than 1.5 million tons of coal a year to a nearby thermo-electric power generating station by rail and water was made here today by the American Steamship Company.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today that two members of the Senate Armed Services Committee had examined a copy of a secret military contingency plan negotiated in 1965 by the United States and Thailand. The Senators went to the Pentagon to see it.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 -- The Open Admissions Committee, an adjunct of the Northern New England Student Health Project, said today that it had presented a demand to 26 health science schools in the metropolitan Boston area for a revision of admission policies.
TOKYO, Aug. 19 -- "Our desires are infinite," a Japanese admiral said. "It is the politicians who decide what we will actually get."

GULFPORT, Miss., Aug. 19 -Limited martial law was imposed today on Mississippi's coastal strip in the wake of Hurricane Camille. Gov. John Bell Williams said the death toll might soar far higher than first feared.

NAPLES, Italy, Aug. 19 (AP) -- United States officials are puzzled by a Soviet naval build-up in the Mediterranean. A Navy spokesman said there were 63 to 65 Soviet ships in the Mediterranean. The Soviet ships outnumbered the more powerful United States Sixth Fleet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -The Federal Reserve Board made public today a special survey indicating that plant and equipment investment by big business would level off next year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 19 -- The Security Council has been called to meet at 10:30 A.M. tomorrow at Ireland's request to discuss the disorders in Northern Ireland.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The Army has informed a member of Congress that the arrests of the eight Special Forces soldiers were made without notification to the Pentagon.
KINGSPORT, Tenn., Aug. 19 (AP) -- Kingsport and its environs were invaded today by an army of crickets, possibly because of Hurricane Camille.
A narcotics addict who almost became a policeman was sentenced to 90 days in jail yesterday after pleading guilty to a charge of possession of dangerous drugs and implements.

The Pittsburgh Pirates thought they had won the 1968 National League pennant on Dec. 15, 1967. They were wrong.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined toward the end of trading yesterday after opening higher in reaction to Monday's rise on Wall Street.

The Western world's first supersonic transport, the 1,450 - mile - an hour British - French Concorde, is scheduled to fly faster than sound for the first time early next month.
PRAGUE, Aug. 19 -- Policemen and troops, backed by armored cars and throwing tear gas, today broke up nonviolent demonstrations in Wenceslas Square against the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia.
LONDON, Aug. 19 -- Early manuscripts and some unpublished poems of Alfred Lord Tennyson, which are at Trinity College of Cambridge University, are now open to scholars.

Once again New York is about to select judges for its highest civil court through a dismal and degrading political process that should have been eliminated years ago. The head of the city office that rules on rent increases and decreases and evictions in lower Manhattan has ownership in four apartment buildings in the area, Assemblyman Peter A. A. Berle said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 -The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today yet another increase in the amount of money it will pump each week into the hardpressed mortgage market.

The Most Rev. James P. Shannon says that after a year of frustration he decided to resign from his post in the Roman Catholic Church because he felt "unable to cope or to manage within the ecclesiastical system in which I was being asked to function."
GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 19 (UPI) -- The Green Bay Packers traded Ron Kostelnik, a regular defensive tackle, to the Baltimore Colts today for a future draft choice.

A radio-teleprinter device about the size of a portable typewriter, to be used in police cars and designed to provide a written back-up to voiced messages from headquarters, has received interim approval effective next Wednesday from the Federal Communications Commission for use in public safety vehicles.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea Jr. said today that he had heard that the Long Island Rail Road's new equipment would not work properly in the years ahead, and refused to share Governor Rockefeller's optimism that the line would become the nation's finest in two months.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 19 -Robert Allen of the Noroton, (Conn.) Yacht Club and Jody Smith, Cedar Point Y.C., Westport, Conn., won division championships of the Junior Yacht Racing Association's novice open regatta today after the third and final race in the two-day series off Stmford Y.C.
THE HAGUE, Aug. 19 -Surinam police units and Guyanese soldiers clashed today along their disputed border.

Rod Laver of Australia and Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones of England were selected as the top seeded players for the United States open tennis championships, Aug. 27 to Sept. 7, the United States Lawn Tennis Association said yesterday.
SCRAPPED motor vehicle tires are going to sea in increasing numbers to provide homes for fish.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20 -- An attempt was made during the night to steal Harvard University's copy of the Gutenberg Bible from the Widener Library.

VENICE, La., Aug. 20 -- The long line of orange buses could be seen a long way off down the highway in this flat Mississippi Delta country. The caravan snaked along Route 23 southward toward the shattered end of Plaquemines Parish, the alluvial finger of Louisiana that juts 80 miles out into the Gulf of Mexico.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 20 -- While 300 foreign exchange students helped the Jets do their pushups today by shouting "oop, down . . . oop, down," the Super Bowl champions returned to the field for the first time since their trouncing of the Giants last Sunday.

A $75-million Bell System debenture offering that was expected to give direction to the corporate bond market received a "so-so" reception yesterday and thus provided little insight as to whether interest rates are, as many believe, heading lower.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 20 -- Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther party's national chairman, was held today on a murder charge in the slaying of a former Panther in New Haven, Conn., last May.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 20 -- A civilian lawyer for three of the eight Special Forces soldiers accused in the reported murder of a Vietnamese double agent said after a hearing today that he expected all eight to be exonerated.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 20 -- Another slight cut in Texas oil production was ordered today by the Texas Railroad Commission after a hearing at which purchasing company spokesmen made no comment at all on the market situation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 -- The Department of Housing and Urban Development has announced its first major loan under the college housing program to a student-owned cooperative.

Volume declined and prices slipped yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. Turnover amounted to 3,298,640 shares, compared with 5,173,335 traded on Tuesday.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 21 -- Prince Yonder of the Chance Hill Farm was as far back as any horse had a right to be in the early running of the $17,850 Promise hurdle today.
PRAGUE, Aug. 21 (Reuters) -- The office of The New York Times in Prague was ordered closed today and its correspondnt, Paul Hofmann, was ordered to be expelled from CzechosloVakia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21 -Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird announced today that he had ordered cuts of 100,000 men from the armed forces and $1.5-billion from the Pentagon's budget for the current fiscal year.
The Federal Reserve kept the money markets on a tight rein in the week ended Wednesday but carefully refrained from making credit any tighter, banking figures released yesterday showed.
HONOLULU, Aug. 21 -- An AWOL marine who tried to join his visiting parents for dinner at a Waikiki Hotel lost his sanctuary at the Church of the Crossroads last night.
Dr. Eugene S. Callender was elected president of the New York Urban Coalition yesterday.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, Aug. 21 -- The Army today concluded its investigation into allegations of murder and conspiracy against eight Special Forces soldiers held after the reported death of a Vietnamese double agent on June 20.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 21 -- You can scribble the message on the subway walls or pass it through the grapevine by the spoken word: "Tucker Lives."

DUBLIN, Aug. 21 -- The Government of the Republic of Ireland said tonight that the agreement reached in London Tuesday between Britain and Northern Ireland had produced very little that would contribute to an effective solution for "the political, social and economic injustices from which the minority in the six counties have suffered so grievously and for so long."

LINCOLN, Neb., Aug. 21 -- Grandmaster Robert Byrne of Indianapolis took the lead at the end of the 10th round in the 70th Annual United States Open Chess Championship at the Hotel Lincoln here last night when he drew with Paul Poschel of Michigan in a short-short 16-move English Opening.

In November, 1965, the people of Maspeth in Queens -- the hard-working Poles, Lithuanians, Germans, Irish and Italians who had always loyally supported Mayor Robert F. Wagner -- voted overwhelmingly not for the Democratic candidate for Mayor, Abraham D. Beame, but for the Conservative party nominee, William F. Buckley.

RICHMOND, Aug. 22 -- Flood waters crested to a record level at Richmond today and began slowly receding after inflicting a death toll in the western part of Virginia that the state's governor said might exceed 100.
Cook Industries, Inc., Memphis-based cotton and grain merchandise and insurance underwriter, is planning to diversify further through the proposed acquisition of Riverside Industries of Marks, Miss.

Films by Robert Bresson, Susan Sontag, Eric Rohmer, Josef von Sternberg, and the late Max Ophuls are included in the program of the Seventh New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The festival will run from Sept. 16 through Oct. 2.
A young Queens couple and a youth were killed and four young men were injured last night in a head-on automobile collision on Clearview Expressway on the Queens approach to Throgs Neck Bridge.

The Western Bancorporation, the nation's largest multiple-bank holding company, said yesterday that it had started to sell commercial paper (unsecured corporate notes) through a wholly owned subsidiary, the Western Bancorporation Credit Corporation.

TORONTO, Aug. 22 (AP) -- National Hockey League owners have agreed to assume the full cost of the players pension fund and are also willing to discuss the controversial reserve clause, Alan Eagleson, executive director of the Players' Association, said today.
The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., disclosed plans yesterday to raise more than $55-million through the sale to stockholders of 1.9 million new common shares.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (AP) -- The United States protested to Czechoslovakia today over her expulsion of a correspondent of The New York Times. It accused the Czechoslovaks of trying "to influence the editorial policy of an American newspaper."

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 22 -- Harem Lady of the Hobeau Farm showed to excellent advantage in the $29,050 Seneca Handicap today. The 5-year-old mare, racing just off the pace most of the way, spurted in the stretch to score a six-length triumph in the 1 5/8-mile turf event, at a payoff of $17.40.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 -- The enemy was reported to be bringing up reinforcements today in a battle south of Danang that has raged since Sunday.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 22 -- President Ceausescu reaffirmed Rumania's alliance with the neighboring Soviet Union today but stressed that the overthrow of a pro-Nazi dictatorship here 25 years ago and the progress of the Communist party and the country since then were mainly the result of his countrymen's efforts.
MOSCOW, Aug. 22 -- The Soviet Union praised the Czechoslovak authorities today for using "a firm hand" to put down demonstrations on the anniversary of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 22 -- A crowd of 38,710 turned out tonight to welcome the Minnesota Twins home from a tumultuous three-week road trip, and thoroughly enjoyed watching a 6-0 victory over the New York Yankees in perfect summer weather.
A new type of catamaran mother ship for deepsea barge carrying is being given tank model tests at the Davidson Laboratory of Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N. J.

Luis Garcia of Mexico was the first name picked yesterday in the draw for the United States Open tennis championships, which start Wednesday at Forest Hills, and thus became the unluckiest player in the tournament.
The London Stock Exchange was steady yesterday on small turnover.
DETROIT, Aug. 22 -- The nation s new-car dealers delivered 200,395 American made cars Aug. 11-20 against 195,583 a year ago, the four automobile manufacturers reported today.

Revelations of drug company activities to obtain monopolies on new drugs, monopolies enabling them to keep prices very high, have focused attention on the problem of high drug prices in the United States.

LONDON, Aug. 22 (Reuters) -- The London Stock Exchange Council today ordered the suspension of all dealings in the shares of Pergamon Press, a London publishing company headed by Robert Maxwell, a millionaire Laborite member of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The United States and Thailand have agreed to begin talks on reducing the 49,000-man American force in Thailand, the State Department said today.

Lloyd's Register of Shipping, which has catalogued the world's merchant marine from London since 1760, has a new executive director, Colin Merriam Glover. He has been named to suceed W. C. G. Knowles, who died early this year.

WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 22 -- Overcall, clearly the nation's outstanding pacer, scored his 14th straight victory, 13 of them this year, by taking the Tar Heel Pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Timed in 2 minutes flat, Mrs. Helen R. Buck's 6-year-old bay defeated the Red Sheep Stables Fulla Napoleon by three-quarters of a length as he posted his eighth 2-minutes-or-faster mile of the campaign.

The Harlem Professional Basketball League, sponsored by the Mayor's Urban Task Force, will send its all-tournament team against the National Basketball Association All- Star squad tomorrow at Intermediate School 201, 127th Street and Madison Avenue, at 4 P.M. Admission is $1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has been invited to explain in Federal Court why Secretary Robert H. Finch wishes to withdraw plans for the immediate desegregation of 33 Mississippi school districts.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced a crackdown on "disreputable tenant relocation companies" that he said hired "thugs" to evict tenants from rent-controlled buildings.

A move to replace tile Democratic leadership of the City Council, with liberals and conservatives teaming against the organization men of the center, is developing in anticipation of an election that is certain to alter drastically the Council's membership.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 -- An American official was reported to have paid a visit today to a woman who fears that her husband was the victim of the slaying in which eight United States soldiers have been detained.
A Queens man and his common-law wife were charged yesterday with the slaying of a Pace College student who was shot from the back of a truck reportedly carrying marijuana.
The American Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in continued light trading.

State Senator John J. Marchi yesterday criticized the assertion by Controller Mario A. Procaccino that he would try to save the 20-cent transit fare by subsidizing it from general city funds if state and Federal aid could not be obtained.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 22 -- The third regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week was all but destroyed by lack of wind today, but served Shawhan Fox of the Larchmont Yacht Club well enough.

BUFFALO, Aug. 22 -- The Baltimore Colts, champions of the National Football League, continued their march through the American League tonight by defeating the Buffalo Bills, 20-7, before a capacity Crowd of 45,750. It was the fourth straight preseason victory for the Colts over A.F.L. opposition.

What could be more cooling on a sticky summer night than a big, beautiful and clean -- yes, clean -- show spilling out of a dazzling cornucopia onto the Madison Square Garden rink? The Chinese cuisine is not, as most Westeners seem to believe, the most elaborate and intricate on earth. Compared to the classic French kitchen -- and the comparison is valid since the two rank as the world's greatest -- the preparation of Chinese food with rare exceptions is a model of simplicity.

The secession of a group of Negro students from the National Student Association is a blow to the civil rights movement on college campuses and to the formation of a cohesive academic community. WETHERSFIELD, Conn. Aug. 28 -- With a threatened caddie strike averted and a record crowd of 10,000 for a local pro-amateur event on hand today, officials of the Greater Hartford open were anticipating only sunshine for their 72-hole tournament that starts tomorrow.

Helicopter service from atop the Pan Am Building could be resumed -- possibly by Jan. 1 -- if a series of agreements filed in Washington yesterday are approved by the Civil Aeronautics Board and the city allows the helicopter service to resume on the 59-story midtown skyscraper.
IN the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 26 -- A city ordinance went into effect this month making it a crime punishable by fine and imprisonment for Buenos Aires drivers to curse pedestrians or other drivers too emphatically.

FORREST CITY, Ark., Aug. 28 -- "I don't know what they want," said a worried businessman. Outside his office on the streets of Forrest City, angry whites were marching along the sidewalks demanding "law and order."

IN THE HIETDUC VALLEY, South Vietnam, Aug. 28 -When 900 American soldiers began moving along the valley floor south of Danang at 5:30 A.M. today, the temperature stood at 84 degrees. By noon it was 118 degrees and enemy fire had killed at least a dozen of the Americans.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -The State Department said today that it saw little likelihood of a Soviet air strike against Communist China's nuclear facilities, but it acknowledged that it had heard rumors that Moscow had sounded out Communist supporters elsewhere on this matter.
The Queen Elizabeth 2, the huge liner whose short seagoing life has been beset by problems, suffered a power failure yesterday as she was preparing to leave here for Le Havre and Southhampton.
The New York Times announced today that all cigarette advertisements it publishes, beginning Jan. 1, 1970, must carry a health warning as well as the cigarette's tar and nicotine content.

HOUSTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Craig Morton threw a 34-yard touchdown pass to Lance Rentzel and set up another touchdown with a 34-yard pass to Bob Hayes to lead the Dallas Cowboys to a 14-11 victory tonight over the Houston Oilers before 55,310, the largest football crowd in Astrodome history.

PRAGUE, Aug. 28 -- Michael Hornsby, correspondent here for The Times of London, was informed by the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry today that his accreditation would not be renewed after its expiration at the end of this month.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 -- The Ford Motor Company reduced today the warranty protection on its 1970 cars, ending the five-year, 50,000-mile protection on power train parts, such as the engine.

A baseball record book that eclipses anything published on the subject before was unveiled yesterday at a press conference in Mamma Leone's Restaurant, with the blessing of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and the proud expectations of Information Concepts, Inc., the editors, and the Macmillan Company, the publishers.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

The New York Telephone Company, stung by mounting criticism of operators who irritate rather than inform, will initiate a pilot training program aimed at increasing the efficiency of the girls it hires to provide directory assistance.
Arthur Ashe scored three important personal victories during the last 48 hours, but only one came on the courts at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.
Prices moved narrowly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and wound up edging up slightly in continued light trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The Navy ordered today a general court-martial for Seaman Roger Lee Priest, who had published an antiwar newsletter while assigned to the Pentagon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) -- A Government economist said today that there appeared to be little hope for any early slackening in the nation's sharpest inflationary spiral in 18 years despite a slight drop in August wholesale prices.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 28 -- President Nixon accepted today the resignation of John H. Crooker Jr. as chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board. The resignation of Mr. Crooker, a Democrat from Texas, from the $40,000-a-year post had been expected.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers has sent Thailand a message of American support to calm her concern over public remarks by Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 28 -- Judge James A. Boyle denied today motions to apply criminal trial procedures to an inquest next week in the death of a secretary who drowned in an automobile accident involving Senator Edward M. Kennedy.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 28 -- Prime Minister James Chichester-Clark of Northern Ireland tonight rejected Prime Minister Lynch's proposal to merge Ulster and the Irish Republic.
NEW IBERIA, La., Aug. 28 -- This immaculately clean bayou town came very close to a riot yesterday -- and surprised, shocked people on both sides of the color line are trying to find out why.
Prices on the London stock market slipped back to the previous day's levels yesterday after moving moderately higher at the start. Trading remained light and lacking in direction.
MOSCOW, Aug. 28 -- The Soviet Union suggested today that a war with Communist China would inevitably involve the use of nuclear weapons and "would not spare a single continent.''

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 28 (AP) -- A stockholder has filed suit in Delaware's Chancery Court to block a McCrory Corporation offer to buy 450,000 shares of its own common stock from shareholders, alleging the real purpose is to aid the Rapid American Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 28 -- Th New York Mets rested on their laurels today while Manager Gil Hodges prepared for four games against the San Francisco Giants and the rest of the baseball world marveled at their surge toward the top of the National League's Eastern Division.

CAIRO, Friday, Aug. 29 -- Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the Cairo editor and semiofficial spokesman, called today for intensive Arab pressure on the United States and hinted that this could best be carried out by oil-producing countries.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company reported yesterday record sales, but a decline in profits for the third successive quarter.

Every motorist who drives into midtown Manhattan is painfully aware of the high cost of parking. Within the past year the rates charged by garages and parking lots have risen anywhere from 10 to 65 per cent, usually for wretchedly poor service. The question the city must now decide is whether regulating these rates by law would make matters better or worse.
A host of executive appointments yesterday included the election of new chief executives for Harvey Aluminum, Inc., and the United Fruit Company.

ASHEVILLE, N. C., Aug. 28 -- The 86-year-old widow or Carl Sandburg relinquished today ownership of the poet's home, Connemara, in nearby Flat Rock, to the National Park Service for preservation as a national historic site.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The State and Defense Departments tried today to reconcile their public differences over the interpretation of a decline in the infiltration of North Vietnamese soldiers into South Vietnam.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., Aug. 28 -- He is slender and 19 years old and when he walks through the dormitory the New York Giants hide behind locked doors.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The auto industry sent its people here today to explain that the "jar bag" approach to auto safety has potential but it needs more development.

Prompt action by the City of New York and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in tolling bridges and tunnels would encourage a more balanced transportation system and limit the number and magnitude of transit fare increases.

Although this second book of poems by the noted American critic and teacher M. L. Rosenthal is in its way an extension of the first, it is marked by a deeper and more enriched tone. His wry attitude, his sense of limits in man's relations to nature and to history are still present. His unwillingness to strike rhetorical poses gives his work that playfulness and surface lightness that characterized the earlier, "Blue Boy on Skates.
Two major steamship lines yesterday withdrew efforts to obtain Government aid for trans-Pacific containership routes and will try to work out their plans without subsidy.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Aug. 28 -- Hoping that Paul Brown, the Cincinnati Bengals' coach and general manager, might be bluffing and would withdraw his claim, Weeb Ewbank, his New York Jets counterpart, played his hand right up to the 4 P.M. deadlline today before recalling Billy Joe, the running back, from the waiver list.

CHICAGO, Aug. 28 (UPI) -- Home runs by Billy Williams and Jim Hickman backed the five-hit pitching of Ferguson Jenkins today as the Chicago Cubs scored a 3-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds. That broke the Cubs' four-game losing streak and increased their lead to 2 1/2 games over the New York Mets in the National League's Eastern Division.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 28 -- A Roman Catholic woman who moved back into her home this week walked down Ardmoulin Avenue in the rain today and told of last night's trouble. Some young Protestants, she said, came into the area and started to shout threats and some of her neighbors heard shots.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28 -- The United States Special Forces group in South Vietnam was assigned a new commanding officer today for the second time in six weeks.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 28 -- Governor Rockefeller was reported today to be considering the elimination of formulas that mandate annual increases in state aid to local governments.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 -- The American Medical Association said today that Dr. John Adriani, a New Orleans surgeon and pharmacologist, was qualified to be director of the Bureau of Medicine in the Food and Drug Administration.

Shortly before 5 P.M. the other day, the telephone rang in the cramped, dimly lighted ambulance office deep inside Bellevue Hospital. Robert DeSilva lifted the phone and murmured: "Yes . . . 271 East Fourth Street . . . ground floor . . unconscious . . . thank you."
A boy's wish became a Presidential command yesterday.
TOKYO, Aug. 28 -- The Japanese Government assured South Korea today that the return of Okinawa to Japan would in no way compromise the security of Asia.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 29 -- Barney Ward piloted Northway to victory tonight in the open jumper class at the New York State Fair horse show to score a sweep in the jumper division.

RIVERS, Manitoba -- From inside the modern, brown ranch-house the sound of a piano drifted across Henry Lepp's front lawn, past the three spreading maple trees. In the flat fields, the knee-high wheat waved in a gentle breeze. Children galloped on the grass.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 29 -- What do Thanksgiving, Christmas, New Year's Day, Passover, Easter, Memorial Day and Independence Day all have in common?

OWERRI, Biafra (Nigeria) -- Aug. 29 -- A Red Cross official said today that the problem of hunger inside the besieged Biafran lines was in several ways more ominous than it was during the protein famine of 1968.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- The Security Council agreed unanimously today to act as a "committee of experts" to consider associate, or nonvoting membership for countries too small or too poor to meet the financial and political responsibilities of full membership in the United Nations.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 29 -- Tensions rose in this city of 200,000 today as a school boycott called by blacks unexpectedly combined with sporadic violence along Franklin Street in the center of the Negro section.

An Episcopal priest from St. Paul's Church in Manhattan was shot to death in a holdup attempt yesterday afternoon on a Brooklyn street.

OAKMONT, Pa., Aug. 29 -- Par at Oakmont proved adamant again today, but Steve Melnyk, the 235-pound golfer from Brunswick, Ga., retained the lead in the United States Amateur championship with a 54-hole score of 216.

An America weary of the stalemate in efforts to end the Vietnam war will have little patience with the battle of communiques between the State Department and the Pentagon over how much importance to attach to the drop-off in North Vietnamese infiltration into the south.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The makers of a newly patented electronic color measuring instrument call it the first to "read" color as the human eyes sees it.

The red, black and green "black liberation" flag that has flown for two months at a state construction site at 125th Street and Seventh Avenue was lowered at 6:30 A.M. yesterday by Parks Commissioner August Heckscher.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Government, responding to the hijacking of a United States airliner to Syria today, issued statements of protest and attempted to get information on the incident.
PARIS, Aug. 29 -- France will embark Monday on a major gamble that deliberately reduced internal consumption will not affect production or employment.

And Americans are reminded of the fragility of the bonds of tolerance that bind cities together.

DETROIT, Aug. 29 (AP) -- Car production in the United States and Canada rallied sharply this week as the automakers rushed to meet the usual heavy list of orders for the new cars. The Ohio Casualty Insurance Company said yesterday that a special stockholders' meeting would be held on Sept. 26 to seek the approval of the formation of a new holding company and the ratification of an agreement to buy 375,000 of the company's shares from the American Financial Corporation of Cincinnati for $12-million.
VERNON, Conn., Aug. 29 -- Ten persons in a bus bound for Boston were cut by flying glass today when windows were smashed by a 193-pound spare tire that had broken loose from a truck.

WILLINGBORO, N. J., Aug. 29 -- This middle-class community was shaken last night when hundreds of black and white students engaged in a free-for-all after a dance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Brig. Gen. James D. Hittle of the Marine Corps, retired, condemned the North Vietnamese Government today for its continued refusal to abide by the Geneva Convention on the treatment of prisoners of war.

The bulk of the estimated $4-million estate left by Frank Loesser, the composer, goes to his widow and four children, it was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where his will was offered for probate.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 -President Nixon told Zionist leaders today that his Administration has assigned the highest priority to permanent peace in the Middle East.
CHANGING fashions in the favorite stocks of major investment companies are pointed up in the latest report of the Value Line Investment Survey on the largest holdings of 99 investment companies.

Prices moved up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in continued light trading.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 29 -- Secretary General Thant asked member governments today for a budget of $164,123,000 for 1970, an increase of 6 per cent over the 1969 budget. He indicated that the United Nations, like many householders, was struggling with soaring living costs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) -- An Interior Department study recommends that a proposed huge jetport in Florida near the Everglades National Park be located at another site, Senator Gaylord Nelson, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today.
FORREST CITY, Ark., Aug. 29 (AP) -- Whites vowed today to continue picketing in this racially troubled city until they have forced the resignations of Mayor Robert Cope and Police Chief Marvin Gunn.
Legislation to regulate parking lot and garage rates will be approved by the City Council before the end of the year, Council spokesmen said yesterday.

A lightly raced filly owned by Mrs. Ada L. Rice, and a "shipper" from Miles Park made for a daily double of $967.40 at Belmont Park yesterday. WESTBURY, L. I., Aug. 29 -- The $40,000 Challenge Cup Trot, the annual sequel to the $100,000 International, will be a six-horse event tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Federal District Judge George L. Hart Jr. today postponed the issuance of a declaratory judgment that Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. was entitled to have been seated in the 90th Congress two years ago.

WASHINGTON Aug. 29--The chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission warned today that violent demonstrations against job discrimination like those in Pittsburgh this week could happen anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from Monday's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon. The auction was held today, rather than Monday, because of the Labor Day holiday.

David L. Cole, who was named Thursday as intermediary in the Metropolitan Opera labor dispute, announced yesterday that representatives of the unions and management would confer jointly with him on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- A predominantly Negro citizens group in the District of Columbia is putting the finishing touches on a formal petition to deny renewal of the WMAL-TV broadcasting license to The Washington Evening Star.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 -- The New York Mets' six-game winning streak collided with the San Francisco Giants' eight-game winning streak tonight. and did not survive.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 -- The old man would have been proud had he seen his beloved Nina take off in the Stamford Yacht Club's Vineyard Trophy Race today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- The Federal Reserve Board announced today an increase of $200-million to $500-million in its "swap" credit line with Belgium.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 29 -- A six-square-mile area immediately southeast of Jerusalem was sealed off by the Israeli Army at dawn today and placed under an indefinite around-the-clock curfew. The area contains the site from which Palestinian guerrillas fired rockets at Jerusalem earlier this week.

WARSAW, Aug. 29 (UPI) -- Ben Vaughn of Georgia Tech sprinted to victory in the men's 100 and 200 meter races today as the United States dominated an eight-nation track and field meet on Poland's first Tartan track in the Skra Club stadium.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- Secretary of the Navy John H. Chafee, rejecting protests of New York political and community leaders, announced today that the Navy would go ahead with plans to sharply reduce jobs at the Naval Applied Science Laboratory in the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 -- American officials here indicated publicly and privately today that they were moving more quickly than in earlier cases to obtain the release of three wounded helicopter crewmen held by North Korea.

Following a mild recession last year, Norway's economy is again on the upswing, according to the survey released last week by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 (AP) -- United States land and naval guns shelled North Vietnam's half of the demilitarized zone yesterday for the first time in 37 days after the enemy had fired on an American scout plane, the United States command said today.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 31 (AP) -Johnny Bench's homer touched off a five-run second inning that carried the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.
MIAMI -- A conversation with the president of the Honduran airline Transportes Aeros Nacionales (TAN) could range all the way from a technical discussion of a prop jet to a recipe for making paella.

Daniel T. Scannell, executive officer of the Transit Authority, said yesterday that any fare increase would not bring a significant drop in the number of passengers because the authority is already down to a hard core of riders, who have no choice but to use city buses and subways.

Departmental charges are being brought against 34 policemen because of complaints to the Civilian Complaint Review Board in the first six months of the year, according to the Police Department. This is double the number of policemen formally charged in the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover forecast today "a continuation of the senseless plunder" on United States campuses when colleges and universities resume classes in the fall.

NAHA, Okinawa, Aug. 31 -- The Japanese Government intends to push ahead with efforts to develop the potentially rich undersea oilfields in the Senkaku Island area of the southern Ryukyuan archipelago.

A well-dressed man, carrying three $100 bills and a picture of himself, was found shot to death and dumped gangland style in a downtown Brooklyn parking lot on Saturday night. He was the third Brooklyn murder victim within 30 hours.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- A 16-month investigation that involved officials of the United States, France and Lebanon has resulted in the arrest of two men and the seizure of 1,256 pounds of raw opium in France, the Justice Department announced today.

The renaissance of the Green Bay Packers was the leading development at the Cleveland double-header on Saturday night when a record crowd of 85,532 saw the Packers beat the Browns, 27-17, and the Chicago Bears defeat the Buffalo Bills, 23-16.

Nodouble heads a field of eight horses today in the first running of the $110,400 Governor Nicolls Stakes at Belmont Park. The event for 3-year-olds and up is named for Richard Nicolls, the first English Colonial governor of New York, who introduced thoroughbred racing on Long Island at Hempstead Plains in 1665.
FREDERICK, Md. -- H. Irving Gates is a sculptor. His wife, Elaine Adrienne-Gates, is a painter. Their house is a collage, a construction, a mobile or, as the current art term goes, "an environment."
OWERRI, Biafra (Nigeria), Aug. 31 -- Biafrans have reacted with shock and outrage to the news that Dr. Nnamdi Azikiwe, one of their past political heroes, had criticized their fight for independence.
SWEDESBORO, N. J., Aug. 31 (AP) -- A 33-year-old Newark man was arraigned in Swedesboro-Woolwich Township Municipal Court here today on charges of murdering a 20-year-old coed last month.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 31 -- The Government of South Africa has granted visas to seven black Africans from Zambia and Rhodesia to attend a confererence here at which its policy of apartheid, or racial segregation, is expected to come under fire.
BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 3 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission will come to the University of Vermont here on Sept. 11 to defend nuclear electric generating stations.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31 -One of harness racing's oldest, most important and most coveted trotting marks -- Greyhound's 1:55 1/4 time-trial clocking for a mile -- was shattered today by Nevele Pride over the all-clay, one-mile oval at the Indiana State Fairgrounds.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Passengers of the Trans World Airlines jet hijacked to Damascus on Friday said tonight that Syrians armed with rifles threatened to arrest them if they tried to interfere with the detention of six Israelis still held in Damascus.

Frank Fernandez went to bat four times yesterday for the Yankees against the Kansas City Royals and all the box score shows for his times at bat is a zero. Fernandez walked four straight times, figuring in two of his team's runs, as the Bombers ended their season series with the Royals with a flashy 5-3 victory.

WOODSIDE BAY, Isle of Wight, Aug. 31 -- This small island off the south coast of England, usually a tranquil attraction for sedate middle-aged British tourists, was flooded today with young people in multicolored jeans, velvet trousers and Hiawatha dresses listening to 25 consecutive hours of amplified pop music.
RIO DE JANEIRO -- Brazilian brokers boast that Rio's stock market has been booming while New York's has been drooping.
CAIRO, Aug. 31 -- Dr. Nureddin el-Attassi, Syria's head of state, arrived here today from Damacus to join King Hussein of Jordan and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

Since the present wave of trouble began in Northern Ireland, the press and television have continually given full coverage and time to the opinions of extremists of both the Nationalist and Protestant elements.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 31 -Brazil and Mexico, the two Latin-American countries with the largest national markets, have agreed to promote joint industrial ventures and stimulate trade.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- A Federal grand jury has apparently made an extensive review of the 1968 campaign contributions to former Maryland Senator Daniel B. Brewster.
TOKYO, Aug. 31 -- The Japanese Government will ease some of its restrictions against sending money out of the country, starting tomorrow.

If clothes really do make the man, as some entrepreneurs suggest, Manhattan's businessmen remain a varied lot . . . still conservative at the lower end of the island, increasingly colorful in the middle and rather elegant on top.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 31 (Reuters) -- Talks between Thailand and the United States on the gradual withdrawal of American troops in Thailand probably will begin Wednesday, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 31 -- Turkish and Iranian experts have decided to meet within the next two months to consider the construction of a 1,000-mile-long oil pipeline from the Persian Gulf to the Mediterranean Sea. The project would bypass Arab countries and enable Iranian-based oil companies to reach lucrative European markets at considerable savings in time and at an estimated one-third reduction in costs.

LAWRENCE WASHBURN Jr., a lawyer with Sullivan, Donovan, Hanrahan, McGovern Lane, together with Edward Mandt, manager of corporate personnel at Borden, Inc., and Betsy and David McKearnan (he's vice president at Berkeley Photo, Inc.) put on old clothes one night recently and got together to wash down some dreadful green walls and a ceiling in preparation for painting.

Labor Day finds many union leaders wondering whether it is time to put a treadmill in place of the collective bargaining table. Unions have been winning wage and fringe increases that would have seemed astronomic three or four years ago; yet, inflation eats up the extra purchasing power before wage-earners can begin to enjoy it.
BONN, Aug. 31 -- With Federal parliamentary elections a month away, the campaign for the ballots of West Germany's 31 million eligible voters is off to a bewildering start.

LEWISVILLE, Tex., Aug. 31 -- While the older generation watched, sometimes with binoculars, from pleasure boats and air-conditioned cars, thousands of youths gathered in this area today for the Texas International Pop Festival.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 31 -- At the major intersection of this 309-year-old village, where cars converge along Montauk Highway, Sag Harbor Turnpike, Ocean Avenue and Lumber Lane, stands a memorial to the war dead going back to the Revolution.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -Controversy over the role that the family of the president of the United Mine Workers of America has played in both union and management affairs is spreading from the Appalachian coal fields of the East to the farthest seam in the continent.
CHICAGO, Aug. 31 -- The opening on schedule of Chicago's public schools Wednesday, something considered unlikely only a few days ago, now appears to be assured.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Aug. 31 -- Oil company sponsors of what has been called "the largest private construction project in the free world" made a direct bid over the weekend for the favor of conservationists.

LADENTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 31 -- Mor Shor Kennels' 2 1/2-yearold whippet, Ch. Winterfold's Bold Bid, gained her sixth best-in-show today at the Rockland County Kennel Club, topping an entry list of 860 dogs.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, Aug. 31 -- When Peter Hall was artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company he achieved many reforms and promoted many developments. It was, for example, under his direction at the company acquired a London home and also started to vary its diet of Shakespeare with other classic and even contemporary plays.

CLOSE to noon Easter Monday, April 24, 1916, downtown Dubliners were bemused by the spectacle of a ragtag contingent of "forty men, two trucks, one closed cab, two motorcycles, and a green Ford touring car" making its way up O'Connell Street and halting before the imposing Palladian edifice of the General Post Office.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 31 -- The world has been hearing much these last weeks about the Paisleys, the O'Neills, the Conways and the Chichester-Clarks of Northern Ireland , but what of the Cohens?

Grace Line's luxury passenger ship Santa Paula is at sea minus 32 of her crew as a result of a dispute within the National Maritime Union. The liner normally has a crew of 265, of whom 210 are N.M.U. members.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 31 -- They came in cars and trucks, in buses and campers and trailers, lumbering through the foothills of the Sierra Nevada, toward a Labor Day weekend away from the agonies of city life. But by Thursday evening they read this sign at the park entrance: "All campsites are full."
A plastic-bodied light car for work or play is appearing in Citroen showrooms in this country. It is called the Mehari, for the swift dromedaries of the Sahara sands.

At 1:31 P.M. yesterday, in his eyrie just below the control tower at Kennedy International Airport in Queens, James McMurray peered briefly at the planes and runways and buildings spread out on the field before him, then leaned over his cluttered desk and wrote "PA 111 21" on the Telautograph machine.

PRAIRIEVILLE, La., Aug. 31 -- Flags proclaiming "Peace" fluttered in the humid breeze and the amplified sound of the Grateful Dead spilled over a crowd of more than 25,000 young persons who sprawled on blankets as the New Orleans Pop Festival grooved happily through its first day today.

PATCHOGUE, L.I., Aug. 31 -Robert David, already assured of the season's point championship on the Great South Bay in the Lightning Class and one of 10 skippers seeking series sweeps in the annual Labor Day weekend invitation regatta of the Bellport Bay Yacht Club, scored his second victory today.

In a humid school auditorium in Harlem recently, a drama student from Queens College was staging his first theatrical production, an elaborate musical with sailors, pirates and monsters played by more than 300 excited youngsters enrolled in a city-run summer day camp.

The country has reason to hope that the 91st Congress has had a good rest; the demands on it from its return on Wednesday to the end of the session will be formidable. CHARLES COON of New York and David Cliff of Basking Ridge, N. J., headed a field of 266 pairs to win the open pairs title Saturday in the Knickerbocker Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association.

FLINT, Mich., Aug. 31 -- The Labor Day weekend is passing quietly in Flint this year, with no speeches and no parades.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 31 -- State Senator John J. Marchi stood on the champagnecolored sands and shook his head. He had planned to spend five hours touring the beaches that stretch for miles along the crashing gray ocean, but fog delayed his arrival and he had time to visit only one.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 31 -- Democratic Governors, concerned about their dwindling numbers and influence in national politics, decided today to ask their party's national chairman here to discuss ways of achieving a stronger voice in party matters.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. -- A small gray pipe that juts a few feet above ground here and extends more than half a mile into the earth is a means of disposing of 250 gallons of industrial waste, including hydrochloric acid, every minute.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Frank Howard smashed his 42d homer of the year and his teammates hit three more today to pace the Washington Senators to an 8-3 victory over the Oakland Athletics. Ken McMullen, Bernie Allen and Mike Epstein got the other homers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31 -The New York Mets ended a tumultuous weekend in Candlestick Park today by splitting a double-header with the San Francisco Giants, and slipped four games behind the firstplace Chicago Cubs.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 31 -- A group of black and white militants, many of them barefoot, wrested the microphone from a speaker at a special session of the general convention of the Episcopal Church here tonight.

OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- George Blanda left the bench in the second half to throw three touchdown passes and give the Oakland Raiders a 42-28 victory over the San Francisco 49ers in a preseason game today.

Plans to resume helicopter service to Kennedy and Newark Airports from the heliport atop the Pan Am Building ought to be vetoed by Federal and city officials. PITTSBURGH, Aug. 31 -- Demand for steel is strong but uneven.
