LA PAZ; Bolivia, Aug. 31 -- Like an apprentice acrobat thrust by surprise onto a swaying high wire, Bolivia's civilian Government is struggling to survive what appears to be an interregnum between military governments.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 31 -- The nation's Governors appear to be closing ranks in a plea to the Nixon Administration and Congress for full Federal funding of the welfare system.
Vito (Babe) Parilli, the elder statesman of the New York Jets, is the next old pro on the world champions who is threatened with being placed on American Football League waivers.
HONG KONG, Aug. 31 -- Prospects are considered highly uncertain for the campaign just launched by U Nu to oust General Ne Win from his dictatorial control of Burma.

MIAMI, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Hurricane Francelia harassed shipping today as it whirled through the northwest Caribbean -- a tropical spawning ground for some of this country's greatest storms. Although the storm was poorly organized, Francelia was termed "a potential leg of dynamite."

The Aug. 21 letter of Fanny T. Taber notes that "above all things [the American people] love [s] a victory, whether in a ball game or a war" and uses this argument to justify military victory in Vietnam.
The Freeport Sulphur Comany indicated last week that it does not expect 1969 earnings to match those of 1968, a record year, because of a continuing downward pressure on prices.

ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 31 -- Team McLaren won its sixth consecutive Can-Am race of the season today in its bright orange McLaren M8B-Chevrolets. Because yesterday was Bruce McLaren's 32d birthday, it was his turn to come in first.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Bill Singer stopped Philadelphia on six hits for his 17th victory and Willie Davis extended his hitting streak to 28 games today as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Phillies, 4-1, for a sweep of their three-game series.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 31 -- Navy dismissed Bill Elias as its football coach and hired Rick Forzano last winter for the usual reason -- belief that a change would turn a loser into a winner. It won't happen overnight.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 29 -- The Gold Room of the Sheraton-Jefferson Hotel was packed the other day with more than 1,000 state legislators and their assistants who had managed to make it to an 8 A.M. breakfast session of the annual National Legislative Conference.

PROVIDENCE, Utah -- A trap door in the hallway outside Mrs. Deloy Hendricks's kitchen leads to a damp, dark root and fruit cellar where the vestiges of last year's potato crop are still firm despite a few sprouting shoots.
Mayor Lindsay urged unity in the city yesterday on a campaign tour of crowded Brooklyn beaches and was received with applause as well as recurrent boos and catcalls.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -Two groups of senior French officials and deputies in the National Assembly will visit the United States in coming weeks as part of what officials here term the improving political climate between the two countries.

CASTROVILLE, Calif., Aug. 31 (UPI) -- Two highway patrolmen returned to their jobs today after coming in contact with methyl parathion, an insecticide described by the authorities as a "nerve poison."

Overseas National Airways, a supplemental airline active in passenger charter activities from the United States to Hawaii, the Caribbean and Europe, announced yesterday another expansion move into the cruise business.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 31 (AP) -- Two great pass catches by Charles Frazier sparked the Boston Patriots to their biggest offense of the preseason campaign today and a 26-10 victory over an American Football League rival, the Denver Broncos.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 31 -- The first gusts of controversy have disturbed the somewhat stagnant waters of the 30th Venice Film Festival, which has been in progress desultorily since Aug. 23. ATLANTA, Aug. 31 -- Ken Holtzman overcame the inspired hitting of the Braves' Clete Boyer with two hits of his own today as the Chicago Cubs downed Atlanta, 8-4.

VIENNA, Aug. 31 -- Communist leaders, newspapers and special broadcasts across Eastern Europe today commemorated the 30th anniversary of the outbreak of World War II with denunciations of West German "revanchism" and renascent militarism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 -- The tip of the iceberg of Ailsa Mellon Bruce's generosity to the National Gallery of Art went on show here this weekend. VIENNA, Sept. 1 -- Czechoslovakia today eased frontier controls imposed two weeks ago making entry of Western tourists, except West Germans, simpler.

PORTIMAO, Portugal -- Sirens wail, whistles blow and everyone runs jubilantly into the street -- as though it were New Year's Day in midsummer. It is the return of the fishermen and, today, there are fish and work for the canneries.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 -- Israel's Attorney General, Meir Shamgar, filed formal charges today against the 28-year-old Australian farmer accused of having set the fire that heavily damaged Al Aksa mosque in the Old City of Jerusalem on Aug. 21.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -The United States Tariff Commission, acting upon a request from President Nixon, has started an investigation of a once-obscure section of the tariff law that has recently become a source of criticism and dispute.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Sept. 1 -- Backers of the Black Economic Development Conference won a round here today when the Episcopal Church's Special General Convention abruptly changed its agenda to discuss a proposal of official support for the Negro group, which is seeking $500-million in "reparations" from American churches and synagogues.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 1 (AP) -- Shooting, fires and rock throwing were reported in a Negro neighborhood on Fort Lauderdale's Northwest Side tonight for the second consecutive night.

New York State will submit to its voters on Nov. 4 a constitutional amendment that seeks to achieve a desirable aim in a peculiarly roundabout fashion. COLOMBO, Ceylon, Sept. 1 -- The value of Ceylon's exports in this year's first half rose by almost 160-million rupees ($26.5million) in spite of a poor performance for coconut and tea in the first quarter. CINI BOERI, an Italian architect and designer, has created a one-room environment on the ninth floor of Gimbels that many will want only to visit but some may want to move into. The curiously inviting room, dim and luxurious, is all midnight blue -- walls, shiny vinyl ceil ing, long rows of huge, loungey seats hugging the floor, and boxy, movable storage units.

The announcement by The New York Times that it will require health warnings in all cigarette advertising after Jan. 1 has caused considerable concern in the tobacco industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- A two-hit pitching performance by Dick Bosman and home runs by Frank Howard and Ken McMullen gave the Senators a 6-1 triumph over the Yankees tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Sept. 11 -- The 72hour cease-fire declared by the Vietcong and agreed to partially by the allies ended early today and it appeared that both sides had immediately gone back on the offensive.

Robert F. Williams is a black militant who fled this country eight years ago to avoid a charge of kidnapping in his home town of Monroe, N. C. Since then he has preached violent revolution in the United States from such places as Cuba, Communist China, North Vietnam and Africa.

The appointments of James L. Greenfield as foreign editor of The New York Times and Henry R. Lieberman as director of science and education were announced yesterday by A. M. Rosenthal, the managing editor of The Times.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- His own voice stilled by death, Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen was eulogized today in words that he himself might have spoken of others in times of grief.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -Civil rights lawyers complained tonight at a meeting in the Justice Department that Attorney General John N. Mitchell had not acknowledged their protests that the Nixon Administration had softened rights enforcement.
Police and welfare demonstrators clashed yesterday on the Lower East Side, where windows were shattered and protesters, including many teen-agers, exhorted youngsters to join in a boycott of classes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- An Administration spokesman suggested today that a method similar to federally assisted school lunch programs could be used to feed the 10 million aging Americans who are unable to feed themselves.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Israel, hard-pressed in its balance of payments, has obtained a new $22.5-million loan from the International Monetary Fund, the fund announced today. The credit comes on top of an equal amount withdrawn in May.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 10 -Israeli Air Force planes today completed the devastation of the Egyptian coastline on the Gulf of Suez that was attacked yesterday by an armored column, it was reported here.

THERE were two notable upsets during the recent United States Open in Lincoln, Neb. Milan Vukcevich of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, totally unknown to American buffs before the start of this 12-round Swiss, defeated Grandmaster Arthur Bisguier of Hartsdale, N. Y., in the eighth round, and Master Victors Pupols of Holly, Wash., defeated Grandmaster Pal Benko of New York in the sixth.

A suspended patrolman who pleaded guilty last May to charges of soliciting money from a Harlem florist and steering auto accident victims to a lawyer was conditionally discharged in Criminal Court yesterday.

PRO football, the television game, will have three strong attractions for the TV audience on Sunday. The Jet opener at Buffalo begins at 1:30, followed immediately by Houston at Oakland on a five-hour, Channel 4 double- header.

Political candidates running for office were advised yesterday by Municipal Service Administrator John G. Duba that the Administrative Code prohibited placing campaign material on lampposts and other municipal property.
Three prominent Wall Street firms announced executive appointments yesterday.

The Sept. 8 letter of Edwin H. Baker Pratt Jr. concerning the hijacking of a TWA jet by Arab terrorists apparently equates the two male Israeli passengers detained by the Syrians with major Nazi war criminals. This is ludicrous.

SUBIC BAY, Philippines Thursday, Sept. 11 -- The officer of the deck of the United States destroyer Frank E. Evans pleaded guilty today to charges of negligence and dereliction of duty in the collision of his vessel with the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, stressing he was not making a forecast, said today "there are indications we may be getting to the end" of the period of very high interest rates.

White Consolidated Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it would appeal to the Supreme Court a court decision on Tuesday that, among other things, would prevent White Consolidated from voting its nearly 30 per cent interest in Allis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- The Washington Caps of the American Basketball Association, announced today the signing of the Detroit Pistons' star guard, Dave Bing, but the Piston general manager, Ed Coil, said Bing would not leave the National Basketball Association club for two years.

Thousands of consumers who buy on credit are being victimized every year by a state law that immunizes banks and finance companies against consumer claims of defective merchandise, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz told a public hearing yesterday.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Sept. 10 -- The State Division of Human Rights has found the Glen Cove Municipal Civil Service Commission guilty of discrimination against Negroes seeking salaried positions with the city's Volunteer Fire Department.

LENA HORNE last night conquered the lifetime of peculiar discrimination by American television. She has made a number of specials overseas, and most were imported by independent stations in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- The 1964 Civil Rights Act's ban on discrimination in employment should be backed by stronger enforcement powers, an official of the United States Commission on Civil Rights testified today.

TANNERSVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- The New York City Patrolmen's Benevolent Association adopted a resolution here today calling on the Police Department to "restrict recruitment to those men and women who have demonstrated their ability to serve as examples of the highest ideal of dedication to good citizenship."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -The Justice Department agreed today to settle a suit that accused the country's major automobile manufacturers of having conspired to retard the development and use of devices to control air pollution from cars.

Prompted by the success of recent expansion, which added six teams and a new division, the National Hockey League will expand from 12 to 14 teams for the 1970-71 season and realignment of the teams is planned.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- The French railroad system was virtually paralyzed today by the first major strike to test the Government's austerity program.

WASHINGTON -- The rug hangs with its bottom edge a good nine feet from the floor. The sign just under it says "Please do not touch." The mural floor covering of knotted wool pile is 31 feet by 7-feet-9-inches. The British Embassy says it's the largest handmade rug in the world. It was made by old-age pensioners and disabled people at Blackfriars Settlement, London.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -The Internal Revenue Service has begun an investigation of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, the Justice Department has disclosed in a letter to the House of Representatives.
The election of Harold S. Gelb as treasurer of the Citizen's Budget Commission was announced yesterday by John W. Larson, president of the organization.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- The General Motors Corporation today raised the prices of its 1970 cars 3.9 per cent -- or an average of $125 a car -- over 1969 levels.

CHICAGO, Sept. 13 (UPI) -Tony Cuccinello and Ray Barres, two Chicago White Sox coaches, announced yesterday their retirement effective at the end of the season. Mathews, exercised a right she helped establish today when she qualified as a poor person to run for alderman in the Oct. 7 city election. It was Italy's second mass protest over soccer in less than a week. Fans rioted for two days in Caserta against the demotion of their club.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 13 -- Lee May's two-run homer in the eighth inning snapped a tie and sent the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-4 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.
RENSSELAER, Ind., Sept. 13 (AP) -- St. Joseph's Pumas opened the football season with their highest single-game score since 1957, beating Olivet of Michigan, 46-0, today.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 13 (AP) -- A 15-year-old boy was killed and his two sisters were injured at their home here shortly after midnight yesterday.

THE first junior International to be held in Scotland produced a fitting winner recently. Seventeenyear-old Roderick McKay of Scotland finished in first place, scoring 7 points out of a possible 9. During this 10-man round robin, McKay did not lose one game outright.

J., Sept. 14 -The ability of country musicians to create a close rapport with their audiences highlighted the final program of the two-day Country Music Festival last night at the Garden State Art Center. KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 14 -- The 6.3-million-member National Baptist Convention, U.S.A., Inc., the largest all-black Protestant denomination in the United States, ended its weeklong annual assembly here today firmly committed to the concept of racial integration and convinced that militancy will lead only to a "disastrously" divided nation.

Rodney L. White, a senior partner and member of the executive committee of Oppenheimer Co., investment bankers, drowned Saturday while on a fishing trip in Quebec. He was 39 years old and lived at 200 East End Avenue and Round Hill Road, Greenwich, Conn.

LONDON, Sept. 14 (AP) -Because of an argument over who is to run Pergamon Press, the Leasco Data Processing Company's bid for the publishing house has been called off again. COLUMBIA, S. C., Sept. 14 (AP) -- A Florida millionaire, Glenn Turner of Orlando, whose father was a South Carolina sharecropper, has given the South Carolina Opportunity School $1-million for scholarships. The Opportunity School gives high school educations to students who would not pursue a college education.
